This is the correction to be imposed on the action of the Commission.Mrs. President, Lords, in the fundamental democratic principle of respect for human rights and freedom and sovereignty of peoples, against any new or old fascism, Nazism or communism, and taking into account that all previous speakers have spoken of sovereignty of the Austrian people, we verify that today it is precisely this Parliament that denies said sovereignty.From the reading of the Austrian Liberal Party program, elements that justify the accusations of attack on the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law, contemplated in article 6 of the Treaty are not extracted.On the other hand, I would like to get the attention of their lordships about the fact that recently the president in the exercise of the Council, so critical of Austria, has given the inhabitants of Macao the sovereignty of the democratic Republic of Popular China.But today, to reinforce the democracy of the Union, it is appropriate to isolate Austria, criminalize a democratically chosen party by Austrian citizens and allow the entry into Europe of the Turkey of the Gray Wolves.Mrs. President, Ladies and Lords Deputies, we are discussing a matter of extreme gravity.Nothing more and nothing less than the presence in a government of a Member State of a political force whose doctrine and whose principles are incompatible with the conceptual and moral bases that inspire the union and that are enshrined in their constitutive treaties.A simple reading of article 1 of chapter 4 of the political program of the Austrian Liberal Party shuds any democratic consciousness.The assumption of ethnicity as a defining factor of a nation and the affirmation of the superiority of an ethnicity over the others, as it is written here, resurrects old spectra of a century that we have just left behind and that some historians have defined as the century of horrors, horrors that the unacceptable philosophy of Mr. Haider's political program again agitates before our stunned eyes.Of course, the Austrian people are sovereign and of course we must respect the principle of non -interference in the internal affairs of a Member State.But the problem is not that.The problem is whether the Union can remain indifferent to the formation of a government in a Member State that includes a party of such characteristics.Our answer to this crucial question is no.Beyond strategic or tactical considerations, beyond possible exculpations extracted from otherwise behaviors, and above the interest of the party or electoral situation, the Spanish delegation of the popular group of this Parliament, in full tune with the Spanish Popular Party and with the Government of Spain, expresses with roundness its full coincidence with the declaration of the Portuguese Presidency of the Council on January 31With its tone and with its reach.(Applause) Konrad Adenauer said on one occasion - and he knew what he said - that the safest way to appease a tiger is to allow you to devour you.History is the compendium of those things that could have been avoided.

We will not fail to focus all our attention on this problem because all the credibility of the authorities and the representative structures of the Albanians in the field also depends on their ability to prove that they are capable of applying measures guaranteeing the multiethnic nature of the territory.I would like to thank Mr. President in office.I have in mind - like all of us, I think - that Portugal, his former president Mr. Soares and his government observed a circumspect and moderate attitude during bombings in the Balkans.Today's political declaration on this issue is very positive, I emphasize and congratulate myself.Despite everything, a concern arises, because if, on the side of the European Union, the intentions are good and sincere, the results are very thin.Unfortunately, lately, we have been witnessing the disappearance of all the minorities - Serbs, Roma, Turks, Croats, - Kosovo and we wonder what will happen.We note the failure of the United Nations mission and Mr. Kouchner in Kosovo.Because it is a failure that after a whole war waged to avoid an ethnic purification, there is a purification due to the other edge.This is why I repeat my question: does the Council intend to take more concrete initiatives to tackle these questions with Mr. Kouchner, on a very large part responsible for the situation that prevails today in Kosovo.Mr. Alavanos, I cannot agree with what you have just said, with your last sentence concerning the responsibilities of Mr. Kouchner and I would like to make a very important distinction: the structure installed in Kosovo is a structure under the supervision of the United Nations.The European Union gave it all the possible support and the countries of the European Union, as such, contributed to it in different ways.But it cannot be denied that Mr. Kouchner's efforts in order to normalize the inner situation of Kosovo are extremely positive.Regardless of the fact that you can estimate and that we too estimate that certain results of these efforts, for reasons which exceed Mr. Kouchner, could not be as effective as we would all wish it.It is necessary to make a distinction, on the one hand, between the question of the responsibility of the European Union and, in particular in this case, the possible action of the Council in this context and, on the other hand, the responsibility of the international community as such, which has the general supervision on the situation in Kosovo.The responsibility of the European Union is therefore part of a determined context.It is towards the international community as such, in particular the United Nations, that it is necessary to turn to the responsibilities of implementing resolution 12/99 and in particular as to the logic underlying this resolution and the compatibility of this resolution with reality.These are questions that we must ask ourselves, but it is within the framework of the United Nations that we must ask ourselves these questions.

His honor has referred to the issue of Ethiopia, which is part of the scope of national indicative programs, but there is, as his honor knows, various community actions to fight AIDS and, in that regard, his honor is right, probably the United States is not doing better.For the rest, in terms of development aid policy I consider that Europe rigorously has anything to worry about the simple reason that our behavior in this regard has no comparison with that of the United States.The question of his honor has derived towards the problem of the armaments, of a broader political nature, which does not seem to me that he fits in the scope of this question, but that in the future the Council will naturally face it if it considers it appropriate, and decides to raise it in a specific framework.Is the advice of the social problems that causes food export to developing countries below the EU production costs?Does the country plan in the exercise of the Presidency to intervene in this matter?Since its author is not present, question No. 13 decays.I thank Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, in whose person I personally welcome the Presidency of the Portuguese Government.Let me point out what eloquent is and what versed is in European issues.However, in my case it has not given the answer that I would consider satisfactory.If the Council recognizes the great importance of culture as an economic good, in my opinion I should also demonstrate it in practice.And I fear that the justification that the cultural sector is conditioned by the principle of subsidiarity and that, therefore, it is the responsibility of national governments is an apparent justification.Because the question that I had raised and that has been unanswered was why when the European Parliament requests an increase in the funds for the financing of the cultural programs of the European Union, the Council, as well as the Commission, as a general rule they cut them, sometimes even even cancel them.This, in practice, shows its indifference towards culture, despite the promises of the Council about the great importance that is supposed to give it.Thus, I would like to ask the advice if you are willing to support culture there with the same complacency with which the banana, hops, cows or hemp of India finances.We do not have, honor, an economic conception of our management of the Portuguese presidency and, therefore, the cultural dimension, as it will understand, is at the center of our concerns.But these cultural dimensions almost always have an economic dimension, in turn, that is, the set of resources susceptible to mobilization precisely for support for cultural actions.And that is a dimension that is difficult to overcome in the field of the European Union and, in particular, in the scope of the Council.For our part, we will try to strengthen and consolidate the European position regarding cultural goods and services and activities in that sphere, because we think this is one of the elements of the essential identity of the image of the union itself and its own specific identity.

You may be aware that this hospital is located in the northern part of the city and that, in view of the tense existing situation, Albankosovares cannot access the hospital under any circumstances.What does the commission do to ensure that Albanokosovares have access to the hospital?Regarding the first question, I will travel personally to Kosovo at the beginning of next month to make another visit and I will undoubtedly examine the allegations that his lordship has made about Echo's food package.I had not heard anything about that indication before, but it is an important observation and I will not stop investigating it when it is there.Secondly, I perfectly understand what your honor says about Mitrovica.I was in Mitrovica a couple of months ago and I could see for myself what the situation was.He had conversations with the municipal leaders of both communities, including the leader of the Albana party, which in the past had exercised as a doctor and won everyone's recognition for their medical assistance during and after hostilities.Therefore, I know the serious problem that exists in that hospital and I can assure your honor that we will not spare efforts to ensure that everyone in Kosovo has access to adequate health care, regardless of the ethnic group to which it belongs.The specific difficulties that exist in Mitrovica - for example, is not only a matter that Albanian patients have difficulty accessing the hospital, but that Albanian staff have had difficulty working there - represent a especially serious problem.We will try to find solutions, but it is not easy.Question No. 37 Formulated by (H-0029/00): Subject: The blockade maintained by Turkey against Armenia taking into account that the European Union actively promotes social, economic and political relations with Armenia under the collaboration and cooperation agreement signed on October 12, 1999, what measures is proposed to adopt the commission to persuade the Turkish government of the need to raise the economic block that maintains against Armenia?The Commission supports all efforts to find a solution to the conflicts between Türkiye and Armenia and regrets that a normalization of relations between the two countries has not yet been achieved.In the current political circumstances, it is, however, unrealistic imagining that the border between Armenia and Türkiye, as well as that between Armenia and Azerbaijan, can be opened without having previously reached a solution to the Nagorni Karabaj conflict.Mr. President, the Commission also negotiates with the view set on the future, in view of the incorporation of Türkiye into the European Union.Is the commission to impose the previous lifting of the blockade as a condition for the start of the conversations, given that we are all neighbors and we also want to cultivate positive neighborhood relations within the European Union?My question is, therefore, the following: Is the commission proposed imposing this as one of the conditions to improve the result of future deliberations?The fundamental issue is the support for the efforts of the Minsk Group of the OSCE aimed at finding a solution to the Nagorni Karabaj conflict, and we are willing to help in everything we can.

I want to approach another fundamental democratic question without eyeshadow.As a member of the Assembly who has just started his work on the Charter of fundamental rights, I mean in complete clarity that, for my group and I, a solemn proclamation of the Charter is not enough.What would the citizens say if they are solemn rights but that they cannot assert them individually?No, I think that would only more like the credibility crisis from which the Union suffers.For all of us, low participation in the European elections should be a sufficient alarm signal.What we need are perceptible rights by all, the charter of fundamental rights must take on a legally binding character for all those who live in the Union, for all citizens.In the interest of the latter, we should work in concert at this objective and I expect from the intergovernmental conference that it reviews the Cologne decision in the matter at the end of the year.Naturally, there is also talk of the effectiveness of decisions and the functioning of institutions in a union expanded to 27 members and more.We will not succeed by a mini-reform such as that envisaged by the Council and that is why it would be necessary to submit all the institutions to the test bench.We must undertake courageous changes while attaching the greatest attention to the balance between large and small member states.I particularly insist as a representative of a large Member State.I thank the commission for the proposals it has advanced and I am convinced that there will be, within this Parliament also, in -depth discussions with the citizens on all the questions they will have raised.I would still like to tackle a last question.The opinion of the Parliament expressly claims changes to the treaty in the field of economic policy.Indeed, economic globalization and above all the introduction of the euro and the supporting stability pact make it necessary to probe the decision -making processes.But that's not all.It is above all necessary to have the courage to carry out a critical examination of the policies carried out so far by the Union.It is a Europe full of social justice.A Europe full of social justice remains more than ever because it is above all a question of placing the fight against mass unemployment and poverty at the center of the policy of the Union.To do this, it is also necessary to have the courage, in my opinion, to modify article 4 of the treaty which defines the Union, in the classic line of neoliberalism, as an open market economy where competition is free as well as article 105 of the CE Treaty, because the European Central Bank must finally respect the mission assigned by the Treaty and which consists in promoting, by its monetary policy, sustainable growth and employment.Mr. President, the Europe of Nations Group considers that the agenda of the next intergovernmental conference, as defined by the Helsinki Council, that is to say strictly centered on issues of decision-making in an enlarged Europe, must be respected.

I wish to praise his thesis of a greater synergy between the institutions, not only between the commission and the parliament, but also between these and the Council, to underline the scope of the political challenge.A larger dialogue is needed, not only among us, but also with civil society.It should be explained more than Europe, we must know how to face fears and anxieties, because in many cases, the greatest fear is precisely fear in itself.Perhaps by promoting dialogue and information we will be able to overcome part of this problem.My group is particularly attracted by the creative possibilities that you have proposed in relation to the white photographer on the theme of the new forms of government that will be presented in the spring.In the face of this Europe as an interconnection of different plans that you have described it is very important that Europe focuses on its fundamental activities, it is important, that is, having the courage to suggest that there are fields in which Europe could perhaps be aside.A similar attitude could convince citizens that Europe, in its forms of government, is not directed exclusively by Brussels, which concentrates and phagocyte more and more powers, decisions and authorities.Here is the political essence of the challenge and it seems to me that today she has well illustrated to this assembly.For my group, the expansion is the first priority on which all the other possibilities of reform must be measured, that they concern the forms of government, the intergovernmental conference or the reform of the institutions.We see the expansion as a partnership process, not as a process that concerns only us and them;The expansion, for us, is an overall gain both for the Member States and for the candidate countries.Allow me to suggest to the Commission, which is the custodian of an extraordinary number of detailed information on the expansion, to present a document that illustrates the value of the expansion, not only in financial and budget terms, but in a broad sense: a document similar to the Cecchini report before the single act, which explains to the citizens, in order to involve them in the debate, that this is the great historical challenge that awaits modern Europe.We must be able to prepare the ground very carefully.Regarding Sudorientale Europe, they agree with you that the value of political institutions is measured on the basis of the results they achieve.During the legislature of the current commission in office and of this parliament we must be able to achieve peace in southeastern Europe, however arduous and complex.We applaud the stabilization and association agreements, but we would also like something more.We will make this material public and present it in the discussion on the SwoBoda report during the week.The strategic document places the emphasis on the global role of the European Union: our central objective must be to attribute to the union, on the global scenario, a weight that is proportional to its weight in terms of aid, commercial and financial flows.At the beginning of this decade we must foresee how our institutions will develop internationally before the end of these ten years, and in particular our role within international monetary bodies, within the United Nations agencies and so on.It is a debate that we must launch.To conclude, this morning, the next day Valentine's Day, the newspapers write that our honeymoon is over.

C50091/1999 as well as SN 5060/1999 - C5-0331/1999 - 1999/0809 (CNS) before the vote Mrs. President, I want to first denounce the absence of the presidency of theof the Council.When dealing with these themes of the third pillar and conventions so important for the construction of a space of freedom, security and justice is not a good thing that is missing the presidency in charge of the Council.In addition, lady president, I have observations to be made on the problem of translations.I will give you only one example, because we don't have much time, but it is a coincidence in which the translations are truly important, being very precise legal concepts.In amendment no.83, in Italian, which is the original language, we read that "the minor must be assisted by a person of his confidence or by an external expert or legal".

This is therefore at least one step forward.The second criticism that we formulate is that the system was too restrictive vis-à-vis the commission.We adopt legislation in the European Union.We expect the commission that it applies them.And from that moment, a system intervenes to hinder the commission and make its work more difficult - in particular, that was the case of the so -called "counter -filet" system, thanks to which the Council could block the Commission through a simple majority, even if the council was unable to find an alternative to the execution measure concerned.In this area also, we are progressing at least somewhat.The Council will no longer be able to block execution measures indefinitely beyond the three-month period, unless a qualified majority has been reached to block the measure, in other words, unless there is substantial opposition among the Member States within the Council.It is a more reasonable system.This is also a step forward.However, with regard to the other two criticisms, we are less satisfied.The first criticism relates to the system by which the Commission is monitored, examined, controlled if you want, by a single committee appointed by the Member States or the Council and not by Parliament.The legislative authorities, namely the Council and the Parliament, should be equal.We confer executive powers to the Commission but only an body appointed by the Council or the Member States can put the off, say no to the Commission and put an end to an execution measure.Parliament does not have equivalent power.It is true that we now see ourselves granting the sketch of such power in this new system.We are supposed to receive all the projects of execution measures sent to a commission at the same time that they are sent to this commission.We will have the opportunity to examine it, debate it and ask questions.However, we will only have the right to challenge the Commission if we believe that it exceeds the powers that we have given it in the legislation.In other words, we can contest the measure in case it exceeds skills but for its content.And in a democracy, parliament should be able to contest the content.I’m not saying that we’re doing so every week.We are not trying to immerse ourselves in execution decisions but the fact that we should have the opportunity to do so the rare times that it is necessary constitutes a democratic safeguard.This is what is missing in this system or, at least, which is only present in an embryonic form.Finally, our fourth criticism is as follows: if an execution measure is blocked through the comitology system, it is returned, not to the two branches of the legislative authority but only towards the council which has the right to take, possibly, an alternative measure.It is not correct.The two branches - Council and Parliament - adopt the legislation which gives execution powers to the Commission.If such execution measures are returned, they should be to both branches and not to one.In general, we have a system that has improved somewhat.The additional aspects arising from the interinstitutional agreement with the Commission are welcome, but that could not change the basic decision of the Council.

The Commission must therefore take on its responsibilities regarding the creation of the strategic framework for the promotion of the capacity for professional insertion and the quality of the work, regarding the evaluation of the results and the effective dissemination of the best practices.Only in this way can the desired multiplier effect be obtained.Mr. President, I would like to intervene on the proposals of the Executive Commission relating to the budget line for information on the PAC.On October 26, 1999, the Commission adopted a proposal to guarantee the legal basis for the budget line relating to the raising awareness of public opinion on Community agricultural policy.Pursuant to this proposal, the current budget line B2-5122 will be abolished in favor of a new item B1-382.The actions that promote understanding between young farmers and the European Union are important, also creating stronger ties with candidate countries and the rest of the world.Therefore I present some amendments to Parliament to support this type of program.Since it is necessary to encourage young farmers to remain in agriculture, it is essential that they are well informed about the developments of common agricultural policy: the information and training of young farmers at European level is fundamental.I ask you to accept that a part of the available budget is intended for the development of knowledge among young European farmers.With regard to information and training, in the past, the budget line was intended for information, communication and training.The executive commission now proposes to exclude training.I believe that training should be included where it involves relevant information on the PAC at European level.European training is an element that serves to guarantee young farmers the necessary knowledge of the PAC to be able to adopt valid decisions regarding their future activities.Therefore I presented three amendments that I ask the Parliament to approve.Mr. President, I take the floor to express, on the basis of the experience gained in a municipal administration, the opportunity, but I would almost dare to say the need, that the projects of the Urban program are oriented in a triple direction: first of all, to encourage the recovery of infrastructure and historical neighborhoods, old and perhaps degraded.Secondly, facilitate and stimulate economic activities and social life within these historic centers, within these corners of "old city".What are those streets for, today perhaps illuminated with taste, with redone sidewalks, complete with tile pavement, splendid in their nore, if we are not able to fill them with activities and therefore employment?And I want to clarify that here it is not a question of financing or assisting different social categories, but rather of knowing how to discern the employment vocation in the projects to be selected, or, but it is the same thing, to select projects that manage to encourage the creation of work and the initiatives on the subject, to confer them more momentum.Thirdly, but perhaps I should have said first, the projects must be aimed mainly at the total recovery of people and families, because man does not exist to serve the right, but it is the right that exists to serve man.

The Pes will never be nothing more than the comparison of the national interests that have already taken hold of the system: how can we not see that it is the union between London and Berlin supported by the respective complicit and that they do not conceive their diplomacy in terms of autonomy from Washington, carving out the role of extras.On the other hand, high representative Solana, she is a living example of this connivance, so to speak structural: she has gone from NATO to Pes without discontinuity, as if it were the same thing, and in reality it is.It is always a question of serving the empire.I cannot deny some fun in hearing it to invoke this delicious and at the same time persuasive argument in the ridiculous competition that opposes it to Commissioner Patten.In any case, she told a German journalist: "The Americans call me".High representative Solana, he could have added: "It is to me that the orders pass", because this is our observation.In the Balkans and elsewhere, the Americans one day ask us to destroy and then ask us to reconstruct.Honorable Martinez was fully reasoned to interrupt it, honorable Cohn-Bendit, it is still servility.You think I am excessive!Not a day passes that the reality of the facts does not provide us with additional evidence of our subjection.Echelon is one of the many examples and offers an image of Europe that is very different from what we like to paint here.Experts speak of a cultural problem, personally I find them very funny.On behalf of the coordination of the European rights, I have to tell them, Mr. High Representative for common foreign policy and security, which she does not enjoy our trust.He says he is against war, but as NATO Secretary General has triggered one.It was an offensive war, in the servile respect of American politics in an area that does not fall within the Treaty of the North Atlantic, against a state that had never been part of it, that did not constitute any threat to international borders, a security policy aims to safeguard the security of the Member States of the Union.How can we believe it?Or perhaps you recognize these states the right to intervene in every part of the world?Secondly, in the latter hypothesis, which rules of international law and political morality do you refer to?I already imagine his answer: humanitarian law.In Kosovo we have systematically destroyed all Serbian civil infrastructures in the name of humanitarian law.When the US cause the death of 2,000 people in Panama, it was certainly not to impose their policy, it was to fight drug trafficking.

So, on behalf of my group, I express a favorable opinion on the Theato report;However, I believe that it is basically a topic to be enrolled on the agenda of the cig.Mr. President, the report of the honorable Theato on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union, proposes in particular and at first, to centralize criminal actions through a European prosecutor.This proposal is decidedly contrary to the spirit of the current system in which criminal law and criminal procedure, which are the pivot of national legal systems, must depend on the sovereignty of each people and are the exclusive competence of each state.The idea of ​​a European prosecutor aims instead, as regards this matter, to relegate states in a subordinate role.In addition, this proposal would take a series of absolutely unpredictable reforms.In fact, according to the report of the honorable Theato, the European prosecutor would be necessary, in particular, to frame the investigations of the urgent to defend its quality.But equally essential is to keep in mind that the components of the water policy are inseparable and the action in that aspect conditions all others.Now, in the debate and in the proposals there has been preference to the theme "Physical-chemical and ecological quality of water" and almost only marginally the perverse effects on the remaining dimensions have been taken into account.Thus, it is necessary to take into account the diversity of the realities of the Member States, the climatic specificities, the hydrological regimes and their variations throughout the We will start a large and open consultation process in order to collect the opinions of all the different parties concerned.I consider the process almost as important as the content;We will dedicate all our resources to active participation and invite all interested parties to participate.At the same time, we have also started a process aimed at improving consistency and clarifying, bringing to the surface and making manifest the real or imaginary problems that we encounter in this area.It will be a continuous process that I consider a kind of constant quality control and I invite Parliament to take part in order to improve the consistency of our actions.Mr. President, I first want to thank the President in office for the Amado Council for what he said, as well as the Commissioner Nielson.I am pleased that President Amado spoke of the European Development Fund.The resolution of the problem does not depend on this institution, on the European Parliament, nor on the Commission;Rather, it is up to the Council to take the initiative to provide the Fest of its budget, and therefore it is to the Council that the preaching must be addressed.Mr. President, I also thank Commissioner Nielson, who spoke widely of the new Lomé Convention.This convention, however, is not exactly the topic that we deal with this morning.In reality, it was our intention to speak of consistency: this is the real theme of today.Already at the beginning of the nineties, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council recognized that the degree of consistency of the union policies was not satisfactory, in particular in the sector of development cooperation and in other aspects of European politics.Several times, attention has been solicited for this problem: in 1992, in 1995 and 1997. The resolution we are examining summarized a bit all the attempts made in this regard in the past.I have already proposed questions about this problem as already years.In 1997 the obligation to consistency was even included in the Treaty of Amsterdam and then, in 1998, it was decided that the European Commission would draw up an annual report on the progress made.But what happened since then?We have heard many beautiful words, even this morning, but we have not yet seen any relationship.It almost seems absurd to say, but it is like this: it is widely recognized that the union policy is contradictory, good intentions are constantly formulating, but nothing happens in fact.It is therefore a good thing that this point is today at our agenda.To explain what are the contradictions of the union policy I will resort to some examples.In some developing countries, sugar cane is grown to obtain sugar from it.In the union the sugar is instead obtained from beets.To prevent sugar from a good price from developing countries to compete with the most expensive sugar in the Union, a heavy tax on cane sugar imports has been imposed.Consequently, the imports of this product in the union have dropped considerably.At the same time, to those same countries that produce brown sugar, we provide development aid in large quantities.Once, a minister of a Caribbean island where the sugar cane was grown had to tell me: if you allow us to sell our sugar in the union, we could safely do without your development aid.

In view of the attitude that we took in Seattle, I am surprised to implement the silence of the failure of the EU to implement the calibration of trade, which had already been decided for developing development aid is also provided by the Member States.Member States' policy must not contradict the Commission's Politics.The commission delegations in developing countries are responsible for playing a leading role in the development of this political dialogue and ensuring that all countries control the same course.Particular attention must also be paid to the means of production.Far too often, My second question refers to Africa, which, in contrast to all other continents, is also not mentioned in Shaping the New Europe.In Africa we have most refugees in the world, the greatest poverty and a devastating AIDSepidemia.I know that Commissioner Nielson and others do a good job in this area, but the entire commission must, even in its strategic goals, focus more on this continent.Finally, I can be underlined that I welcome the commission to explain the first time that the EU is ready to take one -sided measures in order to grant developing countries more access to our markets.My question is: When will this be done?President, Mr President of the Commission, venerated colleagues, lies a document in front of us that is of crucial importance for the future and fate of Europe.For us, however, an immediate challenge mean two aspects under all the points mentioned that are closely interwoven: peace and stability in Europe and outside of Europe.These goals must primarily be pursued, which has long been our common endeavor, but we also have to make it clear that they cannot be achieved without the expansion - may they also cause costs.We are called today to choose between one less enough for the coming decades, but for the entire planet a lamp of peace and civilization Europe and a perhaps richer Europe without future visions.However, these goals can only be realized if, in the end of the government conference that ended in one year, a constitutional reform takes shape in the context of which the commission, which may not be an executor of the decisions of the council or the co -decisions of the parliament, but must also take on the role of a real government of Europe, adequate and real powers are transferred.Parliament would have to be the first proponent of this reform if it really wants to expand its role as the mouthpiece of the Union citizens' will and take over the central function of how it stands for a really democratic and strongly integrated Union.In addition, the Commission can only stand within the framework of the powers actually transferred to it for the obligations taken over.Without these perspectives, Europe would look forward to a hopeless future.President, Mr, Mr President, we can only welcome the announced ambitious goals that are in line with the challenges before Europe.As I state, the fall of the Berlin Wall is the most important event for you at the end of this century.This event forms the basis for the expansion.However, I would prefer this word "extension" and rather speak of reunification, because this seems to me to have much stronger political importance.They take up the idea of ​​concentrating their work more on the core tasks, and make this a goal of their reforms.Basically, it is about the use of the principle of subsidiarity.The clear application of this principle can only increase the measures carried out and convey a clear idea of ​​any level of responsibility to the citizens.Yes, Mr. Prodi, to announce this is one thing to carry out it completely different!

As in Spain, in April 1998, as in Brittany and Vandea since last December, an exceptional natural zone is seriously threatened.In its resolutions, the European Parliament does not cease to attract attention to this kind of dangers that threaten our environment, upset our ecosystem and destabilize populations again.This new catastrophe poses the problem of the integration of the community "collection" in environmental matters for candidate countries.The obstacles that the authorities of these states must overcome, still fragile from the environmental point of view, are numerous.First, the prevention of this type of discharge should be improved, conditioning the most critical industrial locations.Secondly, these countries should be able to have sufficient technical means to stop such pollution and reduce their scope.Finally, they should be able to apply recovery programs of the most affected and most sensitive areas.Today the banks and the waters of more than four rivers that cross four states are contaminated.That is why the European Union must concentrate its efforts and exercise its pressures so that all candidate countries necessarily adapt to community environmental protection standards.But above this, what is in question are technologies and the means available to prevent and to deal quickly and effectively to this type of catastrophes.I want our future partners to demonstrate greater responsibility.The environment must be a priority within the framework of the reunification of the European continent.It must be the core of the political wills of our partners.The application of high environmental standards will allow not only the development of important industrial and technological sectors, but also will simultaneously carry favorable social and economic consequences and improve public health standards.You have to reinforce the efforts already undertaken.The European continent must express its solidarity and responsibilities must be clearly delimited within the framework of the principle "who pollutes pays."Mr. President, when the Catastrophe of Doñana occurred, the World World Wide Fund - World for Nature - presented a report on the amount of rafts in Europe of these characteristics.We all know that there is a huge number of this type of rafts, which are an ecological bomb and that affect the supply of drinking water, ecological wealth and also to the economic future of these areas.I was in Doñana after the spill and I could see how agriculture, fishing and life of the citizens of the surrounding area looked greatly compromised.Therefore, I believe that the European Union must, in the first place, an analysis of the situation of these rafts and a rigorous record of the number of them we have in Europe.You must proceed to the inclusion of these rafts in community law, in the directives that have to do with the waste, and use the prevention principle to prevent this from happening again.If not, we will be continuously endangering the ecological wealth of our continent.Mr. President, this catastrophe in the Romania mine includes a vast hydrogeological sector with rivers and streams in Romania, Hungary, Serbia and Bulgaria.The discharge in the ecosystem of 100,000 m3 of water contaminated with cyanide and heavy metals will have huge consequences, for a long time, for the inhabitants of these regions, for flora and fauna, for agriculture, for tourism and for the entire ecosystem and biological diversity.

It should be remembered that during the Conference on Rural Development which was held in Cork from November 7 to 9, 1996, rural development was defined as one of the priorities of the European Union, insofar as it is essential to preserve the integrity of our agriculture and the whole of the rural fabric (infrastructure, public and private services ....).In this context, we have deplored in commission of credits devoted to rural development and supported the amendments requesting an increase in the budget for this community initiative, so that it is in line with the previous leaders leader I and Leader II.Compared to this latest initiative which had a period limited to 6 years, the budget allocated to leader +, for a period of 7 years, is 50 %.This is not eligible with regard to the importance of rural development and the consequences, for farmers, the fall in prices and aids such as it is planned in the reform of the CAP following the Berlin agreements.Finally, among the priority parameters which will be introduced on the European scale to allow local inscriptions, special attention must be paid to the quality and originality of projects which have already been carried out by GAL within the framework of Leader II initiative, but which could not succeed due to the calendar and the heaviness of the planned management devices.(The session, suspended at 1:40 p.m., is resumed at 3 p.m.) Additives in animal feed The agenda calls for the report (A5-0015/2000) of Mr. Graefe Zu Baringdorf, in the name of the Commission for Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a directive of the Council modifying the 70/524/EEC directive in the additives in the food of animals (1999) 388 -388 -C5-0134/1999 - 1999/0168 (CNS)).Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner byrne, Directive 70/524 currently provides for different treatments for high -tech additives in the replacement of existing authorizations.The Commission now proposes to harmonize the procedures of authorization, so that the substances which have been authorized before 1988 are set up with equality with that which is authorized now.In this regard, the Commission for Agriculture and Rural Development is in agreement.However, the directive also includes the authorization of antibiotics, other drug substances, growth factors and genetically modified organisms.It is about health here and not a simple harmonization of legislation.The Agriculture Commission is therefore of the opinion that the legal basis - Article 37 - is not eligible here and that the Commission must rather offer us a legal basis based on article 152, which provides for the codecision of Parliament.We asked for the advice of our legal committee, which indicated, concerning this harmonization of legislation, that article 37 would suffice in this case.We, the Commission for Agriculture,, however, were not limited to the treatment of this harmonization of legislation;We have filed another amendment, given the fact that this proposal also relates to genetically modified organizations, and this amendment addresses the question of content and also, therefore, the health of the population.We have negotiated two years with the Commission for the seed directive and we found a compromise that governs the dissemination of genetically modified organizations in this directive.To do this, we started from the basic text for this 70/524 directive.Mr. Byrne, we do not understand why the commission undertakes harmonizations and does not also provide for the harmonization of the text concerning genetically modified organisms.

"info-rich" and "low-info" countries, to prevent the origin of companies in which the digital breaks are the new social breaks after the apt expression of my friend Claude Desama.The annual corresponding special parliamentary debate.Above all, we are concerned with evidence that every new proposal has been examined in detail whether it withstands the principles of subsidiarity and procedure according to which this decisive program document is developed and discussed is subjected to general overhaul.Mr President, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for talking to us twice within 24 hours.Yesterday evening he clearly and clearly stated that the prospects for the European economy are very positive for the next two to three years and that the unexpectedly above -average growth rates will make it easier for us to achieve the goals of this annual legislative program.In his contribution from this morning, the Commission President appeals three problems that make me worry.The first concerns the subsidiarity, in which our faction exists very much, and the liberals have already referred to the fact that it must be demonstrated for each individual proposal that it is in the interests of Europe.

The deputy rightly refers to the strategic importance of these regions.We take part in programs in the region that also affect the environment.There is a direct connection between our food programs and structural reforms in agriculture and the relief of poverty.These programs themselves are intended to help agriculture to receive a more solid basis and to stop predatory construction.We should continue to grant this ecological aspect priority in the future.We also take note of the fact that the MP who wrote the request has applauded the answer of the Commissioner.This is not common.In addition, the Lord has not cited a bibliography in this case.Thank you very much, Mr. Patten, for your today's contributions.Inquiry No. 35 of (H-0778/99): Concerns: Greek Action Plan for Employment According to the results of the evaluation of the action plans for employment, Greece and Italy are the most affected countries of critical comments from the Commission, both with regard to the inconsistency of plans as well as the measures and policies to support employment.The report indicates that in Greece and Italy the goals to improve the "employment ability" have not been achieved and it is uncertain whether the politics to be carried out are sufficient to prevent and combat long -term unemployment.With regard to Greece, it is also pointed out that there is no program for medium and long-term measures to reduce tax burdens and social security contributions in the area of ​​employment and for the satisfactory use of the ESF to support employment policy, and that there are also no exact employment figures.Can the Commission report whether the Greek government has adopted concrete obligations b and which B with regard to the way the problem of youth unemployment and long -term unemployment can be managed and whether it has set and implemented a suitable system for localization, registration and control of the fluctuation of unemployment or whether most measures are still limited to listing unemployment?To the request of Mr. Papayannakis: As part of the 1999 package of measures, the Commission has directed certain recommendations to Greece in order to make the measures to promote employment more efficient.These recommendations essentially suggest that more intensive efforts to reform public services in problem areas to improve the system of statistical recording and to apply preventive policies in accordance with guidelines 1 and 2 of the employment package.In the course of its employment policy, the Greek government announced two concrete programs in 1999: "Yes to professional life" and "Back in Work".Since there are no final results for these programs, we cannot first make a statement about whether the quantitative goals have been achieved.The Greek government now admits that there is a problem in that it is not possible to grasp the fluctuation of unemployment.It has therefore committed itself to, firstly, to restructure the state employment offices, secondly to create efficient centers for employment promotion - a corresponding program has started, but has not yet been completed - and thirdly, to introduce electronic employment cards and use suitable computer systems in order to be able to pursue the implementation of all of these policies.

It is about strengthening banking supervision.It is about clarifying liability for transactions.It is about a regulatory framework at the international level.It is about a review of national laws whether they correspond to the rules of the Basel Committee and how they can be spread more.In the present resolution, I have a major problem in a central point, which we cannot accept.This is point 9. If we have now listened to the Commissioner, we know that the commission's expertise will lead to a no to Tobin Tax.If the expertise and this debate and the arguments are as we do and how I think it is right, but then the Commission is also responsible for a further six months and thus an uncertainty of the financial and capital market.The capital market does not need uncertainty from us, the capital market needs clarity from us.Therefore, we reject point 9 and call for a separate vote.Mrs. President!The debate about taxing short -term financial transactions is not new.We have been discussing the Tobin tax proposal for twenty years, and yet this question is always up to date, because we need really concrete and honest answers on the basis of careful studies.We need to know how desirable and how feasible a taxation of short -term financial transactions is actually.This question is indeed in a different dimension today when $ 1,500 billion around the world vagabonds for 24 hours a day in search of attractive systems, and at most 3% of them are associated with the real economy.We worry about the stability of the financial markets, not for the sake of financial markets, but because it is also about our own growth, our own investments, our own jobs in the European Union.Here we have to ask which instruments we can use in order to actually create a certain order here that has been missing so far.We have contributed to the liberalization of the financial transactions, but we still have no functioning set of rules, and we have had to experience the bitterly in the effects of the Asia crisis and the Latin America crisis.It is therefore high time that on the one hand we think of supervisory rules and on the other hand of transparency on the financial markets and their information.It is important that we know which actors exist and what credit ratings they have.We also have to ask ourselves whether there is a commandment of tax justice.At a time when the tax burden on the factor work across Europe, but also internationally, we have to consider which forms we come to efficient taxation of capital gains in, and we also have to ask ourselves the question about the taxation of short -term financial transactions.I really think it is necessary that we will receive a careful report and a conclusion from the Commission so that we as a European Parliament can see whether we do not have to ensure that the European Union, together with the USA and Japan, really gets international solidarity in order to make the economy and the financial markets more stable and safer.

Consequently, without such an active role in the "development" council in the global coordination of political decisions that develop on the sidelines of its decision -making center and directly affect the development policy of the European Union, it will certainly be difficult to develop a more coherent policy of the European Union compared to the development objectives.The speech and reflection of the European Parliament will certainly be appropriate and welcome here too.Let me start by saying a few words about the negotiations between the EU and the ACP countries that have successfully concluded.I would like to point out that participating in these negotiations was a very positive experience.I saw member states working as a team, a great experience indeed.The two parties were deeply satisfied at the end of the negotiations, not only because they had ended, but also because we all knew that we had accomplished something together, the EU and the 71 ACP countries.The world needs this and the signal sent is very positive as part of the general discussion on globalization.I will highlight some of the new features contained in this new agreement.We explicitly approach the question of corruption;We establish a framework in order to deal with the problem of immigration, for the very first time.We encourage participatory approaches, we ensure that civil society is consulted on the reforms and policies that the EU must support.We again focus development policies on poverty reduction strategies.We are not only based on the allocation of funds on an evaluation of the needs of each country, but also on an assessment of their performance in terms of policy.We create an investment system to support the development of the private sector.We rationalize the instruments and introduce a new rotating programming system that allows the community and beneficiary countries to regularly adjust their cooperation program.We decentralize administrative and sometimes financial responsibilities at local levels in order to improve cooperation.We improve the political framework for the development of trade and investments.We are strengthening cooperation in all sectors that are of commercial importance, including new points such as labor standards and links between the environment and trade.After Seattle, I am sure you will realize the meaning of these agreements.I now go to some of the more important points.First, the agreement concerning political issues.The new agreement will imply a firm commitment on the part of the two parties in terms of good management of the government as a fundamental and positive element of the partnership, a subject having to be the subject of a regular dialogue in a sector which benefits from the active support of the community.Second, a new procedure has been conceived in the event of human rights violations, democratic principles and the rule of law.In comparison with the current procedure, the new procedure puts more emphasis on the responsibility of the state concerned and it allows greater flexibility in the consultation process, in order to carry out a productive dialogue leading to measures to be taken in order to redress the situation.In the event of a particular emergency, namely serious violations of one of these fundamental elements, measures will be taken immediately and notification will be made to the other party.

Certainly, an effective competition policy constitutes the premise of a proper functioning of the internal market and the economic and monetary union.However, as the rapporteur indicates, these aid are sometimes indispensable and can allow, in addition to the survival of some companies, to contribute to sustainable development (article 6 of the Treaty), to services of general interest (article 16) and economic and social cohesion (article 158).However, it is clear that they must be controlled and this task looms the European Commission.The aid that the Member States of the Union dedicate to the sectors considered every year have reached, in the period 1995-1997, a total of 95 billion euros, of which 40 percent for the manufacturing sector.These aid decreased considerably compared to the previous period, 1993-1995, (decrease in 13 percent of the total amount and from 3.8 to 2.6 percent of the amount dedicated to aid for the manufacturing sector).This drop in aid is explained above all with the decrease in the aid granted to the new German Länder.Like the rapporteur, I also deplore that the data presented in the report do not include all state aid.The European Commission must remedy as quickly as possible to these deficiencies.It must also cooperate with the Member States to improve the quality of data in time, that is, for the ninth census.It would be a good thing that the Commission published a register in which the amounts of state aid by member country are entitled.It also deploes that the European Parliament is totally excluded from the Consultative Committee for state aid.To remedy this situation, the European Commission must take on the obligation to present us regular relationships.I will conclude on an aspect of the use of state aid that seems particularly dangerous to me: these are aid that result in a transfer of business from one Member State to the other, with the risk of hunting to subsidies without them being able to contribute to the achievement of the common objectives of the EU.For this reason I hope that in the next census of state aid there is the evaluation of the impact of these aid on employment as well as on the sectors of industry and crafts in the beneficiaries.Langen Report (A5-0073/1999) this morning, in the context of the important discussion on the competition, I expressed myself on the text of the honorable Langen concerning the application in 1998 of the sixth code of the aid to the steelurgery.As has been recognized by the Court of Justice in its sentence of 3 May 1996, the steel sector is particularly sensitive to competitive disturbances.Therefore, it was legitimate to establish a regime of state aid to this sector in order to guarantee the survival of valid companies, although article 4, point C, of ​​the Czech treaty, prohibits any state aid to steel.This is, in reality, the theme of the sixth aid code to the steel industry.At the same time, of course, it is essential to avoid any threat to the conditions of competition and any serious disturbance of the markets and from this derives the importance of regulating these aid.It is therefore necessary to continue to give state aids only to research, development, protection of the environment and aid granted in the event of the closure of the plants.

Madam President, I would also like to applaud the initiative that the Commission had to present a report to us on its strategic objectives for the next five years, although I hope that it intends to correct, in subsequent documents, the excess of generalities and the imprecision of the text that we analyze today.That said, the president, I will again denounce the absence of the fishing policy, even if I am hardly listening to me.It is really surprising that the Commission does not place among its strategic objectives for the coming years the process of revising one of its common policies for the reform which must take place in 2002. This revision process is, without the shadow of a doubt, the most important event of those who will affect the fishing sector for many years.But, at first glance, this is not the opinion of the Commission, which is responsible for presenting to the Council and Parliament, before the end of 2001, the report on the functioning of the common fishing policy in the last decade, on the basis of which the Council will have to make the adequate decisions to modify it.In fact, the revision process has already started for many groups and institutions, as for the European Parliament which, in 1998, had already dictated and approved a report incorporating all the problems and faults that the common fishing policy currently includes.We have repeatedly asked for a minimum calendar for this revision but we did not obtain an answer.Less than two years, it is not much if we recall more that the fishing policy is experiencing an anomal situation with regard to internal market standards and that a solution should be found in these anomalies within the framework of the reform procedure.Consequently, the president, Mr. Chairman of the Commission, I request that this point, which is of paramount importance for such an important sector of the European Union, is taken into consideration in this strategy and in these strategic objectives for the next five years.Madam President, I also wish to address my congratulations to the Prodi Commissioner for her program.I am particularly delighted that it has recognized this virtuous circle that constitutes sustained growth: the information company within a European expansion market with, moreover, an effective single currency will give us the opportunity to really develop prosperity, the spirit of innovation, the business spirit and, yes - the most important element - of sustainable jobs with very high added value for European citizens.I have an observation, not a criticism, to formulate with regard to the declaration of this morning of the prodist commissioner, namely that she was a little weak on the real content of economic policy.We must not consider anything acquired with regard to the way of achieving the restructuring of the European economy.After all, what is social justice without full employment?Full employment is the best way to achieve social justice for our citizens.It is for us a fundamental priority on which we must concentrate our efforts.

This is the proof, if it was still necessary, that an immature diplomacy, which defends no interest, except undoubtedly particular interests, stuck between the theology of free trade, the pressure as an obstacle to international free trade by theologians of Geneva and Washington.This was an opportunity to recall that our mode of cooperation with the countries of the South, original and exemplary, was to be developed, reinforced.This opportunity is an opportunity missed by the Corrie report and, with regret, we must sanction the fact that it has been lost to this point.Mr. President, as a conclusion and synthesis, I would like to highlight three essential aspects of this debate.First, the idea that emerges very firmly from all interventions is that globalization accentuates regional imbalances and social inequalities, that it increases poverty.It is therefore necessary to do something, under penalty of aggravating tensions and bringing out mechanisms triggering conflicts that call into question international peace and stability.Second, in this perspective, it would be important to give another dimension to development policies by valuing their role in the correction of imbalances, attenuation of inequalities.I think everyone agrees with the capital importance of the European Union role in development policies on an international scale.Everyone recognizes, such was the theme of today's debate, that the European Union assumes a more active and advanced role in development policies on an international scale, it will necessarily have to strengthen the coherence of its various policies which participate in development objectives.I think that certain interventions have also insisted that this responsibility vis-à-vis the coherence of European Union policies does not include exclusively on the Council, the Commission or the Parliament;On the contrary, it will have to be the subject of a consultation of the work of reflection and legislative and institutional preparation, both at the level of the Commission and at the level of the Council, as well as at the level of the European Parliament itself.Some deputies have also presented suggestions, such as that of the creation of an observatory or a working group to support the action of the various policies in the specific field of development.As was one of the priorities of the Portuguese are not able to give a leading role to development policies as an instrument for the affirmation of principles and values ​​that model Europe's assertion in the international system.

The season risks going to loss and giving rise to a very serious crisis at the end of the year.It was therefore fully justified that Parliament developed a new resolution to which our group has provided an extremely important contribution, a resolution that emphasizes on some points considered absolutely essential by those who operate on the field.First of all, those who pollute must take all their responsibilities.Our resolution therefore asks for the application of two principles: in the first place, that of the "pollutes cleans", because it is not admissible that the reclamation of the coasts polluted by a load of hydrocarbons will not be carried out at the expense of the load owner, but at the expense of public bodies, namely taxpayers or, to say better, the victims.Secondly, there is the principle of "who pollutes".Its responsibility, specifies our resolution, must extend to the sectors and companies in the fishing sector, marine culture and aquaculture.This aspect is essential and means that anyone who pollutes cannot pretend to limit the amount of compensation for victims based on the roof set by the fipp due to the kind concession of large oil companies.If the roof of the fipol is insufficient, if it is clearly underestimated, it is necessary to raise it.Well, our resolution requires it.If the increase is insufficient, those who have polluted will have to finance the rest.It would be particularly unfair to allow an oil company, whose profits this year are around ten billion francs, denying complete compensation to the victims, whose vast majority consists of small companies and employees.The populations tried, Mr. Commissioner, expect concrete signs of solidarity at European level.Our resolution asks the commission to adopt the necessary measures to contribute to the repair of the damage inflicted on the fishing sector, affected by the consequences of the catastrophe.Blue Europe, PCP, must today show that, beyond the constraints it imposes on fishermen, solidarity is not an unknown feeling and the European Union must also participate in the environmental recovery of the wetlands and the affected coastal areas, whose biological value affects the union as a whole.Commissioner Fischler has just affirmed that he would welcome France's requests and please me.In the fundamental chapter of marine pollution, we must play a spur role.Twenty years after the catastrophe of the Amoco Cadiz, in Europe in the field of maritime security they continue to reign undisturbed laxism and irresponsibility, with the repercussions that derive from it, that is, the repetition of black tides.This time we must not let the inertia have the better.We must quickly define a general framework on maritime safety in compliance with the principle of subsidiarity and we must finally put an end to this infernal spiral of generalized irresponsibility.Mr. President, the economy of the western Atlantic is disastrous, contaminated by the Erika Nafta.Fishermen, oystercolors, mollusch growers, tourism operators, local and territorial authorities are frozen in waiting for aid and a treatment of the wreck which, as they tell us, continues to cause escape and constitutes a real delayed burst bomb.

Mr. President, the question asked by Mr. Karamanou is an extremely serious question, it must be said.We are fully aware of the humanitarian situation, difficult and dramatic, of Kosovo as well as from the problem of people displaced in the region, which come from Kosovo, with the repercussions that this leads in particular to the health of children and mortality rates.It is obvious to me that the European Union has clearly contributed to the efforts of humanitarian aid in the international community.As you know, the European Community has brought a total of 378 million euros only to the province of Kosovo, to which the national contributions of the various Member States must be added.This contribution covers various projects in the fields of health and the health system, as well as in that of water sanitation.In addition, as you know, the European Union makes a contribution to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which amounted to 66.3 million euros in 1999. I think that the honorable deputy knows that given the necessary division of labor between international donors, the health sector in Kosovo returns to the World Health Organization.This organization is fully aware, according to the reports it has written, of the alarming situation concerning the health of children.She focused her efforts on improving basic conditions in maternity and hospitals.However, we are aware that this situation is far from being satisfactorily resolved;that it has a dynamic and a dimension which also affects other areas of health, which is more of the health of children.It is a situation of a political nature, it is not a simply technical situation, it concerns the solution of the political situation because there are dimensions here, which should not be hidden, which are reflected according to what is, until today, the inability of the international community to put into practice the functioning of a multi -thnical society in Kosovo, which has had harmful effects on the improvement of the health system in this region.Thank you, Mr. Chairman of the Council, for your answer which completes the remarks that he said yesterday on the subject of Commissioner Patten.However, Mr. President, the amount of 378 million euros, which you say he was allocated in 1999, proved to be completely insufficient for the creation of elementary human conditions in Kosovo, in particular with regard to the granting of health services.Do you not think, Mr. Chairman of the Council, that the mere fact that infantile mortality has increased constitutes for the European continent a withered, a shame which should all mobilize us, so that the aid that we bring is more effective and generous?Admittedly, the situation was not idyllic before the bombings, so much need, but it has been very clearly degraded since NATO intervention with regard to the natural environment and the human environment.Under these conditions, Mr. Chairman of the Council, is it not a question of moral order to strive to create human conditions for the residents so proven in Kosovo, and especially to hold all the promises we have made?

And if we let a group of high -level officials act as a node for exchanges of experiences for the coordination and evaluation of social policy and the labor market, we will not be able to learn.The communication of the Commission, of which we discuss today, and which constituted the starting point for the Council's decision in November, provides a balanced exposure that explains how we can have a more qualified debate, as we can know more about the challenges with which the member countries will compare in the social policy sector in the coming years, years in which we will have populations who age and we will feel the effects of expansion.We already have today great social problems and high social expenses that weigh on public budgets, which for many member countries constitutes a problem.If the reforms are not started, we risk eroding the economic basis of social policy, and a strong and competitive economy is certainly the safest basis for good social protection.It is therefore reasonable to insert these themes in the agenda.In the debate on the coordination of social policy within the European Union, we often use the expression "social convergence".We liberals can be favorable to the concept of social convergence when it comes to defining, within the European Union, large common objectives that countries try to achieve through national social policy.It is therefore not a question of harmonization, but of common objectives.It is a fact: the countries of the European Union have different ways of organizing social policy.We have different traditions, there are cultural differences and, despite many points in common, there are between one country and the other also great differences in the nature of social problems and in their reach.For this, it is important to underline that social policy constitutes a question of national competence.National policy cannot naturally be subtracted from a series of common references that concern minimum social rights, established in the treaty, the guarantee of the free movement of labor without loss of its social rights, respect for the need to coordinate economies and respect for economic cooperation.Coordination and cooperation are therefore necessary.Convergence, however, must be an end and not a means.I also wish to thank the speaker, honorable Jan Andersson, for his very constructive commitment aimed at trying to reconcile different positions and ensure support for his relationship.I support the relationship.However, there are some points on which I do not completely agree.I do not agree with the request by virtue of which the Commission should intervene against what is called unfair competition between social and tax systems, if this intervention must be used to curb the new ideas, the development and improvement of the efficiency of our social systems, or to hinder the reduction of too high a tax burden in many member countries of the European Union.I am skeptical regarding the detailed regulation to which the commission could be reached against the scope and quality of childhood assistance and the elderly, as they are skeptical regarding the advantage of a common poverty threshold.

This does not interest the large groups of this Parliament, nor the major part of the unions, which in theory have in the defense of the European public service but which, in practice, focus on the corporate protection of their own registrants, using in questionable way the great powers which are granted to them.Union representatives are part of the disciplinary council and the status committee, so that the unfaithful civil servant risks nothing and to freeze the status.Union representatives are also part, and it is incomprehensible, juries of competition, and I would not be surprised if members of the union were already part of the Olaf, which would seriously harm this institution which should, at least formally, offer the guarantee of being super parts.So I understand why we meet at this hour, which is usually intended for other activities and not for debate, confrontation and information.Mr. President, when it comes to internal reform, the European Commission is in embarrassment.After the cases that prompted the previous commission to resign, the expectations are enormous.I sometimes have the impression that the proposals made within this assembly are all the more applauded as they are radical.On the other hand, the circumstances cannot be modified by a pen of the day overnight.As soon as it is a question of putting things to work, as soon as we must discuss on a few points of detail, we quickly see the difficulties arise.This is undoubtedly the reason why the budget control commission had to face more difficulties than expected on this point.However, we do not have to be ashamed of the result as it presents itself to you today.On this occasion, I would like to thank the colleague Van Hulten for the work he has accomplished on this report.If this report manages not to be once again watered down by the adoption of several amendments, it will make it possible to send the Commission for clear instructions and without detours on several determining points.Let's start with the most important education.We do not want to remove financial control.The financial controller must still have the possibility of doing his job before payments are done, not in all circumstances but in cases where uncertainties and risks exist.The Commission is launching a bad signal when it renames the Directorate General for Financial Control in general audit direction.The commission organization chart can easily be changed, but the task becomes more difficult when it is necessary to stick to the laws and, in this specific case, to the financial regulations.I did not carry out an exhaustive census, but the financial regulations of the community and the execution provisions which relate to it evoke in more hundred different passages the financial controller, its independence and the tasks assigned to it.These regulations cannot be ignored or bypassed, not even via a so-called soft law, as evoked by a colleague during a session in committee.

President, honorable deputies, commissioners and members of the Commission for Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, I was commissioned to draw up the European Parliament report on the Interreg III Community initiative program.In the parliamentary commission we have examined more than one hundred amendments and so far 17 have been re -proposed, some of which already presented in the commission.Before moving on to the discussion of the content of the resolution I propose, I wish to make you know the elements I took into consideration and that have guided my work as a speaker.First of all, I would like to remind you of the role of the Interreg Community initiative, founded on the principle of transnationality and innovation.This program constitutes a European development and size engine.Interreg is part of the four community initiatives scheduled for the period 2000-2006 and will have the most consistent financial package, i.e. 4,875 billion euros against the current 3,604 billion.Created in 1990, the Interreg initiative finds its prerequisite in the desire to prepare the European regions for Europe without borders in the field of the realization of the large single market.With the reform of the structural funds of 1994 and 1996, the Pic Interreg introduced new elements that contribute to the development of the transe European networks of transport and energy distribution.These programs have encouraged cross -border, transnational and interregional cooperation of the European Union by favoring a balanced development of the community space.The Interreg III program, of which the European Commission submit the guidelines to our exam, in accordance with the provisions of Regulation n.1260/1999 of the European Community concerning the general on territorial structure, transport and environment networks;The realization of this element falls under the responsibility of the Member States and the national authorities;and the CE In intended to
