Member States must act promptly and firmly.Our governments must put together financial resources to guarantee effective controls and must stop dragging each initiative on maritime safety for long.The tragedy of Erika did not have a cost in terms of human lives, but could have destroyed the existence of many, such as the Sea Empress or the Braer.What is certain is that all three accidents caused an ecological disaster.My group is solidarity with the inhabitants of Brittany, whose region was devastated by the disaster, just as on other occasions we were solidarity with the inhabitants of Western Wales and the Shetland islands.It would be time to stop manifesting our solidarity and instead begin to release mandatory mandates to eliminate these ships of shame in favor of safe seas, otherwise, during the year we will find ourselves again discussing a new resolution proposal for the sinking of another cistern ship charging the convenient flag that infesters the sea of ​​crude.The time of resolutions has passed: now it's the time to act.Unfortunately, I fear that the advice will also remain inactive this time and we will return to the future to discuss a new maritime and ecological disaster.Mr. President, every time there is a disaster like this is said that he must never repeat himself again.In reality we cannot prevent accidents at sea, but it is our duty to learn from any accident like this and put into practice the lessons learned to reduce future risks.The Erika accident was serious above all for the inhabitants of Brittany more directly affected, but had devastating effects on the wildlife of most of Europe.According to some sources, there would be the worst disaster that the birds of this European region has ever hit;According to the Royal Society for the protection of birds, at least 400,000 birds may have died, probably mostly Urie.How much tragedy and how much anguish in the images of the black oil birds deposited on the beaches by the veterinarians, which we have seen.We all want the best rules for ships, regardless of their flag.The regulations must be respected, such as the "polluting pays" principle, so as to use the penalties and incentives to exercise pressure on maritime operators and oil companies and ensure that the best practices are introduced.I share every word of the commissioner lady, but the problem is how long it will take why measures of the type they proposed are introduced.As a politician, Mrs. Commissioner must remind her officials how difficult it would be forced to recur in the classroom in a year, on the occasion of a similar accident, equally devastating, if some of the measures proposed today were still only beautiful words, having not had the opportunity to put them into practice.The idea of ​​another similar accident in the future should act as a perfect catalyst for the commissioner and for his officials.

This assembly will face one of the most important imperatives that can result from the essential measures adopted so that the commission's resources are up to their tasks.Last month, as Romano Prodi just said, we started a complete evaluation of the activities and resources of the entire commission and in September we will inform in detail about it.Our objective is to focus the work of the Commission on essential priorities in the field of policy formulation and basic activities, in line with our strategic objectives in the field of policy formulation for the next five years.Inevitably, that will entail the determination of activities that could be and should be reduced or concluded.It involves a very strict examination of how the use of external and internal resources can be balanced in the most effective way.It entails the assignment of personnel to sectors of great importance in the field of policy formulation in the departments and throughout the Commission.And, when this assignment has been met, we can determine if the resources we have at the height of the tasks entrusted to us.If it is shown that they are not, we will raise the question of increasing resources to the budgetary authority.If you do not receive a positive response, you will have to address the difficult question of deciding those of our less priority activities that must be suspended.The commission should not only do it, but also this Parliament and the Council.I do not formulate this observation because the Commission Prodi coats the slightest desire to give up activities or committed.On the contrary, as many deputies to this assembly understand, I expose these considerations, because we want to comply with our tasks in the most effective and responsible way.That means filling any important lag between obligations and operating resources by reducing activities or increasing the media or through a combination of both.In each of the three pillars of the reform, the active support and cooperation of this assembly will be absolutely decisive.The new activities based on activities, which the president has just mentioned, will link for the first time the political priorities with the availability of resources and, consequently, with the budget.Thus, the role of the budgetary authority in the functioning of the management based on the activities will be decisive.It is evident that attempts to manage the activities of the Commission on a small scale would not result in anyone's benefit.Thus, a solid and practical inter -institutional agreement will be a prerequisite for the efficient operation of activities based on activities.In the human resources policy, the participation of Parliament will have to inevitably be that of an employer of officials and that of a democratic institution before which the commission must account.That will also be a very arduous imperative.And, finally, in the decisive sector of financial management, in which the Court of Accounts, the Committee of Independent Experts and other external and internal analyzes have strongly advised real changes, the support of this Assembly for the application of the recommendations for money to pay as much as possible without security for security will cover primary importance.In the limited time that I have for this statement, it is impossible, obviously, to expose our proposals in greater detail.

It is a great danger and it must be ensured that in Europe all regions can participate in the Society of Knowledge and that no one remains excluded.Europe will have to be able more than in the past to draw from the realities of its regions to optimally exploit the strength of these regions in favor of creativity and to reach a more realistic employment policy.We had to see that despite all the means allocated by way of structural funds, there are still major differences in unemployment rates.I therefore ask that networks are established between the regions and that the idea of ​​a Europe in which each Member State thinks for themselves are abandoned.Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister Guterres, president of Prodi, honorable colleagues, judged positive and approaches that the Portuguese commission and presidency have proclaimed full employment as the objective of European politics.I agree, but a sustainable model of full employment contemplates in the first place qualified jobs and covered by social protection.We must modify the world of economy and work in order to make the remunerated work activity ecologically sustainable.They focus primarily on further reforms for deregulating the economy in the internal market, on the internet revolution, trade and electronic transactions as machines to create jobs.With these policies they will not be able to keep faith with the promise of full employment.Economic reforms such as the liberalization of the energy market of energy have generated strong competition and numerous mergers, with consequent destruction of jobs, and this trend is still underway.Already in the mid -nineties, Commissioner Bangemann had promised a huge growth of employment thanks to the information society.The result we face is disappointing.The growth recorded in sectors such as that of the media, mobile telephony and software has not been able to compensate for the loss of places in the telecommunications sector and in the electronic industry as well as the effects of the rationalizations deriving from computer technologies in other sectors of the economy.And it certainly does not increase my optimism to see many electronic commerce companies record a gigantic capitalization on the stock exchange, while on an operational level they continue to work at a loss.It is established that trade and electronic transactions will generally have a great future;But their contribution to the growth of employment is exaggerated by their protagonists in almost mystical terms.That's why I am convinced that for a new policy of full employment there is a different policy mix.A less rigid monetary policy, a budgetary policy that strengthens investments for expansion and future, a wage policy linked to productivity that stimulates the European internal demand and the growth of employment, is needed.We serve secondly a drastic reduction strategy of working hours and redistribution of work between women and men.Thirdly, the employment encouraged by public transport in ecocompatible economic sectors and a parallel innovation policy that looks to the future and aims in particular to consolidate small and medium -sized enterprises must be enhanced by public transport.Fourth, a policy of emancipation of the labor market is needed, which clearly refers to the strategies aimed at creating underpaid work categories and compulsory work patterns for unqualified tasks, because only with a wide -ranging offense will we be able to create a sufficient basis for a qualified workforce for the knowledge society, for environmentally friendly social and cultural services.

I think it is also right to recognize the efforts that the high representative Solana is carrying out in order to have a more effective, more visible and more consistent common foreign policy with the European Union.In this sense, I agree with the interventions made by some colleagues who preceded me according to which it is necessary to have a global policy that integrates not only military aspects, but also civil, diplomatic, humanitarian and police elements, to which the high representative Solana referred.The Portuguese presidency has made significant steps forward, actually, creating a series of organs with a provisional or temporary nature.In record time, he organized this informal advice of the defense ministers and reported a whole series of objectives to be achieved during the long journey towards this foreign and common security policy.One of these was the advice of Sintra about which I would have questions to ask the high representative Solana.This advice was based on two documents: a British document concerning the headline Goals, dedicated to the priority objectives, and another document on the permanent military organs of the European Union.Mr. High Representative Solana, I would like to ask you if, on the occasion of the next commission for foreign affairs, the rights of man, the common security and the defense policy, you would be willing to explain to the members of said Commission B diffusely together with Commissioner Patten, to whom I formulate the same question, and with the President in charge of the Council, to which I ask you, Mr. Solana, to transmit this request - the content of the documents that were treated during the top.A second question, Mr. High Representative, would be to know to what extent she supports the observations and declarations made by the French Defense Minister, according to which the Member States must be destined for 0.7% of the gross domestic product for defense costs.I would like to know his opinion, if you share this point of view, if you consider a more decisive contribution from the Member States in this area really necessary.Thirdly, what is its evaluation of the "Crisex 2000@, just ended, in which, for the first time, the European Union has shared a series of initiatives with NATO for the first time? In the quarter and last place, Mr. Solana, I would like to know if, in the event that the Member States asked him, he would be willing to preside over the political and defense committee by adding this charge to the whole experience that you currently have in the general secretary.of the Council of Ministers, as a high representative for the common foreign and security policy, as a secretary general of the Union of Western Europe and former secretary general of NATO.in Chechnya and in other parts of the world.For my part, I do not intend to exasperate it and today, as far as it concerns, I recognize her the efforts she made to build a European security and defense policy worthy of this name that did not have before.It is true that we are still far from the desired objective, or at least by the goal that I hope.

We too are called into question by this democratic deficit.And it is for this reason that at the next day of the inauguration of the intergovernmental conference, during which I will have the honor of representing the commission next to the president Prodi and working, I repeat, in full agreement with your two representatives, the honorable Brok and Tsatsos, a little while ago, within the college, we decided to launch the "dialogue for Europe and Europe", to contribute to this direct contact with the citizens.All the commissioners, whenever they have to go to a country and not only that of origin, in a region - it happens to me three or four times a month - they have committed themselves to dedicating some of their time to a direct dialogue with citizens, not only with the elites or institutional managers who usually meet, to establish direct contact, in a university, a high school, a factory, to meet people, answer the questions.This will be the role that we will take on, as you will take on yours, compared to this indispensable initiative, compared to this pressing obligation aimed at reducing the democratic deficit, that is, the distance between how much we do and the citizens.We wish to carry out this initiative in collaboration with the Member States and in connection with the European Parliament.We will regularly present a synthesis, in order to feel the pulse of public opinion well and consequently carry out adjustments or impress new guidelines.We also want to carry out this initiative in concertation with national parliaments, the local elect, non -governmental organizations, socioprofessional environments and media.The opinion centers, groups and political parties, European and national parliamentarians, the elected representatives, as I just said, of local authorities or national parliaments, the committee of the regions, the economic and social committee, the organizations of civil society and university environments will be involved.I remember among the other - if there was ever need - that, on 1 February last, the European Parliament itself has already taken the initiative, for which I thank President Napolitano again, to organize a first work meeting with the representatives of the national parliaments, or the representatives of the citizens of each state.The Commission will propose to the Member States to associate with this operation in the framework of a punctual cooperation or in the field of a more structured partnership.We will activate a plan for the means of communication and close contacts with the Presidency of the Union and the European Parliament.I have already explained the methods of the contribution of the commissioners during the meetings and on site visits in practice we want to organize civic debates.I simply allow me, without wanting to give absolutely lessons nor advice, to remember that when I had the honor of being minister for European affairs in my country, I perceived this need to dialogue directly with citizens.Carrying out this dialogue directly every week in each region, I realized that there was an incredible need to give a face to the European Union.So, every week, I went to dialogue with them together with a commissioner, not necessarily a French commissioner, or to ambassadors stationed in Paris or European parliamentarians.

These general remarks being made, I would like to concentrate my point, about Interreg, on your main remarks.The former are linked to the calendar and the content of this initiative.You say that the adoption of these guidelines was too late, and the risk of interruption of previous programs has been underlined, in particular by your rapporteur.It is true, I recognize it, and you know what are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen European deputies.There is a delay in the adoption of Interreg's orientations in March-April 2000. I recognize it, I take note like you.However, I observe that the Member States and the regions are already actively preparing the Interreg III programs and the orientation project was also distributed more than three months ago.I also observe that the eligibility of expenses will be admitted from the date of presentation of the programs and I confirm the possibility of retroactivity until January 1, if this program is presented before April 30.So much for the first remark.Second remark: Regarding the non -exhaustive list of eligible measures for component B, I want to tell you and confirm that I have asked the Commission to accept to include other specific themes, in particular in favor of small and medium -sized enterprises or cultural heritage, in the list of actions eligible for component B and therefore no longer consider this list as exhaustive.Third point: interregional cooperation, the importance of component C. The Commission shares the observations that have been made by your assembly on the importance of this C section, of interregional cooperation.As your rapporteur wishes, I will send you detailed information on the implementation system of this component.Fourth note: the observatory and the possible use of a technical assistance office.As you asked, I decided to delete any reference to the use of a technical assistance office in the text, while waiting for the debate, in progress within the Commission, on the service outsourcing systems finds its outcome.But, ladies and gentlemen deputies, if we delete any reference and, later, any use of a bat, it has a consequence, which must be the increase in certain officials of civil servants to do this work, because someone will have to do it and I will not be able to redeploy the same personnel indefinitely, even though our tasks increase with ISPA and with the concern to better control, with rigor and transparencyCommunity credits, for which I have the charge, often in partnership or in co -responsibility with the Member States.Now being the implementation of Interreg, a subject that has been mentioned by many of you, and the possible eligibility for component A, "cross -border cooperation", actions in the Adriatic, for Sicily or for the UlTrapipheral regions, the Commission, ladies and Gentlemen, understands your concerns and hears your request on these different points.So I intend to modify the guidelines to integrate into the transnational component B a specific priority: "Integrated cooperation of maritime and island regions", so as to cover, in order, it seems to me, appropriate, the different possibilities of cooperation between these regions.

At the moment, it is evident that the first priority corresponds to rescue helicopters and then must continue with food aid and other emergency aid.After three weeks since these floods began, finally the entire world has begun to wake up and realize the situation, which claims to heaven, in which Mozambique lives: there are thousands of people whose life hangs from a thread and that, if we do not have the sending of means of transport, especially aerial, to take them out of the situation in which they are, they will quickly die.That is undoubtedly the most priority issue at this time: Transport for salvation and emergency humanitarian aid, including food aid.But I would like to underline that the European Union and the rest of the world cannot limit their help to Mozambique to this issue of emergency that we are talking about.We must be aware of the ravages resulting from floods.Therefore, it is urgent to start thinking about finding financial support for the reconstitution of infrastructure that have been destroyed and without which Mozambique could not continue its path to the development he had started some years ago and so promisingly.That question of the reconstruction of infrastructure is fundamental, without that there is no development, and it is also time for some Mozambique creditors to think of forgiving or lowering their debts.If nothing is done now, we will spoil all the effort made in the past to help Mozambique in their development.Therefore, I hope that the visit to Mozambique that Commissioner Nielson and the representatives of the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union have made this week properly to raise that very important issue.Mr. President, it has already been said that Mozambique, after a war that plunged the country into misery, is now before a natural catastrophe of terrifying dimensions.Without being calculated at the moment, how many people have died, it is known that about 80,000 are imminent of drowned and that 300,000 have lost their homes and their cultivation fields.They urgently need help for survival, food, water and shelters.Then the needs of medicines will come to avoid epidemics, which already seems that they have begun, and the means for reconstruction.But the immediate need for immediate need comes in spite of the efforts of the NGOs, as roads, bridges and rail lines are cut.Helicopters are necessary.There are only five, apparently, to get off the trees to 80,000 people.But the machinery that mobilizes help is too heavy.The socialist group of this Parliament has promoted the prevention of natural catastrophes - even has defended conflict prevention - as the best means to avoid situations such as the one now suffers from the population of Mozambique.I want to remember, particularly, the efforts of deputy Michel Rocard, of the previous legislature.The European Commission has responded, already in 1994, a program for the prevention of catastrophes -Dítcho- that intended to be proactive and, from a regional approach, avoid catastrophes or, in any case, minimize its effects on populations.

The policy of the European Union must regain the trust of citizens, who claim the right to access the institutions quickly and without preclusions and ask that the rules on which their understanding depends are legible.They want a policy destined to succeed, which they consider as a normal service rendered to responsible citizens.The success of the reform essentially depends on the Commission's initiative.However, I am irritated by the declaration issued today by the executive, according to which the discussion of the intermediate relationship with the Parliament must only have an informal character.Commissioner Kinnock, his intervention on Tuesday next to the budget control commission, however, cannot be one -way, because Parliament wants and must contribute to the reforms.This week's press conference also offends my political sensitivity because it is held before an accurate discussion of the proposal within the Commission for the budget control.Commissioner Kinnock, despite his personal successes it seems to me that the commission must still take a long journey before being able to satisfy our strong, but legitimate expectations.I wish to start by putting to the documents and making the honorable Langenhagen that the decision that I do not intervene at tomorrow's plenary session and therefore is not available to provide formal responses on the relationship is not mine or the commission, but it is a decision of Parliament.So, if he wants to make a paternal, it is better that he does it here in the classroom. The honorable knows me well enough to know that in all the phases of these five years, in which we worked together in Parliament, there was not only one time when I refused to make account complete, formal and detailedly of my work.Mr. President, I would like to start paying tribute to conscientious work and, from what I feel, generous of the honorable Van Hulten in preparing this relationship.Although new of this classroom, he is quite old in some respects, certainly as regards his familiarity with the institutions since he is a former official;I believe that he has shown this quality by skillfully facing a complex theme and of the utmost importance for all our institutions, as various parliamentarians have underlined.I thank him and wish him a long and brilliant career as a deputy.Mr. President, as you will know, the report of the honorable Van Hulten on the second report of the Committee of independent experts is necessarily long and, since I intend to answer in particular in particular on issues relating to management and financial control, I ask you to be indulgent.Of course I will not steal at the classroom more time than it is absolutely necessary.When the Assembly examined the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts last September, on behalf of the Entrance Commission I promised that the report would be considered a fundamental element in the Commission's reform proposals.Our efforts, aimed at keeping this promise, will be evident for Parliament when the package of reforms that the Commission approved today, well within the term we had set ourselves four months ago, will be examined.

Negotiations in Austria for the Constitution of the Government The agenda calls for the debate on negotiations in Austria with a view to the government's constitution.I immediately give the floor to the President in office of the Council.Madam President, the Chairman of the Commission, Mr. Chairman in office of the Council, the group of the Party of European Socialists wishes to send three messages to European public opinion today.Whether it is clear: we are deeply united with regard to these three messages.First, we want to specify that we fully support the declaration of the presidency in the exercise of the Council and the 14 Member States and that we identify ourselves, because it responds to the community of values ​​which was built by all of us, and not by a single political force.Anyway, it is a community of values ​​which is contrary to that defends by this party, which has ironically baptized freedom of freedom.The Europe that we currently build is precisely the result of bitter experiences that we have all suffered and the socialist group condemns the insults addressed to the President of the French Republic and to the Belgian government, but also to the socialists, also European citizens, because, ladies and gentlemen, the Austrian socialists are now accused of trahison to their homeland.I will tell you one thing: for many years, I betrayed my homeland, that's at least what General Franco said.President Guterres also betrayed Salazar.It seems necessary to me that the PPE affirms and defends it.In addition, I think that the Commission, Mr. Prodi, was a guardian of the treaties.But I remind the President Prodi that during the investiture debate, he spoke of the Commission as a European government.However, a government must have more nerve and courage.This is what I ask the Prode President for the moment.(Applause) Unless I owe to a commissioner as effective as Mr. Fischler, according to some rumors - it all depends on the language in which they are expressed -, President Prodi would have asked for the resignation of Mr. Fischler.I will be grateful to you to clarify this point in front of the Parliament.Second, Madam President, we want to send a very clear message to the Austrian people.A call for the majority of the Austrian people who did not vote to Haider, who voted for clearly democratic parties, engaged in the European project I would like to point out that if Mr. Schüssel was Minister of Finance, Chancellor Vranitzky also played a role in the integration process of Austria.In politics, you cannot show as much sectarianism.It is together that we allowed the entry of Austria into the community.It is the work of all and not of a single group.Consequently, Madam President, we believe that it is our right and our duty to ask Austrians to rethink their choice, this kind of plague which we have already suffered in Europe risking harming Austria, but also to expand, as history reminds us.

This is not enough to make proposals from approximate data.What we need is an absolutely binding objective on the legal level for OSPAR.It is only thus that we will succeed in legal clarity and especially the possibility of acting in court.Everything else would have no effect and would not help prevent ecological disasters like the one we currently know in Romania and Hungary can also occur here.I find it unfortunate that national governments are not willing to commit to a legally binding protection, although they agreed on OSPAR at the international level.But I believe that this is precisely what we must repair here, in Parliament, in order to show that we do not tolerate that it is infringed with the credibility of our policy.It is also important to strengthen the principle of the polluter paying, because prices must tell the ecological truth.We cannot kneel before the interests of lobbies of the agricultural and chemical industry;Rather, we must proclaim and express by our vote that we want the principle of the Pollueur Payer and, in doing so, prices that cover costs.Water is our most important vital resource and we must watch, with our vote, to encourage and push for the real respect of the OSPAR Convention.It is possible with closed production cycles;Everything else would be an edulcoration of the directive.Let us enter this chance!Mr. President, during the short time I have, I want to salute the report and recall three principles, to which we must add everything else, which are clearly exposed in the amendments of the rapporteur: water is not a merchant good but a heritage belonging to the peoples of the Union;The final objective is to manage to eliminate all pollutants from surface water and groundwater;And it is necessary to inform the population so that they can participate in the recovery of water and that it does not consume it excess when it is such a precious good.I know that this directive can encounter problems because we have discussed here the different realities of the different countries of the Union.What is happening to the north is different from what's going on in the south and what's going on in countries with desertification problems.I know it.But some amendments are trying to help the countries of the South, more precisely amendment 43 which, when it speaks of recovery of costs, also indicates that the Member States will have to take into account the social and environmental conditions of the countries when making decisions.There are also difficulties in the field of transfers.In my country - I live in the north of Spain - there is a big difference between the North and the South, and these difficulties arise when it is necessary to transfer the water from one place to another.But Ms. Lienemann's report also says that receiving water pools must save and watch over their water.

This public intervention is achievable and the decentralization of university education would certainly contribute to balance the development policy.Another point that we want to underline is instead linked to industrial policy.In the planning of the coordination of structural funds and cohesion funds, the Commission should have taken more into consideration the importance of the tertiary, electronic commerce and the spread of the use of the Internet.In the past, poverty and wealth depended above all on the structure of the local economic fabric.The regions with greater industrial presence were, in fact, considered rich.Today the situation is completely different, indeed we have come to the opposite, and these regions have impoverished.It is therefore important to invest in new sectors, in the so -called electronic and tertiary production, which represent the future.This, in my opinion, was almost ignored by the competent commission that prepared this report.The commission for industry, foreign trade, research and energy therefore urges the commission to pay more attention to this issue.Finally, as a commission for energy, we would have liked to see greater financial support for renewable energy resources through the use of structural funds and regional development funds.In this way, a greater use of renewable energy sources would have been promoted, compensating the insufficient funds of the energy development program..(En) Mr. President, my most lively thanks to the honorable Schroedter for the work done.I would like to explain to my colleagues that I intervene in place of the honorable Flautre, who followed this practice in the commission for employment and social affairs, but which unfortunately is not good.I would like to attract your attention to the amendments nos.1 and 2, approved in the commission for the employment he social affairs, but not a commission for regional policy, transport and tourism.These amendments deal with the social economy and the need to provide the share capital of risk and to give financial support to local initiatives aimed at creating jobs and strengthening social cohesion.In the past this parliament has recognized the large potential for creating the employment of the social economy.Therefore the aforementioned amendments match the position of the parliament according to which social exclusion is a serious problem that requires a constructive intervention.We hope that those who are thinking of voting against these amendments have very valid reasons to present to Parliament and citizens looking for work.In his report, the honorable Flautre also highlights a field in which there is a painful deficiency of coordination, of which instead there is a desperate need.The Commission's proposals refer to the four pillars of the employment strategy and the five fields of action of the European Social Fund.The lack of specific directors here is felt with particular intensity, given that the idea of ​​connecting the aid of the social fund to the employment strategy will be carried out for the first time during the programming period 2000-2006.This omission makes it seem that the commission itself does not know in the least how to guarantee maximum coordination between the support for the European Social Fund, subject to revision after three and a half years, and the annual national action plans for the employment of the Member States.

The fact reinforces the need to strengthen European Civil Protection, following the guidelines suggested by President Prodi in his recent speech and as one or two deputies have suggested today.But, for now, the priority is to overcome the crisis.As I said, my colleague, Commissioner Wallström, is today at the scene.She will inform Parliament in detail about the actions she will propose as a result of her visit.This has been a frightful tragedy for Europe and Europe must respond and do everything to ensure that facts such as this do not continue to ruin our future.The debate is closed.The vote will take place below.Voting(FR) The only reason we have voted in favor of the PSE-VETS/Ale-GG/NGL commitment resolution is that only this resolution allowed us to "condemn the decision of the direction of Goodyear-Dunlop to close its factory in Italy."However, the measures proposed in this resolution are insignificant to stop the policy of large industrial groups, which suppress jobs and sharpen unemployment.On the other hand, these are only words, since socialist governments, which are a majority in Europe, are as incapable as the right -wing governments to take the necessary measures to prevent dismissals.The real problem is not to find the legal procedures that make the process of dismissal more complex, but of prohibiting layoffs.The only way to stop this infernal mechanism - which, on the one hand, generates financial surplus value and, on the other, unemployment - consists in prohibiting layoffs in all large companies that obtain benefits, under penalty of expropriation, and in publishing the balances of large societies, and submitting them to control of their workers and the entire population.It is necessary that the company will have the means to impose on the large companies and their owners their own priorities, and in the first place the eradication of unemployment.The sums necessary to create useful jobs in public services, as well as to finance the distribution of work among all, without decrease in wages, must be obtained from the benefits of large companies.It is infinitely more important, for the majority of society, than waste in financial operations or the scandalous enrichment of a minority of great shareholders..(SV) I cannot give my support to this resolution, since in point 8 an industry determined in Italy is indicated with the desire that its facilities be maintained, at the same time that the current direction of the company that sells the factory to a European manufacturer of tires is advised.It is not a task that competes with the European Parliament to declare what factories in the fifteen countries of the European Union have to remain or disappear, expand or decrease their template of workers, stay in a place or move, sell or not sell and which must be sold, inside or outside Europe.

President, everyone underlined it: Today is a very important day, the day of the first debate in the political life of Europe.And that's no coincidence.Today it is not about the relationship of Europe, our institutions to Austria or the party of Mr. Haider.I think today is about Europe itself, about its right to exist, the reasons why we are here in this parliament today.This parliament does not stand for money and goods.This parliament and the European institutions stand for values, morality and for a spirit.Now in the twentieth century we have had the experience that democracies can endanger this morality, these values ​​and this spirit with the names of fanatic nationalism, populism and racism.You only need to read Mr. Haider's program, the FPÖ.In every chapter you come across fanatical nationalism, populism and racism.I only quote a sentence that my friend Vidal-Quadra has already referred to: "The concept of home is defined in spatial, ethnic and cultural terms, with regard to space, culture and breed." And we cannot accept such explanations.If Europe should make sense and - forgive me if I tell my political friends - if Christian democracy makes sense, if the history of Christian democracy makes sense, then it must clearly and unmistakably differentiate itself from the statements of this program and refuse how many good reasons may also speak for an agreement with an organization of this kind.That is why I believe that the European Parliament, which is more independent in relation to its statements and actions, than the council or the Commission, the states and European institutions that had the courage to say no;To say what you, Ms. President, have explained in our name;An explanation that honors us and clearly and without wague expresses that we reject and condemn what is going on in Austria.We should remember what a great French Christian Democrat said on the day of the Munich Agreement: "When it comes to saying no - preferably immediately." (Applause) Mrs. President!We are worried.We, these are the Belgian Christian Democrats and fortunately also many other colleagues.The coalition, which is prepared in one of the Member States, is certainly an Austrian matter, but it also undeniably has a European dimension.Because what connects us in Europe are the values ​​and principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights in the first place.The chairman of the Freedom Party of Austria, Jörg Haider, has repeatedly expressed his disregard for these values.He also disregards the elementary forms of diplomatic courtesy.He is a dangerous man.The Christian Democratic parties in my country have decided for a long time and they remain: they take note of the protests of voters from extreme right, but never negotiate with leaders from extremely right.Values ​​must be higher than power.

Mr. President, it is true that the suspension or postponement sine die of conversations between Syrians and Israelis as well as the new bomb attack of the day before yesterday which caused 16 injured is not good news.It is clear that for once, the United States has failed to unlock the situation for these negotiations to resume.It is true that the obstacles are size: the Syrians aspire to have under their sovereignty and their jurisdiction again the platforms of the Golan and to recover the borders prior to June 4, 1967, while the Israelis wish, believing that this is better suitable for their situation, that the boundaries chosen are those fixed in 1923. The blocking of these conversations between Syrians and Israelis does not constitute the only delay thatknows the peace process in the Middle East.The application of the framework agreement between the Palestinian authority and Israel is currently suspended.Following the conversations that took place the day before yesterday between the Israeli Prime Minister and the head of the Palestinian Authority, the Israeli Prime Minister requested a postponement of two months from February 13, the deadline for the execution of the framework agreement relating to the situation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.What can the European Union do in the face of this situation?Unfortunately not much.It must logically support these negotiations, under the auspices of the United States and must multiply contacts.The presence of the envoy of the European Union, the ambassador Moratinos, who certainly fulfilled his mission with great diligence and efficiency in accordance with the powers available to the European Union, is positive.But all of this does not prevent us from seeing that we are relatively helpless, because when the two-part-parts negotiators take the plane this weekend to return to the United States, we cannot prevent ourselves from thinking that each time a hundred dollars are spent for the peace process in the region, 60 dollars are paid by the European Union.And when one thinks that a conference will soon be held in Moscow, the pathetic character of the presence of the European Union in this process is highlighted.I would like to emphasize the Portuguese presidency on the need we can play a more central role and that it is time to take over and assume an increased presence of the European Union.I hope that the next visit of the president of the European Parliament in the region as well as that of the presidents of the corresponding inter -parliamentary delegations, will mark the beginning of a period when the European Union will take more initiative and will be more present in this difficult and complex peace process.Mr. President, Mr. Chairman of the Council, Mr. Commissioner Patten, I would like to thank you for your interventions, in particular Mr. Patten, whose analysis I entirely share.That's why I don't have the intention of repeating what he said.I would simply like to make three remarks that Commissioner Patten will no doubt consider as similar to what he said, but who, for various reasons, can only be formulated so open than by a parliamentarian.

All the others can be accepted, either completely either in their minds.Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is an extraordinary coincidence to discuss during this period of the Equal initiative within the European Parliament.In recent times and because of political developments in Austria, there has been an increasing political concern in Europe, but also political statements and dialogue.It should be noted that concrete policies must be presented both in Parliament and to the Commission.Concrete proposals both for legislation and action plans which concern the fight against discrimination, and which concern the establishment of freedoms and social rights.Thus, allow me to make a small allusion to the train of measures against discrimination, praying to the commissions responsible for the Parliament to appoint rapporteurs, in order to approach the train of measures against discrimination as quickly as possible.I now come to the Equal initiative which is of course based on article 13. The Equal initiative concerns all forms of discrimination on the basis of article 13, that is to say the fight against discrimination based on sex, race, age, disability.In particular, I would like to congratulate Ms. Stenzel because her attempts in order to conclude the agreement on the Equal initiative are particularly difficult and complex, not only because the commissions involved defended totally different points of view but also because it was an extremely delicate political subject.The first observation, which was also formulated by many other colleagues, refers to the question of whether it takes a separate mention for women.Admittedly, we have expressed our disagreement as to an aspect of article 13, but the treaty at this moment is such that it is, and among the discrimination categories we find discrimination on the basis of sex.Thus, in accordance with the treaty as it presents itself today, the Equal initiative is structured in this way.However, I want to recall that there is a special axis for the employment strategy that concerns women and that a special program is preparing, the fifth program for equality between men and women.I divided into four groups the subjects that attracted the attention of colleagues.First, the enlargement of thematic domains.There are four thematic areas, like employment strategy, employability, entrepreneurship, adaptability and equal opportunities, and we agree on the enlargement of these thematic fields in accordance with the proposals that have been submitted by the European Parliament.As for concern in relation to the possible danger of attributing to a single country all the funds for one of the categories undergoing discrimination, I would say that it is stipulated in the initiative, with the greatest possible clarity that the Member States will have to submit a thematic domain for all categories undergoing discrimination.

It is clear that many who, in Wales, see the program of structural funds as a means to stop some of the great difficulties that we are undoubtedly confronted.We have found that poverty is growing in Wales, a trend that has been strengthening since 1997. We have seen the gap between the rich and the poor widening.We are therefore expecting the structural fund program that it is not limited to considering industrial restructuring, we want it to also bring more improvements to the entire economic base of Wales.What brings us great prejudice to us, however, is to believe that, in a way, the granting of structural funds was a victory for the government, when it only recognizes that Wales is faced with very great difficulties.This is why I would like to highlight certain points that the commission should, in my opinion, place in the foreground.We hope that the Commission will deal with points related to additionality.We deplore that, in a way, the British figures have masked the Welsh figures.We also hope that the Commission will provide appropriate funding projects.We hope that it will guarantee, by going against the British government, the participation of the private sector in the planning phase, as it is sure that this must provide the main momentum to the expenses of the structural funds.Finally, we ask the commissions to ensure that the structural funds are spent transparently.Within this parliament, transparency is too often lacking.In this area, the Commission can become the great friend of Wales.Mr. President, our committee deals with these questions in many different angles, and to start I will talk about the angle of research.We consider it very positive that, in its conclusions, the rapporteur has taken into account our proposal according to which research infrastructure should be extended in cohesion countries by implanting professional schools and universities so that they serve the populations of the least developed regions better and that they allow trained people to remain in their region of origin.It is something that it is possible to perform by taking measures at the level of the public authorities.Such decentralization of higher education is undoubtedly a useful policy when it is a question of guaranteeing development.The second point on which we wanted to attract attention, precisely with the view of industrial policy, it is that we would have wanted by reflecting on the coordination of structural funds and the cohesion fund, the Commission attaches greater attention to the impact of the progression of services, electronic commerce and the use of the Internet.In the past, poverty and wealth were more dependent on the structures of economic life.The rich regions were those where there were industrial jobs, while today these regions can very well have become a burden and be poor.It therefore becomes necessary to also carry out investments in the new sectors of activity, so -called "electronic" production and the production of electronic services, because they are sectors of the future.

The best prevention for the future is the certainty that the charters will have to be heavily, civilly, criminally and financially condemned if they are not extremely vigilant about the safety of the ships they choose.Second, the condition of a double shell for oil tankers admitted to frequent community waters must be imposed as quickly as possible and not given to Greek calendars.Third, a strict limitation of the age of ships admitted to frequent community waters must be quickly fixed.It could be a maximum of fifteen years.Without obtaining a sufficiently clear, strict and rigorous community regulatory framework, the Member States which, for their part, wish to establish one should be allowed to do so to protect its population and their territory, in the same way that the United States has managed to learn from the disaster of the Exxon Valdez by demanding the double hull and banish from their waters all ships of more than twenty years.This is how the United States had refused Erika access to its waters.If the community had done the same, a huge disaster would have been avoided.Let us make sure, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, to learn this time really the lesson, even when media emotion and parliamentary emotion will be used.Mr. President, Torrey Canyon, Olympic BRAVERY, HAVEN, AMOCO CADIZ, GINO, Tanio, there are all names of disaster memory.And now Erika.Who is the turn?Twenty-one year after the Amoco Cadiz, this umpteenth of the dark, the seventh since 1967, proves the irresponsibility of our successive rulers.The West Atlantic is once again paying the high price of their inability to react, of their capitulation in front of the multinationals.It is difficult to understand why French and Europeans authorize what Americans refuse, and why Europe, usually so quick to legislate in terms of environment, has skipped maritime security.The result is there.The Erika, a beating ship Maltese pavilion, amber wreck classified among the most dangerous oil tankers, soiled our ribs over more than 400 km, which represents much more serious pollution than that caused by the Amoco Cadiz.Elected from Loire-Atlantique, I unfortunately can testify.These repetitive disasters are not natural, they owe nothing to fatality.They are the consequence of the inconsistency of men.It is indeed an ecological disaster.Only those who have harsh realities on the ground have doubted it.It is also an economic catastrophe for all those who live from the sea and tourism, fishermen, oyster farmers, conchyls, malaria, traders, etc.Erika's bug must be the last in the series.We must first shed light on this sinking.Why not appoint a parliamentary commission of inquiry or associate parliamentarians with the mission which was announced earlier by the Commission?Then, we must legislate urgently, first, so that the exact characteristics of the transported goods are known.Indeed, according to experts, Erika oil had to flow by the bottom and never
