I refer, for example, to the restructuring of the company ABB-Asthom Power, of which an important delegation of employees from all over Europe is today in Strasbourg.The ABB-Asthom Power Directorate, which is the result of a fusion carried out in June 1999, has already announced a restructuring with perspectives for reducing jobs in several countries.This disastrous situation for employment raises numerous questions, in particular, about the information provided to the European Company Committee, which exists since 1996. It requires an update and intensification of the community directive on the European Company Committees.It also demands a control of the concentrations that takes into consideration employment, the environment and consumers.The report of the Commission of Economic and Monetary Affairs is insufficient from this point of view, which is why I have refrained.By pretending to apply the principle of subsidiarity at the level of the community competence policy, the Commission delegates in the national authorities and courts the competence in the field of decisions and abuses of the dominant position with respect to agreements of companies that create distortions of the market, although they continue in the notification regime issues of concentration of companies and state aids.The now adopted position is aimed at creating more expedited forms and with lower costs of application of the competence policy, which goes to apply community law at the level of the national courts and not at the level of the European Court of Justice and even speak of the possibility of specialized courts.This partial renationalization of the competence policy could have greater costs for the Member States.On the other hand, as the rapporteur recalls, many times, on behalf of the competence policy, public monopolies have been replaced by private monopolies with the privatizations of important sectors and public companies, as has happened in Portugal, with negative consequences for the country and for workers..(FR) The White Book of the Commission on the modernization of the rules of application of articles 85 and 86 of the CE Treaty (81 and 82 new) certainly does not propose a "renationalization" of the competence policy, as some fear in the European Parliament.But in any case, it suggests quite interesting evolution possibilities for the European Union.Indeed, after having taken note of the jam of its services because of the prior notifications of agreements of companies that can twist the trade and for fear that its number will continue to grow with the arrival of new member countries, the Commission proposes the suppression of the prior authorization regime of these agreements and a more decentralized application of the rules of competence at the level of the Member States.The most remarkable, in my opinion, is the signal that this proposal sends us: the Commission anticipates the consequences of the extension and includes that it implies and almost mechanically a reform of the centralized system.Of course, in this case, the reform consists in favoring flexibility and not in dismantling.On paper, the commission will keep the control and central direction of the new system.On the other hand, the Von Wogau report, which the European Parliament has just approved, encourages it in this regard.

The European Union water policy does not start from nothing.Numerous directives have been approved and, otherwise, the commission warms the willingness to become more legible, more compatible with each other, with clearer objectives.Thus, it has been an interest in rationality that has led to the formulation of this directive.But our Parliament, in the first reading, insisted that the current directive was not only compatible with the commitments we have contracted -tipo Ospar-, but also allows us to invest the course.Well, despite these numerous directives, despite frequent statements about the effort that must be made in water protection, when we examine the state of the environment in Europe, we see that the objectives have not been achieved.In many cases the situation has deteriorated and, therefore, we cannot content ourselves with an effort to rationalization of the texts.We must set objectives at the height of the imperatives that we face and do not have much time, because, if we do, as the commission proposed, with too long deadlines, when she herself and the council have re -extended the deadlines, we will not only have a credit problem in the opinion, but also, in addition, the efforts will be left - after we know it - for tomorrow and tomorrow they will be postponed again and, therefore, the objectives will not bedesiredI insist on this aspect, because it should not be expected for the umpteenth time that every day catastrophes will be communicated in our newspapers to say: "Ah! Europe has not acted. Ah! Europe should have acted", and then, with precipitation, do as if we were going to fix the problems that we did not want to face to the arm in useful time.The example today of the Danube, of the pollution that is taking place in Romania, shows very clearly that, if we do not apply a new mode of economic development, clear demands, precise controls and measures on the state of our rivers, not only will it be reproduced - we know it - that type of incidents, but also will multiply over time.We also know that, if we do nothing, the development of our agriculture will continue to be done with great imbalances.Now the Breton rivers of my own country are in the middle of eutrophication, which harms tourism.I would simply conclude, Mr. President, saying that imperatives are clear in second reading.Do we want, yes or no, rules compatible with OSPAR, that is, to approach zero in the case of hazardous substances?Do we want to reduce the deadlines that the Council has proposed for this directive?Do we want to have a price policy that gives all public and private agents the ability to decontaminate, to act against pollution and save our water?Do we really want to respond to the aspiration of our peoples?Most amendments voted by the Environment Commission respond to that goal;I hope you get the support of the Assembly.Mr. President, ladies, Mrs. Lienemann has just exposed the importance of water and air for us, especially as a simply essential foundation of human life.

In particular, as agreed within the "Human Rights" Council on February 9, 2000, the European Union intends to present resolution proposals on the territories occupied by Israel, on Iran, Iraq, Sudan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Burma/Myanmar, a proposal for the declaration of the Presidency on Colombia and, if possible, on Timor Est, as well as a proposal for the situation in the various countries.The European Union will continue, at the next meeting of the "Human Rights" group in March, the discussion on the preparation of the 56th session of the Commission of Human Rights.It will be discussed in particular of the question relating to the possible presentation of a resolution proposal on the death penalty.So far the group has not come to an agreement on the strategy to be used in facing this question and, especially, on the formulation of the commitment to be assumed ultimately in response to any changes of the opposite sense, including paragraph 7 of article 2 of the UN card, which refers to the question of sovereignty.We tried to obtain a preliminary consent on a compromise text, given the difficulties that arose within the 1999 session of the third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly in which the position of the Member States was divergent with respect to a change with which a reference to paragraph 7 of article 2 was introduced in the proposal for resolution sponsored by the European Union on the death penalty.Last year, in the 55th session of the Commission of Human Rights, as is known, the United States decided, in the already very advanced phase, to present a resolution proposal regarding China.This proposed resolution was rejected thanks to a Chinese motion of non -interference.The European Union voted against this motion.The position of the European Union on the attitude to be assumed against China in the Commission of Human Rights was reconfirmed by the "General Affairs" Council of 21 March 1999: no initiative of the European Union compared to China or any support for a resolution on China, the European Union vote against the motion of non -interference.It is not certain that the cohesion of the European Union could have been maintained if the resolution had been subjected to vote.The United States of America will present a resolution proposal relating to China of the 56th session of the Commission of Human Rights and are pressing for the European Union signing this proposal.This circumstance has caused lively reactions from China: Chinese authorities are soliciting the countries and institutions of the European Union so that they abstain to support the initiative of the United States of America.The initiative is under discussion within the Union, but a decision is not expected shortly.It is the interest of the European Union to maintain, as far as possible and in any case until the end of the meeting that will take place on February 25, 2000, all the alternatives in the context of the dialogue between the European Union and China on human rights.In light of the changes that occurred in the composition of the Commission of Human Rights, the result of the vote on the motion of non -interference will be expected to be very uncertain.Consequently, it is important that this year the countries of the European Union also reach a consensus on the position to be taken as regards the possible vote on the resolution.

Maybe commissioner Kinnock could already make some anticipation tonight?Mr Van Hulten, my group of environmentalists and regionalists in short will support the attempts to further improve the report during the plenary tomorrow afternoon.In fact, it has no sense to resume the numerous and valid recommendations of the Committee of independent experts in the word by word.Therefore, if tomorrow we will vote against some amendments or paragraphs, it is not certain because we are against the content of the text.Our intent is to make his relationship more readable.In any case, it must be clear that my group fully supports the recommendations of the Committee of independent experts.However, I await with interest to see the document approved today by the Commission as well as the White Paper which will be published in February.However, I must communicate to you, Mr. Commissioner, that both the report of the essays and the Van Hulten report will become for our group important points of reference, which will allow us to confirm or deny our trust in the Prodi Commission.I allow myself to be a last consideration.We ask that the new White Paper on the Commission reform receives the same treatment reserved for that on food safety, which was published last week and made accessible to the public and which established a concrete deadline.I believe that it is a necessary step since public opinion expects a change.In any case, my group asks that a real change materializes by the end of 2002. Mr. President, this report is undoubtedly appropriate, but alone it is not enough.Fraud, bad management and nepotism are not random phenomena.They have more possibilities to take hold where democratic control over finance is limited.Much of the European budget is distributed through structural funds.Such an operation makes sense only if marked by solidarity, when rich countries contribute to creating income and development in the poorest countries.The funds thus distributed find the way to return to rich countries passing through Brussels.The municipalities and regional authorities consider these funds owned by them, but are able to reappear only by investing massive financial and human resources in lobbying and negotiated activities.To any undue use of European funds, and certainly after each fraud, the appeal echoes for even more severe controls.However, not even the most rigorous checks can solve the problem.The only result would be an enhancement of bureaucracy and a reduced possibility of influence and participation by local democracies and citizens in the choices concerning the various projects and their implementation.It would be more appropriate that these funds were donated directly by national governments to local authorities without going through Brussels.In the coming years we will have to reflect on the possibility of replacing the structural funds with a pairing fund used exclusively to support the financial statements of the Member States or the low -capita low income regions.This, perhaps, is the only way that allows you to contain fraud and administrative costs and to strengthen transparency and democracy.

A Europe that ensures social justice is an need that has not lost anything of its topicality, since realizing it means first of all to put the fight against mass unemployment and against poverty at the center of the union policy of the union.For these reasons, the realization of this political vision presupposes, in my opinion, also the courage to modify article 4 of the Treaty on the Union which describes the European Union, according to a classic-neolobiral approach, such as an open market economy and free competition.In this same political vision, an important role is due, in my opinion, to article 105 of the same treaty, since the European Central Bank must receive the political mandate once once, provided for by the Treaty, to promote sustainable growth and employment with its monetary policy.Mr. President, the Union group for Europe of the Nations believes that the agenda of the next intergovernmental conference should be respected as it has been defined by the Council of Helsinki, that is, rigorously hinted on the issues related to the decision -making process of enlarged Europe.This agenda must be respected precisely to ensure that, before the expansion, the conference works are carried out effectively and speed.We cannot therefore associate ourselves with the opinion of the European Parliament, nor to that of the Commission, as they are aimed at excessively extending the agenda in the negative sense, or in the sense of centralization and the increasingly tight closure of the European system.My group therefore filed a series of amendments which, recomposed piece by piece, form a real alternative resolution.In fact, we say that the next CIG must work on a more respectful decision -making system of national sovereignty.We regret that the Commission, in the opinion of 26 January last, persist in continuing in the usual direction towards a uniform Europe that extends to the east, a centralized superstated that works with decisions made by majority.Federalists perhaps believe that in this way the unity can be created by force, but this idea is completely naive.On the contrary, in an enlarged Europe, Mr. President, forced uniformation through the abusive use of majority decisions can only lead to the explosion.Furthermore, the centralized European system, as it is developing and properly looming, weakens nations and in this way leds the national patriotism which constitutes the vital center of our will to defense.Europe that derives from it cannot be stronger, but only weaker, since it no longer recognizes its identity and the causes it defends.For this reason we have always said that expansion was possible only by clearly guaranteeing the diversity and freedom of the peoples who form Europe, that is, by adopting a variable geometry based on respect for national sovereignty.We are pleased to see this idea progress in the areas that fortunately are still outside the skills of the European Parliament and the Commission.Europe with variable geometry is Europe that respects national democracies and is based on nations, on national patriotisms and does not persecute them.It is in this Europe that we will find the desire to defend ourselves against external threats and not in the binding and excessively complex decision -making procedures that the Commission intends to propose during the next intergovernmental conference.

And when one thinks that a conference will be held soon in Moscow, the somewhat pathetic situation of the presence of the European Union in this process will be evidenced.I would like to insist before the Portuguese presidency that you have to have greater prominence, in which it is time to take over and assume greater presence of the European Union on this issue.I hope that the next visit of the president of the European Parliament to the region, as well as the presidents of the corresponding interparliamentary delegations, allow to initiate a stage of greater initiative and of greater presence of the European Union in this complicated and difficult peace process.Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner Patten, I want to express my congratulations for his exhibitions, especially to Commissioner Patten, whose analysis I fully share.Therefore, I will not repeat anything he has already said.I just want to make three observations that are perhaps considered similarly by Commissioner Patten but that for various reasons could not be formulated as open as some deputies have done.First, I think we can be glad of the agreements between Israel and the Palestinian national authority.But we already have enough agreements: Oslo, Wye Plantation, Sharm-El-Sheik.Enough of agreements, what you have to do now is to fulfill them.I share the skepticism of my colleague Salafranca when he says that this week there are bad news from Israel since this last agreement will not be able to comply in the planned time.The second point refers to the restart of negotiations between Syria and Israel.Me parece una noticia muy alentadora.But this week we have news that Mr. Barak is not going to Washington, so they will not be able to continue negotiations.I want to verify very clearly that if the goal heights are returned to Syria, the problem in that region is solved.Regarding the question of the referendum to which several colleagues have referred, we have to reconsider whether to fulfill the obligations derived from international law, a referendum must always be carried out.In Germany they would probably be very happy if it was said that a referendum will be held on payments to the European Union and that these payments will depend on what the German people are willing to pay.It would be a similar situation.The third and final point: the role of the European Union.I want to highlight the extraordinary role that the special envoy has played to this region, Mr. Moratinos, as well as the financing we have made there, Mr. Commissioner Patten.You know that you will always find support in this Parliament, also for your proposal.We will be present when financed.But we must also play a political role and this role cannot be played by Mr. Moratinos alone in this region.Here the presidency of the Council has to act and the Mister PESC has to travel to the region.And we, as the Russians have done, we have to invite the protagonists of the peace process.Then we will play the role that corresponds to our participation and contribution.

When it comes to security, my group will always support initiatives that increase security in transport.As recent events have demonstrated, we still have a lot to do on this subject.Mrs. President, I would like to make some observations.First, I want to thank the speaker for his extraordinarily precise and technical work in this report, and secondly, I want to thank the commission for the proposal he has submitted.It is the harmonization of examinations, but in fact we are talking about the minimum requirements.It is a shame in a certain sense.The importance of road transport security, by rail and navigable is naturally very large and, given the international character of transport, the training of security counselors should be harmonized, as well as, for example, the requirements of the future ADR.That is important, but so is the control and there are of course several reasons why we must dedicate special attention.Look at accidents on the road in recent years.For example in Belgium, the Netherlands and some other countries where, having fog, trucks with dangerous goods were still on the route when they should have stopped at that time.O Ships from Eastern Europe docked next to other vessels where there is a more than evident danger situation.In addition, it follows from the investigations carried out in the ports in Belgium, in Finland, but also in Japan, that 50% of the containers with partially dangerous goods are not delivered correctly.In other words, it is of great importance.When contemplating the situation of the security counselors, we see that in some countries it is mandatory to have these security advisers since January 1 of this year.At this time this causes great control problems especially in small businesses, because they cannot pay it.Then, or they will reject these goods or mix them with others and that will cause some problems.Therefore, an evaluation of these activities is being requested in the form of annual reports, business analysis, which could be incorporated eventually in ISO 9002 certificates. The rules are now control.Let me mention a last issue.Regarding control, we have to reach good agreements with the countries of Eastern Europe, because until July 1, 2001, that is, within a year and a half, they will not participate in the treaties on this matter.This gives them a temporary competitive advantage.It is not serious in itself, but what we should do especially is to give priority to the security aspects in the transport of goods by road, by rail and by navigable and incorporate this part of the community heritage as quickly as possible and present it to the candidate countries to adhesion.Mrs. President, in this Parliament rightly pays attention to the importance of transportation security.The growing amounts of goods that pass through Europe, entail risks of which we are conscious and sometimes unconscious, for the staff and for the social environment.

President!"It is miserable in terms of development cooperation between the European Union." This was to be read in a newspaper article on the Union's development policy in a past week.This assessment is not new.Since we deal with development cooperation in Europe, their effectiveness and quality have been questioned.Hope for improvement threatens to disappear if the Commission continues to refuse to look in the mirror.Why wasn't the critical report on the coherence of development policy published?An important conclusion of this report concerned the contradictions inherent in European politics.In contrast to development policy, European politics is particularly in the areas of trade and agriculture.We do not succeed in making a serious contribution to the development of the least developed countries.This is related to the different views in terms of development cooperation in the individual countries of the Union.We are no longer allowed to consider development and cooperation as an instrument of external relationships, but it is to be assessed as an independent policy area.I advocate a transparent, solidarity and efficient development policy.As long as European approaching to the development problem causes inefficiency and waste of money, it is advisable to assign a greater role to the Member States.Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to send the European Parliament as quickly as possible to the European Parliament so that we too can think about possible solutions.President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues!I think this initiative is useful and sensible in every respect.As several colleagues have already mentioned, we always experience situations in which there is a great contradiction between what we want to achieve with development and cooperation policy, and what we can withdraw with other sectoral policies that pursue opposite interests in the development of the same countries.We are not only talking about the concrete effects of our joint measures, on tourism, the environment, agriculture, fishing, industry.In general - and this is the worst - we talk about the contradictions between our economic and trade policy measures and our defense policy measures.Ultimately, there are a number of situations that are contradictory.In my opinion, the contradictions in the area of ​​community policies are not quite as pronounced.However, they are more pronounced for certain objectives and industries of some member states.We have to be clear about that.On the one hand, we often accept resolutions about peace processes in other parts of the world, such as recently in the case of Indonesia, a case screaming.Then again we find that some European countries had delivered weapons and war material to them.For me, these are the most serious contradictions in this whole area, they are more serious than those that result from a certain incompatibility of the sectoral policies, which are also available.Of course, we know that there are always contradictions between several policies within a certain country.This is normal.At the level of the European Union, we must also be aware that there will be contradictions between the individual community policies, in this case in development policy.We have to be aware that these contradictions are available and that we have to reduce them as far as possible.

The European Union stressed its total support for the United Nations efforts related to the need for a court to judge former leaders of the Red Jamers.At the same time we greet the continued dialogue between the two parties.I feel comforted by the optimism of Kofi Annan, general secretary of the United Nations, on the possibilities of an agreement about the proposed court.The Commission will continue to raise issues related to the rule of law, democratic principles and human rights before the Cambodian authorities through the CE-Camboya Cooperation Agreement that entered into force on November 1 of last year.It has been very useful to discuss twice on human rights in a couple of days.I hope we have other opportunities, but I trust that in the coming years we have less examples of your abuse.Thank you very much, Mr. Patten.The debate is closed.The vote will take place at 6:00 p.m.Environmental catastrophe in the waters of the Danube in accordance with the agenda, the joint debate of the following resolution proposals is carried out: B5-0164/2000 of Mr. Leinen, in the name of the Group of the Party of the European Socialists, B5-0167/2000 of Messrs. Maaten and Thors, in the name of the group of the liberals, democrats and reformistsB5-0168/2000 of Messrs. Oostlander and Grossetête, on behalf of the European Popular Group (Democrat-Christian) and the European Democrats, B5-0173/2000 of Messrs. Papayannakis and Sjöstedt, in the name of the Confederal Group of the European Left European Left/Left Nordic Green, B5-0179/2000of Mrs. Schroedter and others, on behalf of the Green Group/European Free Alliance, on the environmental catastrophe caused by the dumping of cyanide, from a Romanian gold mine, in the waters of the Lapus, Somes, Tisza and Danube rivers.Mr. President, this week we have debated the framework of the Water.Well, the catastrophe that has occurred in Romania demonstrates once again to what extent it is necessary that we take water protection seriously.This catastrophe has put on the table a series of important issues that affect us as a European Union.We congratulate that the European Union has committed to help decontaminating rivers.It is equally important that environmental awareness is reinforced, both in Romania and in central and eastern Europe in general.For all these reasons, we are glad that Commissioner Wallström has hurried to visit the region, since her visit can result in the benefit of such awareness.After all, it is a country candidate for adhesion and this catastrophe joins the existing concern about whether all candidate countries will assimilate in time the regulations on the EU environment.Who pollutes must pay.I wonder if the European Union can carry this type of expenses to the "jeans" of the environment that are manifested in the so -called "savage east", benefiting from the permissive environmental legislation of those countries.I would be in favor of that option.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, not every day are the same, but ecological catastrophes, unfortunately, are all the same.There are reasons to be disturbed, once again, for this serious pollution that today affects the fourth wet zone of Europe, in order of importance.The Danube delta is in danger.

Commission's communication recommends a greater exchange of experiences, as well as the implementation of a high -level group and benchmarking.In addition, the social protection report must be published each year and be examined at the same time as the employment report.That's good, but that is not enough.We offer a procedure similar to the Luxembourg process.Clear guidelines and indicators are necessary, while Member States must develop methods in national action plans.We are shaping a common model, but keep subsidiarity.This social convergence is a process that will continue for a long time.Parliament must therefore be involved in work - not by entering the high -level group, but so that the representative of the Parliament can follow the work in this group and come with proposals on how to continue the process.The Commission's proposal, as well as cooperation for employment, is based on four major objectives.It is a question of: to make the system favorable to employment, to make the pension plan viable in the long term, to promote social integration and to guarantee a protection of sustainable and high level health.All these points are important.In our report, we particularly highlighted the importance of fighting poverty in the EU and finding indicators as quickly as possible in order to advance in this area.Equality between men and women does not have its own pillar.This is mainstreaming in question.The aspects of equality between men and women must therefore find themselves in the four pillars.We took note of this.We submit a multitude of proposals so that, for example, we go to individual social protection systems, that parental leave gives the right to social security benefits, that the possibilities of reconciling family life and professional life are improved and that basic old age pensions ensure a decent standard of living.These proposals promote above all women.In addition to this strategy of European social convergence, a concrete plan is necessary in terms of legislative work in the social field, as well as proposals for a framework agreement in the context of social dialogue with a concrete calendar.We expect the Parliament to present this in its proposal for a social action program.Social convergence is also necessary with a view to enlargement, on the one hand to strengthen the social model and, on the other hand, to remove the risks of social dumping.The Commission must consider the development of a specific action program relating to social policy in the context of enlargement.We had a constructive discussion at the Commission.We had many amendments, but we managed to agree on a report.The number of amendments subject to the vote of the Parliament is now reduced to fifteen.This is explained by the fact that we have significant convergence.Part of these amendments come back from reading to the Commission and I will reject them.I will also reject the amendments deposited by the TDI group, because I do not think they bring something to the report.

We have all heard some of the stories from the building of the Council of Ministers in Brussels.Nor do I see clearly to what extent we will achieve some form of convergence on defense expenses, since some member states spend considerably more than others.And, in fact, some Member States are not oriented towards mobility.They are very static in their military and inadequate forces for that kind of war.Perhaps I could address Mr. Patten and ask, from the point of view of the conflict prevention work that we are going to carry out, to what extent we can examine situations causing long -term conflicts, such as environmental degradation and water shortage and include them in the main policies of the EU, in particular in development, because it is meaningless to try to react quickly to something that we have taken years to prepare.And finally, allow me to also make Mrs. Schroedter's observations, in the sense that we need a parliamentary dimension in this defense development.We cannot limit ourselves to leaving it in the hands of governments.When Mr. Solana spoke for the last time in this Parliament, I adopted an extremely critical position at the fact that he barely mentioned the idea of ​​conflict prevention and today he is talking about this prevention here, but not any proposal to make it a reality seriously.We talk a lot and with pride that in sixty days you can prepare a contingent of 60,000 soldiers for a whole year, but we currently have crisis in Europe and its borders and elsewhere that this union is not addressing, which is abject.What we need are 60,000 civil police to try to address these situations.Mr. Solana has not given us any information about the springs that will be used in relation to Russia and Chechnya.Mr. Solana has not told us anything about whether he is doing or the European Union any diplomatic intervention seriously - diplomatic interventions seriously - to stop butcher shop in Chechnya.We have wide gaps in our defense, in principle, of human rights.We made a collection of the ability to intervene in Kosovo and now we are creating absolute chaos in that province, not sending the right resources and staff to address the situation, which demonstrates our inability to approach conflict prevention.Thus, I would like Mr. Solana to explain to this assembly the position of the European Union in relation to Chehenia.What are we going to seriously end up with that atrocious situation?We have springs that we could use with Russia, if we proposed it, but we have set out not to do it.Mr. President, Mr. Alto Representative, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to ask you two questions, Mr. Solana.How can you, with any credibility, continue the deepening of collaboration in military and defense matters if member states are not willing to comply with common commitments?

I hope that all these problems can be addressed and treated in the field of discussion that is currently being held on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.On an external level, I believe that most of the points that we have included in the resolution provide us with a fairly approximate vision of reality and does not invite precisely, Mr. President, to optimism, since aspects important issue.The absence of the Council and almost all the deputies of Parliament makes us understand how great the space that separates the noble, important and useful statements, from the formal point of view, of the concrete application of the issue of human rights in the field of daily policy.I believe that this Parliament, starting with the contribution that the European Union will give to the gin meeting, must fill out this space and contribute not only in the plane of the enunciation of the principles, but also in that of truth and even loyalty.

The discussion and negotiation that we held with the Council and the Commission have won around three issues: the budget, the calendar and the Committeeology.Your rapporteur wants to particularly place the emphasis on the commitment and flexibility shown by everyone to bring the positions on budget closer so that from an initial endowment of 9 million euros of the B7-6201 line, which meant a total of 73 million euros throughout the period, we have reached an agreement that provides for 249 million euros for the next seven years, starting from the 30 million euros already foreseen in the budget.Budget agreement - which implicitly includes an agreement on the times - the differences have coagulated around issues of the Committeeology due to historical positions of Parliament and the Council which, in view of the future - and in order not to insist on the problems indicated by the honorable Wijkman - in my opinion should be revised with an interinstitutional agreement to make the parliamentary legislative procedure more agile and fluid.I conclude by recommending to the assembly the acceptance of the amendments nos.1, 7, 9, 10, 11 and 12 and the rejection of others since, if they were accepted, they would cancel the agreement achieved after the discussions held with the Commission and the Council and would oblige us to start the entire negotiation procedure again, paralyzing certain projects and actions to be carried out, and undoubtedly causing serious problems to the conservation policy and reconstitution of the tropical forests that we want to develop.Mr. President, I find that the speaker, honorable Fernndndez Martn, who preceded me is right on many points of his relationship.Before anything else, for all budget lines it is very important to talk about their respective financial allocation.Exactly as for the report we have just discussed, I am not satisfied with the limited duration, but, in consideration of the many projects at risk, this argument is excellent for aiming for an agreement with the Council as soon as possible short.As for the Wijkman report, I am in favor of the Split Comitology, proposed by the speaker, that is to deal with the strategic lines by resorting to a management procedure and the measures concerning the implementation of the projects in a consultative committee.A point that I consider particularly important is the emphasis placed in different amendments - for example to amendment no.2 and to amendment n.4 - On the active participation of the populations that depend on the forest and the local communities.In my opinion, it is a truly essential point, especially in the context of sustainable management of tropical forests and other forests in developing countries.

They alone are able to invent policies likely to modify structures that have been developed by men for men.Because it is indeed to the structural discrimination that women are most faced, whether in politics or on the job market.It is therefore up to European political parties to open up to women.Moreover, article 191 of the Treaty (ex 138 a) underlines, I quote, their "important role as a factor of integration within the Union".This article continues by affirming that "they contribute to the formation of a European awareness and identity, as well as to the expression of the political will of the citizens of the Union".If such a provision has no legal value, it is no less highly symbolic.It gives political parties an important role in the construction of a democratic Europe.This can pass, for example, through the implementation of positive actions, through the promotion of parity within our political parties.Some parties have, on the occasion of the 1999 European elections, presented joint lists.This is a good practice, which must be generalized.I do not know if there is a link of cause and effect, but the fact remains that the proportion of women deputies in the European Parliament increased from 25.7 % in 1994 to 29.9 % in 1999. In addition, he has been chaired by a woman since the 1999 elections. I will end by taking up the conclusions drawn from the April 1999 conference organized by the Commission, entitled "women and men in power".Equality between men and women is not a problem that only concerns women, it is an issue that affects our whole society!Progress has recently been made in the increase in the number of women present in the Union's decision -making bodies.In our own institution, 30 % of elected representatives are today women, including the president of the European Parliament herself.Finland has also just elected a woman as a presidency.On average, almost a quarter of the governments of the Member States and just over a fifth of their parliaments is made up of women.These rates are still far from satisfactory, in particular given that the figures vary strongly from one Member State to another: women in the Nordic countries are much more represented in positions of responsibility and in decision -making processes.This situation is more a reflection of respect for the quality and competence of the contribution of women to the company than the result of quotas set.My group is not favorable to the use of quotas in general because, in the long term, they may go against the aim sought, or even to undermine the cause which they aim to support.We nevertheless recognize that experiences vary from one Member State to another and that certain recourse to such measures are sometimes justified, as a temporary remedy, with a view to rebalancing the representation of women where they are clearly underrepresented.We could support the resolution on women in the decision-making process, adopted in order to commemorate the international day of women on March 8, for which the Liberal group filed ten amendments and relaxed the reference to quota in accordance with the approach advanced above.

In the case of Türkiye, the situation is different: the plant does not yet exist and then I have already said that Turkey has joined the Treaty on non -proliferation and the nuclear security agreement.If in the development phase of the nuclear power plant, there will be reasons of concern about security. We will discuss it with Turkey.If we should conclude that Turkey is planning a nuclear power plant incompatible with European security rules, we would behave as we did with Lithuania, Slovakia and Bulgaria.I believe it is a right of the parliamentarian to demonstrate his concerns or fears.I don't share these concerns.I believe that Turkey fully recognizes the rules and criteria of the nuclear security convention and the treaty on non -proliferation, but it is out of doubt that European public opinion has some concern and it seems to me more than just to discuss it in this parliament.Question n.29, of the honorable (H-0786/99): object: weapons with depleted uranium has carried out the Studies Commission on the effects that transfrontier pollution due to the use of weapons with impoverished uranium during the Kosovar conflict could have on the EU states?Otherwise, for what reason?In the name of the commission, Mrs. Commissioner Wallström has the right to thank her, Mr Bowe, for her question.The European Commission has studied the effects of the conflict on the environment from the first actions of NATO.Already last June the Commission financed the first study carried out by the Regional Environmental Center for Central and Eastern Europe and concluded that no large -scale ecological catastrophe has occurred.None of the tests collected later or subsequent analyzes denied that first evaluation.The Commission was also strictly associated with the development of the recent report published by the United Nations Environmental Program - Balkan Task Force.This is the most detailed and more exhaustive relationship so far developed on the consequences for the environment of the conflict in Kosovo and I recommend reading it to those who have not yet studied it.The use of weapons with depleted uranium is one of the various issues addressed and the relationship is also available on the net.The Balkan Task Force has been hindered by the lack or scarcity of information about the real use of these weapons during the conflict.The exploratory mission of the Balkan Task Force in Kosovo has not found any contamination signal.However, this does not exclude the possibility that some areas of Kosovo were contaminated by the depleted uranium.On the basis of the theoretical assessment coupled to the exploratory mission on site, the relationship comes to the conclusion that any risks, if there are, would be limited to the area surrounding the target.The stability pact for Sudoriental Europe provides for further initiatives;A special regional plan of environmental remediation is also being developed which will constitute the reference framework for emergency assistance in the event of damage caused by a conflict, if this intervention should become necessary.Mr. President, first of all I wish to thank Mrs. Commissioner for the very useful answer he gave me.

We have not heard that beyond the proclaimed and positive objective of eradication of children's poverty, the autonomy of people would be reinforced thanks to the establishment, in each member state, of minimum decent income that would be part of a true strategy to fight exclusion.We have not heard that the objective of full employment would include support for local and regional initiatives, to the hidden sector of the solidarity economy, to the effective and coordinated reduction of the duration of work and would be accompanied by strong demands in regard to the quality and durability of these works.We have not heard that the long -awaited growth would rely on the choice of lasting development.We do not find in the document of the Portuguese Presidency or in the strategic orientations 2000 of the Commission the slightest footprint of the legislative project in the social area, to reinforce the protection of workers against dismissals or to fight against social dumping.Of course, we can only sympathize with the concern of the Council and the Commission to finally provide the European Community, after the Single Market, after the euro, of a political project proposed to all its residents, but the new governance that you use, abusively in my view, does not have the participatory democratic ambition to which the emerging European civil society aspires.Mrs. President, Mr. Prime Minister and President of the Council, the situation in the Union and in the generality of the Member States is to raise legitimate concerns, despite the conjunctural economic recovery.The unemployment rate is maintained at fairly high levels, long -term unemployment is permanently aggravated and employment levels are extraordinarily low, elements that are also accompanied by and aggravated by the growing precariousness of employment and that denote, in fact, a social situation that particularly affects women and young people and that is dramatically marked by about 50 million excluded.On the eve of the Extraordinary Council dedicated to these problems, the fundamental issue that arises, for that reason, is to know whether or not there is political will to modify such a situation.Or if, on the contrary, we are only facing one more initiative without consequences, which will be added to successive planes, strategies and summits already dedicated in the past to that topic and of which no substantive modification was.In our opinion, it is not only necessary to modify this state of affairs, but also, it is possible to do so.Necessary, because employment, and quality and rights, constitutes a fundamental right of the human person.Possible, if their true causes are addressed, which, in our opinion, are inseparable from neoliberal drift that has been characterized by the fundamental orientations, in particular in the macroeconomic sphere, which has exponents in the priority granted to the stability pact and the criteria of nominal convergence and, consequently, in the secondarization of social cohesion, generally accompanied by the completelabor deregation, incentive to privatizations, mergers and companies, usually causing unemployment, but also by a deeply restrictive budget policy in community and national plans.

We want the European Union level to come to uniform regulations for shipping with all its technical, economic, social and ecological aspects.The dangerous practices of cheap flags must be prohibited in the ports and waters of the 15 Member States and the 13 countries willing to join.We also speak together with the UDB for the creation of coastal guards and the use of sea inspectors that are subject to the direct supervision of the affected shipping areas in order to control the strict compliance of European legal regulations.The assumed resolution points in this direction and has therefore found the unrestricted support of our parliamentary group.I am pleased that the resolution on the effects of the oil plague emitted by the Erika, whose elaboration our faction has made a large contribution, was actually unanimously accepted.Since, in contrast to our previous resolution, it takes a closer look at the extent of the catastrophe, which turns out to be larger every day than the first impressions suggest, it is more demanding, precise and urgent.The overall assessment of the damage caused by all areas of fishing, marine cultures and aquaculture is currently hardly possible.However, it is certain that they are considerable.The balance sheet is worsened every day by new dirt.The losses are not only in sales declines, but also in the form of financial loss.The impairment of the good reputation of marine products cannot currently be expressed in digits.In addition, there are damage caused by the upstream and downstream areas (fish wholesalers, suppliers, tourism, etc.), as well as the costs of the local authorities for the elimination of dirt and the repositioning in the tourism business.Fishing and tourism, the two closely related essential sources of income of most regions of our Atlantic coast, are both severely affected.Therefore, it is necessary, as in our resolution, to emphasize the cause principle, supplemented by the duty of the polluter to remedy damage.It is the duty of the cause to pay for the cleaning of the areas dirty by its fault and for the restoration of the ecological balance disturbed by his guilt.With regard to the compensation procedure, those affected are very worried, because the first payments made by the FIPOL are limited to 25 %.This is a scandal.Of course, each victim must be 100 % compensated.It would be absolutely unthinkable to want to impose part of the damage to the victims, which they arise exclusively by the negligence of the person who was neglected.Furthermore, the initiatives taken by some local regional authorities, such as the Department of Vendée, are welcomed in our resolution to capture the exact condition of the coast before the first oil carpet arrives.This procedure is exemplary because it enables accelerated compensation of the victims, whether private individuals or local authorities.And finally, our resolution makes it clear that in the area of ​​marine safety, the vicious circle of general irresponsibility must be put to an end, this contradictory system of mutual paralysis, in which the states and the Union are of mutual advantage of the responsibility.Everyone has to perform the tasks that he arrives.The Commission, whose American reflex did not come into play this time, must quickly work out a general framework for marine safety.

We know that these waste is there and how we have to deal with it, and there is no excuse for not acting.This guideline pursues three goals.First of all, we want to restrict the use of poisonous heavy metals in the production of new cars.On the other hand, we want to fix the responsibility of the manufacturers.We can no longer take care of products at the end of their life cycle, but have to rely on waste avoidance.As many of the various materials contained in the product, as many must be recovered as possible.Third, we want to achieve the recycling goals specified in this guideline.These are the three most important intentions of the directive.The material that is present in the cars does not constitute a wasteland of resources. Above all, the manufacturer's resources are dealt with in a lavish way if we do not take care of the life cycle of a car.Two questions were raised here of great importance - of course there are more, but I would like to mention the two most important ones.First of all: who should pay for that?The second question is: With this draft we weaken the competitiveness of the European automotive industry?The first question is about who should bear the costs.According to the guideline, these are primarily to be taken over by the manufacturer in accordance with the principles of manufacturer's responsibility and the principle of pollutor.However, it is clear that these costs are borne together by manufacturers and consumers.We calculated that the effort for recycling a car does not make up more than 1 % of the price for a new vehicle.Can we fool ourselves that this money disappears if the directive was not accepted?No, of course we will all have to bear the cost of destroying the environment, and that becomes much more expensive.In addition, these only fall after a long time.So the costs do not disappear, but we now make it clear where the responsibility is and how the financial effort should be distributed.Are we talking about a crisis -shaped automotive industry here?Is the discussion about an industry with low profit clashing, which we have to help by not imposing him even more?Can't the vehicle industry afford it at all?Doesn't our true intention actually be weakening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry?No, of course not!Do you think that consumers' reputation will fall silent after environmentally friendly cars and vehicles with less fuel consumption in the future?What do you think, what requirements our children and child children or the legislators of the future will put on the cars?Of course, that these must be environmentally friendly, can be recycled, use little fuel and do not pollute our environment!Only in this way can we give the vehicle industry a future.We have to create healthy incentives to recycle waste and reuse materials and that we can exist in competition with environmentally friendly vehicles with low fuel consumption.The fact that the European automotive industry is already well advanced compensates it to it that even more cars roll through Europe for which it has to take responsibility.These are not horrendous sums or an unsolvable task.

The previous experiences have sufficiently proven that linear regulations on personnel loss and incentives, voluntarily extinguishing from the work process, often had undesirable effects.I remember that workers who had retired at the Belgian telephone company had to be called back so that the company did not lose too much know-how and experience.The discussion point will undoubtedly be the reduction in personnel when the postal services liberalization.It should not be forgotten that offers for the voluntary departure above all take on the employees who work under pressure or can easily find a new job, in other words, they are often forces that the company in question itself.In my opinion, it would testify to a consideration of human resources if the Commission would take some of these worries to heart, so that the liberalization of such a sensitive sector as the post is largely socially acceptable.President!Postal services and post offices currently seem to be a very current topic in parliament, and rightly so if you have their importance.Just last week, the newly elected MP held his maiden speech on this topic by our partners from the European Free Alliance, the Plaid Cymru, the Welsh party, in the parliament of the United Kingdom in Westminster.There was also a debate in the Scottish parliament, which was particularly referred to the role of post offices, especially in rural areas, as part of the service offerings and the survival of rural communities.Liberalization does not represent the only potential threat to the services of post offices. As we have heard, post offices in Scotland have to do far more than the post.Governments and some local authorities traditionally use them as a position to pay pensions and other services and also as a place where rents, local taxes, etc. are paid.But to the extent that the modernization of public finances' systems more and more leads to electronic payment transactions through direct debits and transfer, the life offices of the postal offices in the country are threatened.If a post office in the country, which usually also includes the only shop on site, closes, then this can become a great danger to the survival of the community and social cohesion.Instead of admitting that post offices are infiltrated by liberalization or the modernization of systems, the governments and the Commission should promote and support a branched network of post offices and regard them as an assistant on which one can build up by a location and services to be achieved conveniently for the residents.President!The post is responsible for ensuring that the post is delivered everywhere in the city and in the country, a tariff for everyone every day.Post was a public matter for 150 years and, just like public transport and power supply, a core task of national governments.Such obvious and useful core tasks provide people a reason to choose.They show significantly less interest in a government that does not take care of such things.

island regions get back on their feet.Tourism also creates additional jobs and thus causes an amusement of employment, especially when it comes to the most sensitive social groups, namely women and adolescents.In my opinion, however, this is blatantly contradicting the fact that there is no European tourist policy.Due to the lack of legal basis, no measures can be taken for this area.Because Article 308 (ex-article 235) repeatedly used, according to which a legal act requires unanimity, it was not even possible to adopt a program of eight million ECU for five years and fifteen Member States.The measures that have so far occasionally been taken were fragmentary and therefore inefficient, the regulations were subject to the dictation of parallel, for example, the consumer
