euro is enforced before it is brought into circulation, whereby a legislative gap is closed in some Member States.I would like to expressly support the rapporteur in the fact that it is necessary to expand this criminal protection to the national currencies, which, after being removed from circulation, can also be exchanged.Each Member State must ensure the introduction of effective, expedient and deterrent criminal sanctions for the actions provided for in the draft of the framework decision as a criminal offense.As for the proposal to determine a maximum limit of eight years for prison for the first time, which is used in all 15 Member States at the same time.This takes further steps towards the goal of developing and shaping the European Union as a space of freedom, security and It is evident that the incidence of trembling in the sheep species has been a factor that has contributed to the general problem.I greet the legal basis that has been established and the comprehensive approach of the new provisions that, I hope, will allow to correct this situation.We must guarantee that nothing enters into the food chain or the compound feeds that can cause in the future situations such as those we have already known.No one wants the situation of farmers to be repeated following the EEB.We must introduce the most strict provisions possible and we must ensure that they work.It is of the utmost importance for the producer, as well as for the consumer who restores confidence, and the only means of doing so is to rigorously stop the problem and solve it.The EEB has not disappeared.We can find it in some countries.I do not want to point out any particular country, but many countries currently face problems similar to those we had in the United Kingdom.The problem will remain for some time.We must guarantee that the entire system of identification of the origin and monitoring of the animal from born until it is sacrificed and throughout the food chain is part of said mechanism for restoration of trust.If we are not able to achieve it, we will face enormous problems in the future.Finally, I believe for a long time, because I come from an agricultural environment, that if we had fed the animals properly and if the feed had been made based on the appropriate compounds, the EEB would never have occurred.The person in charge was not at any time the farmer, those who caused this problem were feed producers, and we have the obligation to ensure that it never repeats itself again..(In) Mr. President, I am glad that this opportunity to deal with a subject in which there is good cooperation between Parliament and the Commission, namely the fight against the EET.I would also like to thank Mr. Böge for the work he has done on this matter.It has been considerably advanced on our proposal for the directive of the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with article 152 of the Treaty, regarding the prevention and control of the tremble.This proposal deals with all the dangers of the EET in all animals and in all phases of the production chain.Today I am here to listen to your opinions on the first step of this process aimed at establishing a really integral community system for the control of these diseases.In the proposal that concerns us, I propose the elimination of all community provisions currently in force regarding the trembling in sheep and goat species, and transfer them to the framework of the directive proposal.Next, detailed provisions would be introduced in said framework.I have been able to know that Parliament welcomes this initiative to formulate a unique text, as follows from its interventions this afternoon.I hope to deal with any other additional improvement that Parliament wishes to suggest within the framework of the legislation proposal, especially after the reference made by Mrs. Roth-Behrendt to your own report and opinion in this regard.

Following this singular procedure, Parliament refrains from imputing responsibility for the 1997 provisions where it resides, that is to say with the old commission.It was the 1996 accounts that dropped the old commission and accounts for 1997 are just as overwhelming.There is therefore no reason to grant the discharge.Regarding the decision to close the accounts, we will be able to reflect during the vote and, finally, with regard to the proposal for resolution, we especially insist on the many recommendations which have been made rightly and we will vote for.Mr. President, the discharge decision for the 1997 financial year was postponed because the previous commission had already presented its resignation to the date scheduled for this decision and only managed current affairs.Now, Ms. Van der Laan, to which we should pay tribute to all the work she has accomplished, invites us in her report to be discharged to the Commission for the year 1997. We may wonder why the current commission must receive discharge for the execution of the general budget of the previous commission - Mr. Camre also reported -, all the more since the discharge for the year 96 was refused.But it is so.Since its entry into office, the new commission must assume responsibility for the acts, but also for the shortcomings of the past.As the system of collegial responsibility which prevails within the Commission allows us to make in all and for all three decisions in matters of discharge, namely a grant, a postponement or a refusal, the fact that four commissioners having belonged to the previous commission are again found today in this body has no more impact.This question should have been asked during the inauguration of the new commission.If the Parliament approves this week the proposal made by the Budget Control Commission and grants the discharge, the Commission would however be wrong to consider this decision as a white check.I am in fact of opinion that the third part of Ms. Van der Laan's report, namely the resolution proposal, is the most important.The obligations it contains, taken up under eight different titles, are an integral part of the discharge.It is on its execution that our decision depends.During the discharge for the following financial year - the year 1998 is already on the exam - Parliament will have to check very carefully if it has not congratulated the commission in a somewhat too premature manner.We will have a sidelines from the moment when the commission will present its reform program.The discharge for the 1998 exercise will allow us to know if efficiency, transparency, responsibility as well as an attitude of opening in relation to the discharge authorities prevail.Mr. President, we all know that Parliament has decided to postpone the discharge for the 1997 financial year while waiting to know the internal reform commitments that the new commission would adopt.

For three quarters, these are children under the age of five.This does not depend on deficiencies of food, but rather on what we have talked about several times today, that is, by growing poverty.The AIDS is such a big problem in Africa today that more people die from this disease than in conflicts.I hope the minister will take the time to go into this special point.The USA already have medication, but they are not ready to sell these medications at a price that is affordable for the people of Africa.I would like to ask the minister what he will do in Ethiopia in relation to the emerging location.The country suffers from droughts and misfortunes, and in six months the same problems will occur as a few years ago when thousands of people died during a famine.At the same time, the war between Eritrea and Ethiopia continues unabated;The European armaments industry delivers plenty of weapons, and then we come and deliver the food.Mr. MP, you have to understand that, first of all, I do not agree with the way you interpret my colleague's speech at the meeting of the Committee on Development.There is no contradiction between these points of view, on the contrary.In the program of a presidency, we cannot do something like an exhaustive inventory of all possible and imaginable situations in relation to all major problems, especially in the context of the outdoor relationships, at most in a seizure of megalomania.It would be easy to do something like you understand.You only need to take a flow of development and write down all questions one after the other.We are responsible enough to recognize that we can only accept the questions that we can treat as part of our presidency and within the framework of the possibilities of governments at the council level - and one must always be aware of it.We have to understand that there are limits here in relation to the enforcement options, especially in the national guide programs.The MP has pointed out the problem of Ethiopia, which is included in the framework of the national guidelines, but as you know, there are various measures for AIDS fighting at community level, and in this regard you are right, Mr. MP, probably the United States will also do nothing better.Incidentally, I think that Europe does not have to worry about development aid policy, and for the simple reason because our behavior in this area withstands every comparison with the United States.The MP's question then passed the problem of the negative effects the armor has.This is a problem of further political importance, which is probably the framework of the actual question, but that the Council will of course discuss in the future if it intends to tackle it in a special connection.Is the advice of social problems that cause the EU's food exports below the producer prices in the developing countries?Does the chair intend to do something on this matter?Since the questioner is not present, request No. 13 is obsolete.I would like to thank the incumbent Council President and personally welcome him to the Portuguese government's presidency.Allow me to pronounce my recognition for his eloquence and his well -founded knowledge of European affairs.

This situation is generally caused by the Union's economic and social policy.Width sections of the Union emphasize this policy as dangerous and anti -people.Unfortunately, the new guidelines go in the same direction, and nothing indicates that their implementation will change something.President, dear colleagues!Allow me to say a few short words here to emphasize two points that these reports remind us of and those in the idea we have from the Union play an essential strategic role.The first is the relevant and central importance that we still attach to the principle of economic and social cohesion.We express our concern about reports that we can see that the importance of this goal in the commission's views increasingly subsides.We are still of the opinion that the economic and social cohesion is a central goal of the Union.Secondly, I agree with what I have already heard of a colleague about the topic of the islands here, and I would also like to draw attention to the areas in an extremely outskirts.In the future, we would be happy about more courage in the treatment of the topic of the areas in an extremely outskirts, as is the case in the case of my home country for the island groups of the Azores and Madeiras.I take this opportunity to ask whether the Commission can inform us about the reasons why the Commission's report about the areas in extreme outskirts, which has been expected in Parliament for a long time.President!First of all, my thanks to the rapporteur, also for the willing to take up suggestions on our part in the report.Mr. President, my very worshiped ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner!With the help of guidelines, the Member States should be offered an orientation to achieve the reform goals as part of the programming.However, the commission's requirements in this regard represent their claim to give orientation, but rather represent an offer catalog of possible measures within the framework of the political fields. To give direction and set priorities is their actual sense.I am in conformity with the rapporteur that the commission document unfortunately contains too few recommendations to the member states for administrative references, and underlining claims such as concentration in the event of negotiations on the promotion of a favorable environment for labor -intensive small and medium -sized companies, on a clear objective for alternative sources of financing, including regulations for risk capital and private financing, on operational start aids, including new onesInformation technologies and investments in innovative areas.My special support applies to an amendment to my faction on Section 10, which should ensure an appropriate inclusion of the private sector when planning and implementing the projects.I would be happy, Ms. Schroedter, if you included this change in change, especially from the aspect of subsidiarity in your positive considerations.President, Mr. Commissioner!In the committee for employment and social affairs, we unanimously took the view that the support of the interventions of the structure and cohesion funds in favor of better employment opportunities for the unemployed and equality between men and women is of strategic and priority importance.Unfortunately, the excellent report Schroedter did not consider this idea, although there are numerous evidence of this - we will see this later in the report - how these funds really help the less developed regions to bridge the distance between them and the most developed regions in Europe.

Mr. Commissioner, Fischler, the development in rural areas can and has to respond to three approaches, specifically, to the maintenance of jobs, land care and, not ultimately, in the care of local In the committee, the Commission referred to the fact that it provides to submit a Novel Food Directive in the future.However, this should not be an obstacle to make the alignment in this case, so that there is no legal uncertainty here with different guidelines.Therefore, we assume that you will also accept our amendment to this genetically modified organisms.The fact that the old text still stands in this directive 70/524 has to do with the fact that the seed guideline in 1986 was presented in parliament and that we negotiated with the Commission until 1988, while the report on this Directive 1994 was treated, and obviously the parliament did not allow the genetically modified organisms to have the same importance as I later had a report.Therefore, we believe, Mr. Commissioner Byrne, that the amendments submitted by us are also accepted by you with regard to the legal basis.If this is not the case, we have to reserve the right to transfer this report back into the committee, so that, like us, like we did the Saatgut Directive, to negotiate with you via this sensitive point, whereby I once again indicate that the text that we have now worked out is valid for your and for our legal service as a compromise.So we don't have to negotiate the text again, but we only have to include this text in this directive.I am excited to be commissioner Byrne, what you will say about our suggestions!President!Mr. Commissioner!Is the regulation of the additives in feed a matter of competition or consumer policy?It is a question of competition for the commission and the legal committee.Certainly we have to take into account the competitiveness of the feed industry by harmonizing the regulations for substances approved before and after 1988.An increase in feed prices must be prevented, and therefore the change applications 4 and 5 must be supported by Mr. Doyle.First and foremost, however, how Mr. Graefe zu Baringdorf formulated it in his report is a consumer policy topic.Food security must have an absolute priority in all discussions about animal nutrition.When we speak of the transparency of the food chain, this applies from the pitch fork to the die fork, and consequently consumer protection in animal feeding is consequently starting.Antibiotics, growth promoters and genetically modified organisms, ultimately come into the food chain of humans.As a consequence of the dioxin scandal, it was clear to all of us that we finally had to step out of this dirty corner.The regulation of the additives in animal nutrition is a step in the right direction.According to Article 152 of the EC Treaty, we are obliged to remedy causes for the risk to human health.The emphasis is clearly on causes.Consequently, we have to close the cock to the original sources of pollutants - harmful additives in animal feed.Otherwise, I find, we find the symptoms, but do not combat the causes.The population is particularly critical of the use of GMO.We have to face the growing awareness of the population to GMO and accordingly regulate the use in feed.First, there is an additive made of genetically modified organisms or if it contains such organisms, this additive may only be approved if it is harmless to human health and the environment.

Mr President, this initiative is becoming more important as to how the economic and social problems in the cities of Europe intensify and their citizens are increasingly getting the impression that the administration of their city or its quarter is becoming increasingly off.In addition, there is the profound social change due to the expansion of the European Union.We therefore have to endeavor to revive the economic revival and social cohesion of our cities in good time.Coping with these problems is also urgent in view of the great radiation of the cities to the surrounding region and its historical and cultural role.However, the commitment and participation of all citizens as well as the mobilization of the less active social groups and those that are particularly affected by the effects of the economic and social crisis are necessary for the success of this project.At this point we would like to note how important the balanced participation of women or their organizations is to plan and implement the programs as part of the Urban initiative.As a committee for the rights of women and equal opportunities, we also point out that infrastructure measures that make the professional activity of women easier, especially with regard to the compatibility of professional and family obligations, as well as generally institutions that have to fund solidarity between generations that promote social solidarity.The efficient implementation of this initiative could have a multiplier effect, because this may have similar projects to be stimulated at regional and local level.This would make it possible to increase their political importance, because women must finally feel the effects of European politics in a practical way in their daily life.President!In our committee, we welcomed the fact that the Commission proposed the better integration of local communities and ethnic minorities as well as the increase in security and crime prevention as priorities for the Urban program.We considered it necessary in the committee that an economic and social revival of urban areas must go hand in hand with the creation of an atmosphere of tolerance towards minorities, so that measures that are suitable for reducing racism and xenophobia must be an integral part of the programs to be financed within the framework of urban.We have considered an increase in the feeling of security of the citizens, and thus combating everyday crime in urban crime, for a central task in reviving urban areas.Our committee has determined that innovative and efficient fighting and prevention requires differentiated measures at the local level;This includes the inclusion of crime prevention in urban planning, measures to prevent youth crime, the reintegration of criminals and models for effective cooperation between different actors at the local level, e.g.B. police, judiciary or social services.As a committee, we unanimously adopted our recommendation because it was very important for us to continue urban - which was successfully carried out in the past - because we assume that in the European Union we will only be able to realize a peaceful coexistence of all residents of the European Union in the long term.For this reason, such programs are welcome.For the largest of the four community initiatives, namely Interreg III, I would like to point out the concerns of the committee for employment and social affairs.

Why didn't the advice informed us of it?Why didn't the Commission informed us of this formal request from Macedonia?Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, from a political point of view, the Balkans are not simply a dark Spelonca.Just look at the considerable positive developments that have been recorded in recent years - difficult - in the Republic of Macedonia.The frightening spiral of ethnic violence in the nearby Kosovo has not extended to the Macedonian territory.Paradoxically, even if it is true, the war in the field of Kosovo Polje has had the opposite effect: an evident reduction of the dangerous gap in terms of trust existing between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority.In the eyes of the Macedonian majority, the Albanians behaved with great loyalty against the common state during the international explosion of the conflict in Kosovo.In the eyes of the Albanian minority, the Macedonians and the Macedonian state generously acquitted their obligations of neighbors against the Albanian population of Kosovo tortured up to the extreme.This unusual result of the conflict in Kosovo can therefore reason the second internal political birth of the Republic of Macedonia is right.The balanced and commendable relationship of Honorable SwoBoda takes place very concretely to this surprising and happy outcome.In other words, the European Union knows which position to take on Macedonia.It must help this region recently become the place of refuge of numerous refugees to correctly play its role as promoter of the stability pact in the Balkans.Mr President, for eight years I have been dealing with Macedonia, and I allow myself to contradict the honorable Dupuis.What we do is not of hypocrisy: we have reached the right time, and I believe that the Macedonians rejoice.Please don't be so hostile and moderate his statements: I think we should face the question in a more positive perspective.Macedonia was not at war, but has affected the conflict in neighboring countries and sanctions and still continues to undergo the consequences of the sanctions imposed by the right to the adjacent countries.It has greatly affected the flow of refugees during relationships between ethnic groups and solves them with ever better results.I would like to explicitly emphasize that we can congratulate Macedonia for the exemplary legislation on minorities and the way in which he faced the problem and that the involvement achieved of 30 percent of the Albanian population in life and in government and social policy constitutes the assumption of peaceful coexistence in the country.I am satisfied that at the beginning of March it is possible to follow the request formulated in the report of the honorable Swoboda, that is, that also in this country a I think the report by colleague Swoboda is excellent and I can fully agree with him.President!I would also like to express my congratulations on his report.It is to be welcomed that so many support the approach he chose.It is about tackling the stability in the region structurally, and that is also the content of the agreement with the Republic of Macedonia, which we treat today.While the actual execution of the stability package still has to be launched, the Commission quickly worked on the development of the new instrument, the stabilization and association agreement.This begins with the contractual stabilization of the countries of the former Yugoslavia.It is about the countries that are not yet an option for a approach.This agreement is actually a kind of "pre-advance agreement", but with the perspective of future membership.This integration of countries via active contracts is a very good instrument, provided that the agreements specified in it are energetically implemented so that the hoped -for stabilization also occurs.Macedonia is still a potential powder barrel and, as such, has a story.But it has the ambition to get rid of this image.This requires internal stability.The new government will be addressed and the agreement can be an agenda for reforms, including the direct participation and equality of the Albanian minority.Above all, the country needs peace and quiet to create order inside and to find the way to more prosperity.We, the Social Democrats, appeal to the opposition to behave accordingly.She must support the Macedonia model here.The country also needs and, above all, stability to the outside.What use is inner stability if the environment is unstable?This stability is required in relationships with Yugoslavia, Kosovo, Albania and Bulgaria.The region must take note that Macedonia exists and will continue to exist.External stability means open borders and regional cooperation.Minorities and majorities have to get space for human and cultural exchange.Macedonia's stability is closely interlinked by development in neighboring countries.The Kosovo problem is known, where the international community is massively present.Apparently the Albania factor is underestimated.According to the Union, the time for a stabilization and association agreement with this country is not yet ripe.But when?The arguments in particular to conclude an agreement with Macedonia and not yet with Albania fulfill us with so much concern that a waiting attitude of the Union towards Albania is really not acceptable.What position does the Commission draw on this question?Yugoslavia is also a weak point in stability and thus represents a threat to a stable Macedonia. We have to wait and see what is happening there.The mood in Belgrade is more difficult to assess every day.However, we support the decision of the council to shift the focus of the sanctions.At least this is finally trying to strengthen the opposition, which prepares for a new round of demonstrations, to strengthen his back.What will the Union continue to do in this direction, should the opposition request be given up for the opposition?

Secondly, it is clear that the reform will require some new investments in training and technology;Thirdly, it is evident that it will be necessary to start many preparations for the expansion, and Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, I brought you a gift.Here is a piece of NAFTA sent by an inhabitant of the island of Noirmoutier who writes to me: "At every tide, the beach is covered with the crude oil from Erika. At every flood, volunteers, military, firefighters remove enormous masses of this black, viscous and dense tar. When we restore the clean beach and when will this accident be fine?"Yes, this Erika accident, like that of the Russian ship in Türkiye, is unacceptable and intolerable in times when high technology is brought to the stars.It is even more unacceptable because it occurred twenty years after the catastrophe of Amoco Cadiz, when instead we had said and repeated many times that it would never be more successful.It is undoubtedly responsibilities of politicians, and therefore ours, to guarantee the safety of maritime transport.We must really guarantee citizens that such a disaster will no longer be repeated.Listening to her, lady commissioner, you feel a little frustrated because those who had already dealt with these issues know that the Commission and Parliament had prepared, in 1992 I believe, a very interesting text that already contained all the proposals contained in the resolution developed today by the Commission for regional policy, transport and tourism.Because it is true that you have to say and repeat it: Erika is a catastrophe too much.For this reason, it is urgent that the European Union undertakes in a drastic review of its directives on maritime transport, to make them more restrictive and set a clear and precise regime of the responsibilities of the owners of the loads.For example, Shell and British Petroleum had refused to make their oil transported to Erika.Why in this case is not the responsibility of the rent that is the total?In your proposals it is also necessary to introduce the obligation of the double hull and the prohibition of degassification at sea.A European body of inspectors must be established so that they can actually and effectively control the state of the ships.Furthermore, it is equally urgent that the European Union is committed to reforming the OMI.In fact, to what purpose to elaborate restrictive directives if most ships then when you plow the oceans do what they want?Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address a thought moved to all the volunteers, to the friends of nature and the birds who spontaneously and generously respond present and rush to the rescue of the birds impregnated by Nafta by organizing their rescue with the available means.I am a direct witness of this exceptional work.You surely know that about 200,000 birds will die due to the black tide which is an ecological catastrophe of enormous and practically unprecedented ecological catastrophe.Certainly you also know how difficult it is today to keep the species and how difficult it is to keep the habitats.In this regard, Mrs. Commissioner, you have not said anything about the way in which the Commission intends to contribute to the restoration of nature and ecosystems.Once again, there will be no clearly identified managers.In the wait is always the nature that has the worst.

We are at the beginning of an era of creation of a new right, in which the right to exploit intellectual property will face the public interest for its dissemination and exploitation by the general public.Mr. President, thanks to the rapporteur for this excellent report that, however, it concludes that our adhesion, as a community, to those two WIPO treaties should not be limited to a simple institutional evolution, no matter how important it is: the possibility for the European Community and the WIPO Assembly of working together.This ratification is also necessary with respect to the expansion of Europe.But behind that community adhesion, an objective is emerging in my opinion still too virtual and yet too offensive for some member states.This is the affirmation of a European cultural policy for which I hope that we, Parliament, Commission and Council, agree.Who refers to cultural policy refers among other things to the defense of the role of creation, to the recognition of the authors and the production of a demanding culture.And even more today, when Europe must endow a new copyright and related policy, they have just underlined several times - define and re -define what an author is.We maintain too much inaccuracy in this regard and from now on new technologies impose that clarification effort.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the signing of the WIPO treaties meant a considerable positive step in the global development of the information society.These treaties crystallize a copyright tradition of decades, and constitute a balanced and very well thought out solution regarding the regulations on the copyright and related rights.However, the entry into force of the treaties and their definitive form will depend on both this recommendation, and on the execution made by the interested parties.The WIPO treaty has already entered into force in the United States with the help of the digital Millenium Corporate Act, a legislative measure that has contributed to conserve the delicate balance of the WIPO treaty.The European Union must also advance in the process of adapting its laws to what was agreed in the WIPO Treaty.It is also worrying that the positions adopted by the preceding Parliament do not support the balanced System of the WIPO Treaty.The opinion approved in the first reading of the directive on copyright was very distorted, and balance, in turn, is being modified in a pernicious direction for Europe.With the recommendations that have been proposed, the position of culture in Europe is not improved, quite the contrary.The modifications proposed by Parliament would be limited to improving the possibilities of communication companies based in the markets to transfer their old installments, exceeding 80 percent, to a new framework through rigid and sized copyright.I do not refer now to the recommendation of Mrs. Charlotte Cederschiöld, which in itself is a great proposal, but to copyright as addressed by the previous Parliament.

.(IT) On behalf of the Italian communists, I want to express great dissatisfaction with the contents of the document that, according to expectations, had to formulate the strategic objectives for Europe until 2005. Employment: for years, the link between economic growth and increase in employment does not respond to reality, however, it is proposed again as a recipe - which has been proven useless - to solve the very serious problem of unemployment.And that the president is a seasoned economist.Pensions: The document is said: "The responsibility for the modernization of social protection systems will continue to correspond to the Member States";However, precisely the Commission intervened in the case of Italy, repeatedly asking for a rapid modification of the pension regime, aimed at reducing rights and remuneration.And that Mr. President Prodi, for the important orientation he gave to the Italian government in those years, knows how many and what sacrifices our fellow citizens have been requested and made to enter the euro and knows the important role that Italy plays in European development.Therefore, we cannot accept invitations to make greater pension cuts.There is an agreement regarding this issue that provides for its review in 2001. It should not be reviewed a day before or a day later.On the other hand, the dynamics of costs in this regard is totally under control.Therefore, the commission must refrain from this unacceptable ideological approach and these statements that create instability and uncertainty in citizens.I have mentioned the case of Italy not only because the president knows him very well, but because of the community data (Eurostat), it follows that for Italy the welfare expense - currently 25.9% - it is not only since 1990 less than the community average (28.2%), but that it is much lower than the average of the countries considered copies such as Germany (29.9%) and France (30.8%).Role of Europe: First, we must reaffirm that Europe rejects war as an instrument to solve international conflicts;Then you can talk about the "military" role of the Union.Agriculture and Health: Our vision of the issue differs from the vision of the Commission: for us there are no consumers, there are citizens who want to nourish themselves with healthy foods, with products whose purpose is not competitiveness, but the health, quality and respect of the environment, elements that, on the other hand, create employment..(FR) The proposals for measures and the program presented by Mr. Prodi are extremely inaccurate, and social issues, once again, are absent.In addition, the word "social" seems to be banned from the vocabulary of the commission, while liberal and American references abound.Renano Prodi collects the highly controversial concept of "good governance";controversial because it favors leadership against the proper functioning of democracy, and because it refers to the notion defined by the IMF, whose ideological content is totally dominated by liberalism and monetarism.

Coherence and actions are needed.In the next Lomé agreement, investment in education and stimulate regional cooperation and participation of local entities must be specified.The participation of local entities is the greatest importance.And, in a much broader framework, I consider priority the conversion of the debt of poor countries into poverty eradication and sustainable development programs, as well as the control of fraud and corruption.We must advance with concrete and coherent actions.Populations from poor countries begin to despair.I request the Commission to undertake proceedings in the sense of an urgent adhesion of Eastern Timor to the Lomé Agreement, as a way of promoting, among other measures, the eradication of poverty and accelerating its economic, cultural and social development, to reinforce its internal democratization.Finally, I congratulate the presidency of the Council for the next Europe-Africa summit and call all participants to achieve contributions to the materialization of practical actions for the development of peace, democracy and the eradication of poverty in underdeveloped African countries.Thank you very much Lord Commissioner.The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon.Stabilization and Association Agreement with the AryM in accordance with the agenda, the report of the report (A5-0031/2000) of Mr. Swoboda, in the name of the Foreign Affairs Commission, Human Rights, Common Security and Defense Policy, on the decision recommendation of the Council for which the Commission is authorized to negotiate a stabilization and association with the former Yugoslava Republic of Macedonia,(Sec (1999) 1279 - Articles 6 and 7 of the treaty would be, in effect, insufficient arriving the worst case.In this sense, it is necessary - and I would like to confirm and ratify it now here - that the commission persevere in the effort to ensure that the new letter of fundamental rights that must be prepared is incorporated into the treaty and establish some rights of mandatory compliance, enforceable before the courts.The Commission must also persevere, in this sense, in the constant consolidation of the common space of freedom, security and justice, and therefore, in this aspect I maintain a position opposite to that of the two speakers that have preceded me.It is only possible to respond to the irrational, deceptive and demagogic statements of the right, of the extreme right, contrasting the principles of immigration and the right of asylum.However, I want to highlight it -this policy must also be accompanied by a coherent and convincing policy of employment and against social exclusion, since unemployment, marginalization and increasing inequalities constitute an optimal breeding ground for nationalist feelings and actions of an antieuropeo nature.Mr. President of the Commission, I also would like to review in this context to the problems that you have raised in relation to the issue of globalization and the perception that they have broad sectors of the population.The feeling of impotence, lack of influence and lack of support from the State lead to the best of cases to the distancing of politics and electoral abstention, as happened in European elections, and in the worst case, to extremist electoral behaviors.In this context, the union - which not everyone understands - must offer our EU citizens of the EU as a medium, as a protection against the negative effects of globalization.We are building a house, but too few of our own citizens really feel at home at it.Therefore, not only is a reform of the World Trade and Economic Architecture reform necessary -and it is significant that the President of the Commission has forgotten to mention the reform of financial institutions, of international financial architecture -but also necessary to take generating measures of confidence in favor of our citizens, who are authorized to wait with all the right help and support from the EU, and within the EU, and within the EU, and within the EU, and within the EU, and within the EU, and within the EU.painful processes of adaptation to new world circumstances.In this context, what the commission about the strengthening of the voice of Europe can say.Mr. President, you have talked about a model about which, unfortunately, I find too few references in the document.He said that we must offer our citizens a model of economic, social, cultural and ecological development, inside and outside the Union, which is clearly distinguished from other models, also including the American.The United States, in addition to being our partners, are also our competitors in this regard, not adversaries, but competitors, and we must compete to settle who can offer the best model to our citizens.I would like the statements that we pronounce today with such vehemence also find a greater place in the commission documents.Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, the greatest legacy of her commission to the European Union could be her contribution to the restoration and a new distribution of the powers and powers of the Commission, which are increasingly intertwined and are more confused, and that may even be extended even to the Union.

The authors of this question do not offer any solution but call for a new tax, call for an additional bureaucracy, a measure against market mechanisms and seize the plenary of an intergroup design by short-circuiting the competent parliamentary committee, in contradiction with several decisions of the Parliament.In my opinion, and I clearly say, this question is motivated by ideology and is not oriented towards a solution.I repeat that I consider this as an erroneous path.Why do we refuse the Tobin tax and consider it so much questionable?First, as the commissioner also confirmed, because it represents a very heavy burden for the capital markets.A reduced tax would also have heavy repercussions on the capital markets because such a speculation tax would greatly reduce the profitability of investments.In addition, such a measure would also greatly hamper the development of financial markets.This would go against the principle of free movement of capital which is at the curriculum of the internal market.Second, speculative capital is difficult to identify.Third, tax measures can easily be bypassed if they are not simultaneously introduced in all countries because there are many shelters.Fourth, this measure is hardly applicable on the technical level, generates a large bureaucratic and administrative load and is difficult to control.The measure that we should take relates to part of the resolution presented to us.This is the strengthening of banking control.It is a question of clarifying the responsibility of the transactions.This is an international regulatory framework.It is a question of examining national laws in order to determine whether they correspond to the rules of the Basel Committee and if the latter can be disseminated more.I have a big problem with a crucial point of this resolution that we cannot accept as it is.This is point 9. If we have followed the commissioner, we know that the knowledge of the commission on this case will lead him to say no to the Tobin tax.If the said knowledge, the debate and the arguments are such as we expose them and as they seem justified, I believe that it is irresponsible to mobilize the commission six more months and to generate in this way doing uncertainty in the financial and capital markets.The capital market does not expect from us that we are bringing uncertainty, it needs clarity.This is why we reject point 9 and ask for a separate vote.The president, the debate on the taxation of short -term financial transactions is not new.We have been discussed for twenty years from the Tabin tax proposal and, yet this question is still topical because we really need concrete and sincere answers based on scrupulous studies.We must know to what extent a taxation of short -term financial transactions is truly desirable and achievable.Today, this question actually takes on another dimension since, every day, USD 1500 billion travel around the world 24 hours a day, looking for attractive investments, and that at most 3 % of this sum is linked to the real economy.

The recent dioxin alarm in Belgium and even before the ESB crisis in Great Britain, as well as the persistent controversy on the safety of genetically modified foods have contributed to undermining consumer confidence in foods.If the commission manages to reconstruct trust in the food production chain, at the same time it will reconstruct trust in the European institutions themselves and demonstrate that they are able to protect the rights of European citizens.For this reason, I rejoice that the question of food security, public health and consumer trust have a prominent place in the commission's work program for 2000. However, the nature of the proposal relating to the creation of a European food authority in the recent White Paper has disappointed me.Currently the proposal concerns more than anything else a consultative agency for the executive, rather than an independent body with legislative and decision -making skills more similar to those of the American Food and Drug Administration, which has already affirmed its credibility in this field.In addition, the future legislation will face the modus operandi of relations between the European food authority and national authorities, for example the Irish authority for food safety.This organ, together with the cross -border body recently established in Ireland for food safety, is already carrying out a good job.It would be a tragedy if these efforts were threatened by community legislative deficiencies.My fear is that these deficiencies in community legislation could trigger wars of competence between national and community bodies that instead should work together and not one against the other.This is something we have to look at from.Mrs. President, today's presentation by President Prodi by force of things was only a brushstroke.We expect the details year by year, for example as regards the social action program that will have to be presented this year.We will also examine it in the perspective of social policy and employment and submit it to a series of tests.We will verify to what extent it is possible to create an equilateral triangle of policies, which combines economic policy, employment policy and social policy.At this moment social policy arranges behind economic and employment policy.In the framework of the strategy for employment, we will verify the deepening and expansion of the strategy following the revision carried out under the Portuguese presidency and in the context proposed by it.Regarding the social dimension, we will evaluate if an in -depth analysis of the internal market is proposed with a social component.The explosion of the mergers, the sales and the relevance of companies to which we assist as the market is strengthened mean that we must update the matrix of the directives on information and consultation of the workers adopted in the past, but we must also complete them with a new general framework of information and consultation provisions and with an update of the directive on European company committees.We also need a code of conduct for companies in order to ensure that they actually work in an atmosphere of partnership with employees to manage change.

On average, to manage $ 10 million aid, the Commission has a staff of 2.9 people, compared to 4.3 of the World Bank and between 4 and 9 in the major Member States.This is a serious problem: there are too many financial instruments, each with its own characteristics and, in particular, a series of different budget items.It is difficult to reconcile this situation with the needs of an effective management system.To deal with and solve these problems, the community must engage in a real dialogue with the Member States and Parliament.It is absolutely essential to face the question of consistency in a realistic and pragmatic way, which means starting discussions in the adequate institutional context, that is, with the Council and Parliament.The lack of concerted actions between the 15 Member States and the community must also be addressed.By focusing the community development policy on international strategies and objectives we will spend the way towards better complementarity with the Member States.This is almost the line illustrated a little, indeed by the president in office for the Amado Council.Today, when we talk about policies, we commit ourselves in a convergence process.This is part of the solution.We are engaged in the formulation of new programmatic guidelines and we must identify the priority sectors for community intervention.Everything has become increasingly complex, and this also applies to cooperation in the field of development.No donor is able to deal with the entire spectrum of issues alone, ranging from macroeconomic issues to the regulatory framework or from sectoral policies to a variety of new transversal issues, such as gender issues, the environment, good governance and institutional reforms.It is important to identify flexible mechanisms that allow a distribution of work based on the skills and skills of the different donors in each country developed.This should be done at the level of the Member States and should lead to the formulation of sectoral policies for community intervention.This is the goal we aim to achieve.In order to identify the priority sectors for Community support, the specific characteristics of the community must be taken into account with respect to Member States and international institutions.I quote only a few: our ability to associate development policy with commercial policy and to guarantee synergies between aid and economic cooperation;our neutrality and the protection of the general interests of the community;The fact that we represent a critical mass and that we are able to carry out relatively vast range of interventions compared to what the individual Member States can normally norm.Furthermore, our concrete presence: basically, I believe that our biggest value is precisely the fact that, since we represent ourselves a successful attempt at regional cooperation, we are seen as a neutral and welcome partner for this experiment worldwide, a role that no one else can boast.It is vital importance to make community policy more effective and develop a more operational strategic framework.The Commission must accept this double challenge, presenting a proposal for a general political declaration over the next few months.

Now the situation is so much pointed that the Pentagon banned the American armed forces to return to northern Mitroviæa.They have now been replaced by robust Danish, Finnish and Swedish troops.It is easy to despair in view of the violence and hatred, but for Kosovo, the Balkans and for Europe it is important that we do not fail here.The stability pact gives us great commitments.Thus, this matter becomes a test for the credibility of the union's common foreign and security policy.At the moment there is an immense lack of suitable staff in Kosovo.Bernard Kouchner already demanded a civilian police last autumn.I am therefore pleased to hear now that Mr. Javier Solana will gather the Interior Minister at the weekend to discuss the police question.I hope these conversations will primarily revolve around Kosovo, so that the desperate location can be ended there.As for the Balkans and Kosovo, I also hope that the Council also supports the claim of Parliament and, as I understood, the Commission also supports the Commission for a multi -year budget for missions in Kosovo.Mr. Solana!The situation in Kosovo has taught us a lot, e.g.B. the creation of military capacity for crisis management, which has already been put into practice.Another, at least as important experience is that preventing a crisis is more important than later fire brigade operations.For this reason, the EU also needs independent and credible funds for conflict prevention.As for the Commission, Commissioner Patten has already undertaken several commendable initiatives in this direction.I am thinking of the proposal for setting up a Rapid Reaction Facility and a Rapid Reaction Force for non -military missions as well as the creation of headline goals for non -military missions and a commission crisis center.My last question to Mr. Javier Solana is: What specific steps are planned for conflict prevention?How is this organized in Mr. Solana's office and coordinated with the work of the Commission?President, Mr. Solana, you enjoy the full support and trust of the liberals' parliamentary group, but we would like to remind you of the huge responsibility that is now on your shoulders.On the one hand, I think of the upcoming important humanitarian, peace -based and peace -creating tasks.However, I also think of their responsibility that the new European cooperation in the field of defense does not run a wedge between NATO and the EU or between the USA and Europe.Such a split would only use those rifles and despotic states that threaten freedom and human rights.I think you have taken note of the concerns that some members of the American congress have been expressed here in Parliament last week.You have to clear these concerns, Mr. Solana.You have put it yourself so that we can do something when we work across the Atlantic.Disability makes us weak and thereby extends the suffering of the oppressed.Therefore, dear Mr. Solana, keep in touch with our American Allies as close as possible and also take into account Norway, Turkey and Canada.

The respect and inviolability of human values, the rights of minority and those of all citizens who live in the territory of the European Union represent the foundations on which the principle of the EU law state is based.That's why the Convention on Fundamental Rights should also be binding from a legal point of view and not relegated to the role of simple declaration.Our support for Austrian democratic forces is also equally important;None of us intend to isolate this country.We know perfectly perfect that most of the Austrians respect these values ​​as they have shown, also publicly, through their protest that did not take place outside the borders of Austria.Certainly there are also many voters who with the vote wanted to give voice to their strong desire to attend a radical change of course in Austrian politics.In my opinion, Parliament should support these democratic forces.I also invite the Austrian president to commit himself to the maximum in trying to form a government based on these democratic forces.Madam president, deputies, simply I would like to underline the value of an attitude like what the president of our group, Francis Wurtz, recalled a little while ago.I appreciate the declarations of the Prime Minister and the position of the 14 countries that refused official contacts with the Austrian government if Jörg Haider's party was included.This underlining of ours is all the more important because we, as is known, are substantially disagreement with policies made by this Europe: from its economic and social policies, by its deficit of democracy, by the involvement of these same countries in the dramatic Balkan war.This dissent highlights today's appreciation even more: an exceptional element, because it is exceptional the danger of a rebirth, in Europe, of an irrational and neo -Nazi component.This danger does not concern Austria, it concerns Europe.Let's talk about us, not of Austria.We know the social causes that contribute, with unemployment and uncertainty, to feed propensities in that direction;We know the cultural causes - xenophobic, racist - but we cannot fail to indicate in the inability and non -will of these far -right forces to deal with Nazism, the possibility of building an explosive mixture in Europe.It speaks of the Alpine arc, it speaks of all our countries: conditions are being created for which a danger to European democracy and civilization can be reborn.The position taken of the presidency was aware of this drama of civilization.Europe shows that she has not forgotten Auschwitz;Europe meets a soul.Now, however, it should be consequent in its actions, and the first to be consequent should be the commission which, however, has shown here an opacity and a lability that make the value of the position of the presidency even more evident.This is the correction to be imposed on the action of the Commission.Mrs. President, colleagues, in the fundamental democratic principle of respect for human rights and the freedom and sovereignty of peoples, against every new or old fascism, Nazism or communism, and since all the previous speakers have spoken of sovereignty the Austrian people, we see, today, denied this sovereignty by this parliament.

It is true that the problem of the wood sector is terribly complex.You have indeed talked about unlocking funds for storage of wood because it should not be depreciated.On the other hand, the municipalities which have not been affected by storms will also undergo damage, since the National Forest Office has decided to freeze the forest cuts for four years.So these municipalities which have not suffered losses will still see their recipes decrease.All this to tell you that the problem is eminently complex and I thank the commission again to push the analysis of this situation as far as possible.I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that there is, of course, economic disaster, but that real ecological disasters are still to come.You have said it yourself, Mr. Commissioner, these disasters, these storms are not always natural and we believe that these are the first signs of climate change.So we have to review our policies to integrate this data.Mr. President, all those who arrived here by car, train or plane could see the extent of the damage caused particularly in France by the hurricanes of unprecedented violence that hit Europe at the end of last month.Faced with a disaster of such magnitude, what can elected officials of the European Parliament do?First of all, I want to salute all my mayors, local elected officials, who, on a daily basis, had to reassure the population, organize solidarity, cooperate with public services.They deserved the confidence of their fellow citizens.I then want to thank here the rescue services and the armed forces of the Member States of the Union which, as part of exemplary intergovernmental cooperation, came to support the efforts of their French colleagues.I would also like to wonder about the paradoxical situation in which we are in terms of emergency aid.If this disaster had taken place in Guatemala or Turkey, we could immediately involve the community budget for the benefit of the victims, but in our countries nothing is possible, for lack of adequate line of credit.We must also ask the Commission not to prevent local communities and states from helping businesses disaster -based by the disaster, in the name of an overly close application of community competition rules.I especially think of particularly struck fishing and conchyliculture companies.As you said, as you said, the Commissioner, that forced activity judgments can be compensated and that the investments which are entirely to be rebuilt can call on Ifop.Beyond that, I believe that the mechanical application of POPs is no longer put in the disaster regions.I therefore ask the Commission to give it up for, on the contrary, helping sea professionals to make new investments that are urgently imposed on them.Mr. President, dear colleagues, the storms that ravaged France in the night of December 26 and 27, as we said, 90 dead, 75 billion francs, or 11 billion euros, damage.

The design of the council has serious defects, especially in relation to legal protection.According to the reports of the rapporteur di Pietro, the draft even contains very significant deficits.The agreement enables a chain of request for legal welfare, whereby every member authorities and criminal law systems can be assigned to other Member States.This chain is structured in such a way that it cannot be controlled by a single judge as a whole.Flanking measures, for example the obligation for investigators, need to appear as a witness to request in every criminal matter in which their documents are used.For my faction, it is also problematic that the council draft disregards the proportional principle.In any case, the area of ​​application is not restricted.This agreement is not only applicable to combating serious crimes and organized crime.There is even nowhere that it only refers to criminal law.It is therefore quite conceivable that the European Union will soon shoot at sparrows with cannons and to dissolve the rights of citizens in smoke.Mr. President, which deals with us today with legal assistance in criminal matters, contains minimum regulations that are essential for effective and quick cooperation between the various judicial and investigative organs.It concerns the deliveries, the exchange of information, the temporary transfer of imprisoned persons, the return of objects, the questioning of witness by video conference, the investigation, including the so -called hidden investigations, telephone monitoring, etc.m. This is the minimum that could be agreed, whereby it must be said that if there are some change requests such as No. 32 or No. 81 or 71 in their revised version, the overall agreement would result in the mere exchange of messages or information and could really be thrown into the trash, which is why we would be correct.I hope that the colleagues of the various political groups can be guided by their common sense and reject these amendments.The fact that it was not enough for a framework agreement, but only to an agreement, is a defeat for the European Parliament.Commissioner Vitorino will surely have taken out all the different articles, how necessary it is to create a framework for common rules, instead of continuing to continue with this incoherent regulation, these small conventions for individual areas such as the investigation or the .. It is rather absolutely necessary to create a minimum of more secure, more than the guarantees - also to ensure that it is possible to extend it as far as possibleneed to be increased.I only imagine what should become of this community, these agreements or the legal relationships if, for example, a fascist country like Turkey would join the European Union: I would be really at a loss.As everyone emphasized, we need a corpus juris and, especially in procedural law, common rules that ensure a common constitutional state throughout the community.It is obvious that this is a matter of which the government conference must mainly deal with and that the parliament can only make a limited contribution to this objective, since everything depends on the council and on the commission.In my opinion, this first half of the year, in which the responsible commissioner is Portuguese and Portugal, has the Presidency of Council, an excellent opportunity to give this joint objective a first impulse.

However, I took note of your comments and I will examine them more in -depth.Ms. Roth-Behrendt asked me a question about the establishment of a positive list.This is one of the questions we tackle in the appendix to the legislation and we intend to establish a positive list for substances intended for animal food.For the time being, the list is, I would say, negative and completes itself in the required manner.The establishment of a positive list constitutes one of the questions raised in the appendix and accompanied by a date, namely 2002. We have identified the fast alert system intended for animal feed as a gap in legislation.Quick alert exists for food and not for animal feed.It is unfortunate and incorrect and we think it is important to highlight it, to establish legislation in order to fill this gap and this will be done.Work in relation to ESB within Member States and the establishment of tests carried out at random in order to assess the levels of infectivity in the Member States are underway.I know that Mrs. Roth-Behrendt already asked me this question and I replied that I thought it was progressing quickly.However, I think I know that the question is at the stage of the consultation between the services within the Commission and that the work is currently underway.I hope that the next time you ask me, I will be able to provide you with more detailed information.Ms. Jackson stressed the fact that there are 24 new legislative acts and 20 modifying legislative acts.She also asks if this aggravates excess regulation.I would say that the legislative acts that we have identified are intended to fill the gaps in current legislation.This concerns less the establishment of new regimes or additional regulations, although it is part of it, than to identify where the gaps and weaknesses are located in the chain ranging from the stable to the table and to fill them.It has been referred to the candidate countries, something we keep in mind.The standards in food security and of course other areas of security are of obviously crucial importance with regard to enlargement and this is a question to which I drew the attention of Mr. Verheugen.The Commissioner, the ignorance of certain Member States has plunged Europe into a large -scale food crisis and I am once again irritated, unfortunately, to note the total and renewed absence of the Council when you present this interesting report.I would really like you to tell me how you intend to guarantee that this new authority, whatever its detailed name, will have the influence on the advice, which will have its say within this authority, which will give the orders.It goes without saying that we cannot impose anything in terms of content but I still insist that after Maastricht and Amsterdam, the parliament retains its right, and even that it develops it.

In today's debate, many words have been pronounced that correspond to essential concepts of today: globalization, knowledge society, relations between the old economy and the new economy.All those words and the concepts that are behind them can correspond simultaneously to opportunities and problems.And the imperative that arises is to transform problems into opportunities and above all to avoid at all costs transform opportunities into problems.It is evident that, for us to get it, there are two essential issues in all spheres.First, a very strong investment in people and a decisive concept mentioned here by so many of their lordships: training and education throughout life are an investment in people, a decisive issue for all these matters to become an opportunity for all.But, in addition to investment in people, it is also necessary that there are regulatory capacity of public authorities, whether they are national states, the European Union or world authorities, in the sense of making the indispensable business and personal initiative compatible with the conditions of social justice and equity.That is true in the sphere of globalization.The globalization is something that allows a greater increase in wealth, international trade, productivity.But deregulation globalization, as it exists today, or the globalization in which large sectors of the world population do not have a strong investment in people is also a factor of exclusion, division, expansion of the pit between rich and poor.That is true in the Knowledge Society, which can provide a new equal opportunities, but it can also be an increasingly clear separation factor between those who have access to it and those who do not have it, as occurs in relations between old and new economy.For the rest, it is not the first time that there is a technological transition that modifies the paradigm of society and the organization of the economy.And what has always happened in those moments of deep transition is that the problems of the old economy, in particular those of employment, are always resolved to the new economy and its instruments.I give an example: in Europe we have a textile industry and we must continue to have it, but we will only have it, if we can apply the technologies of the Information Society and the Knowledge Society.And it is still extraordinary that at this time, in the sectors of the so -called "New Economy", there is a lack of almost 80,000 people suitable for jobs that exist, just like there are millions of unemployed.Which means that we have not yet been able to use the instruments of the new economy to solve the problems of the old economy, which will never have a solution with the logic of that same old economy.Finally, I want to answer a question that has been asked: if I speak here in the name of fifteen or fourteen countries.The answer is simple: I speak on behalf of fifteen countries.And one of the things that the Portuguese presidency has guaranteed is the full participation of Austria in the functioning of all the institutions of the Union.

Mr Andersson will surely know the phenomenon known under the name of prohibition and also know what were the consequences for the activities of the US mafia.So much so that in the end it was decided to abolish prohibition.It is obvious that we must protect the health of citizens, but not by forbidding alcoholic beverages, since it is obvious that it is useless.Mr. President, in reality these are the revenue deriving from the monopoly on the alcohol of the Swedish state.When the Swedish government claims to have it to cover the health costs, it shows that we are in the presence of a distortion of competition since other countries must independently finance their health costs without being able to have a monopoly on alcohol.My question is as follows: she is also aware of studies that say that moderate consumption of high quality alcohol products such as French wine or Bavarian beer can even be healthy and that therefore even a relief of the Swedish budget could derive from it.I seem to have understood that the honorable MEMT referred to the tax of the matter.And if I am not mistaken, the high excise duties on alcohol in Sweden date back to 1638 and since then much of the state fiscal revenue comes from the sale of alcohol.It is also known that currently in Sweden there is a state monopoly, which in itself already represents a violation of the union legislation.Therefore, as far as the healing power of alcohol is concerned, it was to this that the honorable S meeting referred if I did not get badly - I agree with him one hundred percent.In my opinion, a good bottle of wine can do very well to health and at the level of social contacts it can be extremely pleasant.Perhaps the honorable S Melt, the honorable Andersson and the undersigned one of these days we could meet at the Parliament bar to drink a glass of Aquavit together.Mr President, I followed with interest the commission's response regarding the need to apply the legislation on the single market.I wonder if the commissioner can tell me if he considers his response compatible with the fact that the Commission has not brought the French government before the Court of Justice due to the application of the French law "Loi et Vin" which in fact prevents the application of legislation on the single market for the sale of alcohol in France.Can we expect that the European Commission present an appeal against France to the Court of Justice?I would like to answer very briefly to the question of the honorable parliamentary, since the question is currently being examined by the Commission.The Commission must decide whether the question is to be considered closed or if it should be brought to the attention of the Court of Justice.Perhaps my answer will not be satisfactory at the moment, but I want to reassure the honorable parliamentary that the commission will adopt a decision within a few weeks.I appeal to the understanding of the honorable parliamentary for this small delay in the Commission's decision.Mr. Commissioner exist, there are public health reasons that justify different tax rates, for example for the Scottish whiskey rather than French burgundy wine or even colleague's Bavarian beer?

The truly substantial difference concerns the charge of costs for waste disposal.Colleague Bouwman has already focused on this aspect.There are two experiences on the subject.That of the Baltic Sea, and therefore an experience not only national, but of the whole Baltic basin, according to which, including the costs for disposal in general port rights in the wide part, the elimination of the waste of the ships no longer encourages.Once paid, it is worth providing for the disposal of waste in the port.The second system is based on the pure principle of "polluting pays": the ships that land waste are required to pay an additional amount.This second system proved to be ineffective, otherwise why would the Mediterranean be so dirty?Why is the North Sea equally dirty?Because the principle of "who pollutes pays", without adequate checks, does not work!Here is the reason why a large majority during the commission - not a great majority and now the representatives of the minority opinion will President, I am pleased that she is the one who presides over the discussion, because I know, that being Bavarian, she always pays close attention to the issues relating to ports and seas.I want to
