I would like to ask the president in the exercise of the Council, who has spent a few hours in this hemicycle working with the deputies of the European Parliament, if he has come to get an idea of ​​what they are worth in terms of remuneration of honor, such as this debate on the fees of the European Parliament is not exclusive to his country and even extends to my country, I have an exact idea of ​​how much the fees of the deputies ascend to the European Parliament.Therefore, I am perfectly aware of that problem.Mr. President, I appreciate the answer.I want to ask a complementary question that has some similarity with that of Mr. Sjöstedt.We are both Swedes.In our country the largest tax is the municipal, since the services are local and abundant.There are problems related to politicians and, in no less proportion, in European politicians in Parliament.How do you think that confidence in us, politicians, if we are granted the right to use services at the places where we live - schools, assistance, etc. - but, at the same time, we not pay taxes, we do not contribute?How do you think that a system of this nature would influence us?It is a question, Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, that I do not know if he is obliged to answer because he is really philosophical.But if you want to enter the field of philosophy, go ahead!No, Mr. President, I don't feel tempted to enter the field of philosophy.These are underground issues and related to the matrix of the deputy statute itself and its role, within the framework of political society.I do not want to enter that type of debate, because it seems to me that it could - to use a French expression - préjuger the interpretation that the Portuguese presidency does within the framework of the negotiations, in which it is immersed, on the statute of the deputies.I would like to ask that in this regard allow me not to advance any comment.Having exhausted the time assigned to the question shift to the Council, questions 11 to 35 will be answered in writing.The question shift to the Council is closed.(The session, interrupted at 19.05, resumes at 9:00 p.m.) address of Mr. Vaclav Havel, President of the Czech Republic Mr. President, Ladies, in the name of the European Parliament, I have the great honor of giving an effusive welcome to Mr. Václav Havel, President of the Czech Republic.I would also like to express the welcome to Mrs. Havel, who has held a position in the gallery.Lady, welcome.(Applause) It is not the first time we welcome him in our Parliament, Mr. President.You already talked to the Plenary, in Strasbourg, in March 1994, almost six years ago, and many of us retain a very intense memory of it, that is, those of our colleagues who were already deputies at that time.Indeed, just after the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty, you pronounced in favor of strengthening European values, the creation of a European ethical dimension, of the opening of the Union to the countries of central and eastern Europe.

I do not say that the degree of specialization of workers in the sector should not be increased - it is obvious that it is necessary to do it -, but first it is necessary to allow jobs to be created.The availability of non -specialized, temporary and seasonal work is very important in some economic sectors of the community.Tourism contributes to regional development in rural areas that are trying to diversify and to that of urban areas that try to highlight the importance of their cultural heritage.Considering together all these aspects we can truly do something in Europe and perhaps we will be able to stretch the tourist season by throwing the holidays on our continent.We must not forget that with the expansion we will have the opportunity to increase the number of tourists who land in Europe to visit those monuments of our cultural heritage that for many years - about forty - have not been open to the public.We are losing market shares, and I think something should be done to make us more competitive.So I hope you want to help us.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, today we deal with a very important sector, which gives work directly to more than 10 million people in the EU and which helps the more or less disadvantaged regions, as well as the insular and more remote areas, to bring forward.Tourism creates an additional number of jobs, contributing to the consolidation of employment especially for the most vulnerable bands of society, that is, women and young people.In light of such data, I think that the lack of a European tourism policy constitutes a serious contradiction.The absence of a legal basis makes the adoption of measures in the sector in question impossible.The occasional use of article 308 (ex 235), which provides for unanimity, prevented a five -year program from 8 million ECU for all the Member States.The measures adopted sporadically in the past have been fragmented and ineffective, and their provisions have been dictated by parallel policies in the sectors, for example, of consumer protection, the environment, transport, taxes, etc.;These were policies that not only did not help tourism but rather hindered it, given that their application often presupposed a cost for the tourism sector, without ever in depth the way to help or encourage the latter.I emphasize with regret that today tourism, within the framework of the renovation of the commission services, is only a sector - and not a direction - in the context of the "Enterprise" General Management.In my opinion, our tourism must instead be supported and the pillars for this support can be the following: addition of a chapter dedicated to tourism in the revision that will give a legal basis to the sector;processing of a common tourist policy that will support the sector without upsetting the functioning of the relative market;coordination between tourism policy and other parallel common policies that influence it directly or indirectly;Sector study and adoption of medium and long -term measures to help the competitiveness of the tourist product.

The history of the Joint Assembly attests in this regard, in a resounding way, of a positive evolution.If before the ACP countries were represented in the meetings by members of the governments, senior officials or ambassadors, today more than three quarters of our interlocutors and interlocutors are chosen parliamentarians.We must celebrate a great party when we soon reach 100%, as you want with the new agreement.Advances in democratization processes, which, unlike the various crisis outbreaks, are produced discreetly, unfortunately go unnoticed.A specific element of multilateral ACP collaboration is regional cooperation and integration.This will fulfill a desire for the long list of desires of Parliament.The Joint Assembly will soon hold meetings at the regional level.We have already been able to listen.Strengthening regional cooperation may contribute to preventing conflicts for ethnic, economic, social or religious reasons, that is, it can have a preventive effect.For the same reason, the European Parliament has promoted from the beginning the participation of civil society in the decision -making processes and in cooperation management and has revealed the meaning of decentralized collaboration.The intensification of the contacts between the Joint Assembly and the social agents, provided for in the new agreement, is one more step in the right direction.There is only a slope of sadness due to the fact that the European Development Aid Fund is not yet integrated into EU Budgets.I hope we do not have to wait another 25 years until in this regard we reach our goal.Mr. President, let me congratulate Mr. Corrie for his report.The Lomé Convention has attest to an authentic partenariat between the EU and the ACP countries for more than 25 years, and the fact that it has continued in despite the overwhelming pressure against which it has received from many organizations, including the WTO, represents a whole triumph.However, it is obvious that the new agreement must not be evaluated for its mere existence, but because of the way in which it can contribute to the EU's commitment to eradicate poverty and achieve international development objectives.If we apply this criterion, we will realize that the new agreements present a series of deficiencies: for example, the agreement is quite disappointing for ACP countries that suffer short -term fluctuations in their export income.In December, during a marathon negotiations round, the agreement was reached to provide aid to island states, to those who have no way out of the sea and the least developed when they suffer losses of at least 2% in their export income, while the other ACP countries would continue to be applied the scale of 10%.However, at the end of the negotiations, the EU alleged that she had never given her approval to include the islands and countries without the sea among the candidates deserving of aid based on the limit of 2%.This change has had devastating consequences, especially for the Windward Islands, which is possibly the only ACP country that will actually be harmed with the new agreements.

in a globalized world is a statement that our fellow citizens, regardless of their level of preparation or their ideology, have heard many times.However, the more rarely we hear what the role of Europe must be in this context of the company of information, globalization and technology.I happen to think, Mr. President, that this probably happens because perhaps we Europeans have a perception of Europe sometimes a little far from our closest concerns and interests.The first concern of European citizens, after health, is probably the job.

I hope that what we have affirmed today with such vehemence will also find greater response in the documents of the Commission.Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, the greatest inheritance that the Commission could leave to the European Union would be to reorganize and redistribute the increasingly chaotic and confused powers and skills of the executive and perhaps of the same union.You took a first brave step, rightly underlining the need to focus on the so -called "fundamental activities".As you have said this today, this means that it is necessary to identify the tasks, policies and programs that are marginal or irrelevant compared to the primary vocation of the Commission.Many policies and many current programs of the European Union have probably already passed their expiry date, or have proved to be difficult to manage or ineffective at European level.Today's challenge is to find the courage to delegate as much as possible not fundamental activities to a lower, national, regional or local level of government.If we want to convince the European public opinion of the merits of further European integration, we must be able to demonstrate that we are so busy on the front of the lower delegation of European skills not justified as on the front of the attribution to the European Union of new powers.We must not allow the detractors of the European integration to support, as they currently do with some reason - we have heard of it by the honorable bonde - that the proliferation of community responsibilities is a one -way road.We must demonstrate that it is a process in two directions, in the context of which the policies and programs of the union not fully justified on the basis of subsidiarity and proportionality, are delegated and abandoned.If we manage in the coming years to make these concrete events correspond to these aspirations, we will make an unprecedented contribution to the future of the European Union as a whole, and as we have heard today, you will be able to benefit from a broad consensus within this parliament.Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, I fully associate myself with the logic of the proposals of colleague Heidi Hautala about the strategic objectives of the Commission for the next five years.For my part, I will intervene on a topic that has not been addressed, despite being expected, that is, the work program of the Commission for the year 2000 in progress.They are aware of the limits of the operation: working as part of the treaty in force, we must stick to its rules.I think in particular of an important topic, that is, the tax problem, but I really don't want to talk about tax aspects.I instead start by welcoming some proposals of the program for the year 2000. I think of all the ambitious and important proposals on food safety and also the safety of navigation, after the two black tides that hit the coasts of Brittany and Turkey.It is good that the Commission quickly reacts.Conversely, in other areas I believe that one could be more ambitious and proceed more quickly.I would like to advance a series of positive proposals regarding, for example, the social, the environment and the sequel to be given to Seattle.

Among the most unprotected, it is important that I intervene on this point, are immigrants and refugees.Thus, almost systematic detention conditions, the criminalization of the asylum applicant are no longer acceptable.Any asylum applicant must be entitled to equitable hearing and a resource with suspensive effect.Last week I attended, a little by chance, at Roissy airport, to a scene of unusual violence in which two young women, clandestine without a doubt, they were returned to Conakry.They were treated as the worst criminals.They were naked, they were dragged by land from the hair and escorted by a horde of CRS.The Portuguese presidency must end this type of barbarian acts.Our role is, on the contrary, to accompany, reassure, help those fleeing dictatorships.The Commission proposed the creation of a European Fund for Refugees.Parliament was very favorable to it.Instead of hesitation on the budget granted to this fund, I think you can adopt the decision to apply it.The Presidency and the Council can realize what was rejected incomprehensibly in Tampere, although Tampere has constituted an important basis.In the same way, we cannot settle for verifying the increase in xenophobic currents in Europe, the trivialization of discriminations, without adopting size measures.The harmonization of laws against racism is imposed.What is the point of giving article 13 of the treaty? What do you plan to do to promote equal salaries between men and women? How do you expect to work for the eradication of homophobia, racism and sexism?It is necessary to take the best of what is already being done in each of the countries of the Union.When six European countries grant the right to vote, its president can afford to expand that right of vote and eligibility in the municipal and European elections to all extra -community citizens who have residing for more than five years in the European territory.Thus, the regularization of roles without some countries, including your, must become an example for others, since those without papers are currently a mass of fragilized people in the hands of dream merchants and a workforce subject to personal benefit and an economic exploitation that makes them modern slaves.More generally, this presidency must begin a principle of change in the behaviors and relations of our fellow citizens with minorities and immigrants.Immigration is too often synonymous with insecurity and violence and responses are purely repressive.How do you plan to make our fellow citizens understand that today, as always, immigration is a source of social and cultural wealth, whose function is and will be indispensable in the demographic context we know? What action does it tell to carry out to value the place of immigrants in our society and guarantee true protection to asylum seekers?Mr. President, there is a great lack of transparency in the field of security, freedom and justice.The European Union is an economic portent, but we are not in a position to pontify when it is time to talk about the treatment of refugees.The level of racism in our society is terrifying.

The road has been very long, especially because of the legal problem that survived by the extent that it could be considered that the community had full competences in intellectual property issues.The problem has been overcome.Today we must give our opinion as essentially on two treaties: the Treaty to Intellectual Property and the Treaty on Interpretations or Executions and Phonograms.As for the first, it seems that it resolves effectively the demands of the authors of artistic and literary works, while creating the framework for protection in issues of distribution, rent and presentation of their works to the public.As for the second treaty on executions and phonograms, we must underline that for the first time they are recognized by an international treaty, which also signs the community, the exclusive rights of interpreters and artists for the production, distribution and rental of the public, as well as the right to a fair remuneration for broadcasting.In this framework, the great advance of the treaty in the issue of the right of reproduction must be pointed out.Although, as the commission mentions, in the texts of the treaties there are no special provisions that regulate all the additional issues that arise with technological development, it can be affirmed, however, that in this legislative framework that is being created, the interpreters enjoy a broader protection than that which derived from the Treaty of Rome or even the community directives.The interpretation of article 7 of the treaty leads us to the conclusion that the application of protection against reproduction does not mean only protection against the reproduction of the interpretations or the executions of them that are incorporated into phonograms, but also, protection against the copy, partial or total, permanent or ephemeral, as well as protection of all types of production.However, it would be convenient to refer to some points that must be the epicenter of the future works of the WMO or other diplomatic conferences.This is the right of distribution as refers to article 8, first section.The possibility given to the States, from the following section of the same article, to regulate the exercise of the right mentioned above, is dangerous and constitutes one of the most negative points of the treaty, since there is nothing that prevents member states from approveing ​​special conditions to exercise this right, something that will have negative consequences for artists.On the rental right, the interpretation of article 9 leads us to the conclusion that of the exclusive rental right enjoy only artists or interpreters, as long as it is provided for in national legislation, and I believe that here there is a difference in relation to article 13. To end I want to say that the ratification of these treaties opens horizons to the property right.For the 21st century, the century of knowledge and intangible economy, intellectual property will be a primary form of property and, in many cases, more important than traditional property.

Mr. President, the place that women occupy in politics is an important issue that would deserve something better than the politically correct overpuja we attended.Without a doubt, there are not many women who participate in politics.It is not true that the predominance of men in the party devices is the only reason to be invoked.In France, 95% of the elected are councilors.Most of them are not affiliated with any party.In the departmental organs, the first party of France is that of the elected without label, which represent several left or right parties.To be elected local councilor, just love it, and on the implementation offered by these mandates often depends on the possibility of assuming national responsibilities.Our group wishes to promote a fair representation of men and women in the organs of the European Union.That is why we reject the quota policy and positive discrimination, it is already expressed in favor of women or even the alleged social minorities.The minority policy, by subtracting importance from the deep unity of the human family, in order to establish superficial divisions, dangerously threatens the cohesion of the social body and the balance of our democratic model.On the one hand, if we set fees for women, why we would not establish quotas attending age or ethnicity, Catholics, workers, people who wear glasses.The application of social quotas in favor of the most modest categories would not be more crazy than the creation of fees for women.With this philosophy, it would no longer be necessary to organize either elections or administrative competitions.It would be enough to determine the composition of the ministries and the chambers through a statistical calculation.The quota policy can only increase the little interest of the voters with respect to politics, and would give them the impression that everything happens behind them.On the other hand, this policy demonstrates a deep contempt for women.It is not because of the mechanical game of a certain quota that women must access the performance of political or administrative functions, but through the recognition of their own merit and skills.Ladies, would they be so little pride to be willing to carry a ministerial portfolio or a girdle of deputy for the mathematical contingency of a quota?Women are worth much more than a quota.It is restoring the principle of "meritocracy" as we will improve in quantity and quality the presence of women in the decision -making process.I want to thank Mrs. Minister and Mrs. Commissioner her interventions and the important statements they have made before the European Parliament on a crucial issue as the one we discussed today.The presence of women in decision -making positions is first and foremost a matter of democracy.It is necessary that all citizens, men and women be recognized, feel really represented by their chosen ones and their rulers.

For this reason, we give a cordial welcome to these programs.I would like to refer to the positions of the Employment and Social Affairs Commission in regards to the greatest of community initiatives, that is, Interreg III.It is necessary that in the framework of Interreg III a considerable number of social measures can also be promoted given the fact that 50% of the unemployment in the Union is structurally conditioned and in view of the especially sensitive situation that is recorded in the border territories - I want to refer only to possible unwanted migratory movements - this is not only reasonable, but also imperative.However, the measures susceptible to promotion mentioned in Annex II of the orientation A seem to promise a lot in this regard.However, in the communication of the Commission, instructions are completely missing to the Member States containing these integrated approaches of aspects of social policy and employment policy.For this reason I would like to refer in a special way to the progressive adoption of professional training measures, especially in areas that are affected by a high degree of long -term unemployment and youth unemployment.The B orientation should also be open to employment policy promotion measures, especially in connection with the introductory strategy for adhesion candidates.In relation to employment policy measures, it seems necessary to compose the mixed cooperation committee at the regional level because only at the regional level the experience and familiarity that are precisely necessary for these measures are given so that they do not fade into something abstract.We can criticize always that in Interreg it is still excessive - as I think too - the administrative trajín, but we must always criticize it, although this almost seems inevitable in the case of the commission's promotion programs.However, I would like to indicate that this is fatal precisely here.Precisely for the employment policy we should tend to measures as simple as possible so that the social dimension acquires again in this EU the importance that corresponds to it.Mr. President, the Regional Policy Commission, Transport and Tourism considered, among other things, the Report on Leader+ and, in this sense, agreed to support the decentralization process in the management of the actions, considering that such a process may be effective if two conditions are respected: that the local action groups are representative of the general interests of the local community and that the control mechanisms of the commission are used to prevent the territorial and local political powers from using the resourcesLeader+ to maintain organizations and civil groups related to power.It is requested that in the decision -making bodies of the projects, an equal representation of three components is guaranteed: political representatives and public administrations, companies and economic operators, and social actors, including unions and non -governmental organizations.And it is especially underlined that, in all these organs, there must be a balanced representation of men and women.

It is for this reason that the Commission presented in November 1998 a proposal for a directive on the information-consultation of workers.We thank the Parliament for the support he has given to this proposal since that time.Unfortunately, more than a year after the presentation of the proposal, the other branch of the legislative power, the Council, has still not started working on this proposal.I hope that this debate will help remind Member States the importance and urgency of this initiative.We recently heard the Portuguese presidency declare that a serious debate would soon be launched on this proposal.The next presidency, which will be exercised by France, also seems willing to grant this file the priority it deserves.The Commission sincerely hopes that the Parliament and the Council will quickly finalize this important file which constitutes, in its eyes, the most effective response to the concerns raised by cases such as that which brings us here today.Regarding the involvement of employees at the transnational level, there are certain indications of at least one case of infringement of transnational agreements in terms of consultation and information concluded between companies and European work.The companies concerned may have taken part of certain ambiguities of the legal and contractual framework in force.The commission will contact the relevant national authorities to see what it is.In any case, I would like to make anyone who believes they have been flouted in their rights that they have the appropriate means of enforcing the law and obtaining compensation, in particular through relevant national jurisdictional bodies.The Commission heard the request of the Parliament to carry out an immediate revision of the European Business Committees Directive.As indicated by the report it will adopt in the coming weeks, the Commission admits that the directive presents certain shortcomings.Nevertheless, as my colleague has already pointed out, Commissioner Diamantopoulou, on various other occasions, the decision to immediately revise a directive is not easily taken.It depends on various considerations.First, a revision of the directive would have little immediate effect on existing agreements, unless the fundamental principle of respecting the autonomy of the parties continues to be applied.Then, an immediate revision would risk delaying the progress of other pending files in this area, such as that of the European Anonymous Company and the proposal on national information-consultation.The success of these other files could greatly facilitate the subsequent revision of the CEE directive and even bring some possibilities of solution to the problems identified above.This is why the Commission thinks rather that it would be better, in this context, to revise the directive on European corporate committees after having completed these two other files and after having evaluated the application of the directive.The revision does not stop at legislation alone.To encourage and support dialogue, as a cornerstone of a successful change, the Commission is putting into practice the recommendations of the Lillehammer report by preparing the creation of a European industrial change observatory.

share reached during the last decade - at least 23-24 percent of GDP, both in the public and private sector.In order to allow the public sector to take the initiative in investment policy, the Council should have sacrificed some of its most sacred cows.He should have reviewed his negative attitude towards the large infrastructure programs of transeur European networks, who remained to take dust in the drawers for too long, allow these programs to be adequately financed through the EU bonds, and to accept an interpretation of the concept of budget deficit that would allow governments to contract for investments without remaining victims of the restrictions on the stability pact.This was the first fundamental aspect of my proposal.The second aspect consisted in embracing a large number of structural reform proposals, privatization and deregulation and facilitating the transition to an economy based on knowledge that, as we know, constitutes the foundation of the proposals of the presidency for the Lisbon summit.The experts said several times that the structural reform plan in conjunction with an investment expansion program and growth could awaken the European economy from its state of inertia, while unilateral policies are destined to fail.

The sixth report of the European Commission draws very precious conclusions.I will summarize two, which have already been recalled by the rapporteur, one positive, the other negative.The first is that significant progress has been made in terms of territorial and social cohesion throughout the territory of the Union and that the community funds have played an important, although not decisive role, in the reduction of regional inequalities.The negative is that the considerable effort that has been made has proven more effective with regard to bringing together the GDP and productivity of European regions than in terms of its employment levels.It is therefore necessary to better coordinate structural financing and the creation of workstations.It is, Mr. Commissioner, the first mandate for the next period.I therefore ask, Mr. President, to my illustrious colleagues to approve this report and I ask the Commission, as did other colleagues, that it does not lose sight of the conclusions of its sixth periodic report with regard to the programming of the period 2000-2006.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and also for the way in which the amendments' proposals were taken into consideration during the committee exam.The sixth periodic report provides a basis on which to assess the achievement of the European Union regional policy.The report shows that, despite all the efforts, the growth is uneven.Extremely rapid growth continues in central Europe.Likewise, the most dynamic centers are constantly growing faster than the European average, while many regions in the north and southern Europe experience significantly slower growth.An in -depth analysis of the reasons which make regional policy not give the expected results in all regions is now necessary.Is the reason for bureaucracy?Or the regional disparities - distances, too hot or too cold climate, dispersed habitat, rigorous conditions - have not taken enough taken into account?How can the European Union face the challenges of evolution on the planetary scale so that the less well developed regions can keep pace?It would also be important to analyze the effects of expansion on structural funds and the development of the most remote regions.Member States also have their share of responsibility in this area and they must not forget it.Some Member States have contravened the principle of subsidiarity and reduced regional resources to the national level, while the regional aid provided by the European Union was increasing.This had a harmful effect on the results of regional policy.It will also be necessary to think in the future of setting up indicators to target the measures at the right time and in the right place.For example, the uncontrolled migratory flow was not sufficiently taken into account.In this regard too, there is reason to emphasize the decisive role of SMEs as suppliers of jobs and engines of regional development.It is particularly important to put new technologies and know-how available to companies in developing regions.Our group is favorable to the adoption of this report.Mr. President, the Commissioner, dear colleagues, the territorial policy of the European Community has so far made it possible to significantly translate the residents of income of the inhabitants.

The freedom of discretion of the state that you address in point e) of your amendment 10 does not seem to me to be consistent with the entire text of your otherwise awarded report.I therefore ask the colleagues to examine my amendment and hope that we can come to a result tomorrow.To the outside world, these two proposals seem to introduce certain procedures to promote freedom of movement in Europe and to implement the recent judgments that Ms. Berger spoke in their introductory comments.In the event of the United Kingdom, however, we believe that they also go beyond and are therefore unacceptable.This applies partly to the content, but sometimes also to the legal basis in relation to the special position of the United Kingdom.According to the agreements included in the contract, the United Kingdom retains its border controls.The system proposed in these legal texts stipulates that citizens from third countries who want to come to the United Kingdom in accordance with the procedures described present the service ID issued by another Member State and thereby bypass the border controls of the United Kingdom.If there are changes to the current border control regulations of the United Kingdom, then these changes should be brought about by the government and the parliament of the United Kingdom and not a passerby about the European legal law.For this reason, we will vote against these two proposals.President, Lord, ladies and gentlemen!First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the colleague Wieland for the trouble to summarize the various amendments and the various interests in this report.These two proposals significantly contribute to the implementation of one of the four core principles of the internal market for freedom of service.The new regulation for cross-border services will undoubtedly improve both the functioning of the internal market as well as the company's ability to compete and act.The strict framework for the creation of the - and here I am with colleague Wieland - EU service ID card are unavoidable because they serve to prevent abuse such as illegal immigration and apparent contracts.Why do I think the guideline is so necessary?Three reasons: because of the economic importance of the third -country workers in the EU, because of the competitiveness of the companies and because of the smooth functioning of the internal market.On the one hand, I therefore welcome the strict frame and on the other hand, that the appropriate controls carried out by the Member States are as effective and simple as possible.My question at the end, because I am repeatedly asked about it, goes to the Commission: Will the directive be prejudiced to the accession negotiations?How is Article 1 interpreted and interpreted from your point of view because this plays an important role for our country at the border on the border and in the accession negotiations?President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues!So far, business people had to find that two important freedoms, namely freedom of movement and free service transactions, did not apply to them.They actually had to endure endless bureaucratic immigration procedures by Member States in which a service was to be provided.Around 13 million third -country nationals live in Europe.The number of business people among them is not well known, but it should certainly not be low.

%.This means that funds must be used in order to obtain a maximum effect and information on partnerships must be widely and quickly disseminated.The Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has Only they can invent policies capable of modifying structures that have been created by men and men.Because it is the structural discriminations that women have to face the most, either in politics or in the labor market.It is then the European political parties to open up to women.On the other hand, article 191 of the Treaty (Ex 138 a) indicates that they - textually - "constitute an important factor for integration into the union."The article continues to say that "these parties contribute to the formation of European conscience and to express the political will of the citizens of the Union."While this provision has no legal value, it does not cease to be highly symbolic.It gives political parties an important role in the construction of a democratic Europe.It can be done, for example, introducing positive discrimination measures and promoting parity within our political parties.Some of them presented, on the occasion of the 1999 European elections, joint lists.It is a good practice, which must be generalized.I do not know if there will be a cause-effect relationship, but the case is that the proportion of deputies to the European Parliament went from 25.7% in 1994 to 29.9% in 1999. I will end up repeating the conclusions extracted from the April 1999 conference organized by the commission, entitled "Women and men in power."Equality between men and women is not a problem that only interests women, it is a challenge that affects our entire society!It has recently been made with the increase in the number of women present in the decision -making bodies of the Union.In our own institution, currently 30% of elected representatives are women, including the president of the European Parliament.Finland has just chosen a woman like president.On average, a quarter of the governments of the Member States and just over a fifth of their parliaments are composed of women.This situation is still far from being fully satisfactory, especially since the figures vary greatly between the Member States, where the Nordic countries have a much greater feminine representation in positions of responsibility and decision making.This situation has more to do with the attitude and respect for the quality and ability of women's contribution to society than with fixed quotas.My group is not in favor of quotas in general because, in the long term, they can be counterproductive and even mining the cause for which they were created.However, we recognize that the experience in all member states is not the same, and a certain resource to this type of measures can even be justified as a temporary remedy to rebalance female representation where they are enormously infrared.We support the resolution on women in decision -making, adopted with a view to commemorating on March 8, International Women's Day, which has incorporated ten amendments of the liberal group and softly the reference to the quotas in tune with the approach outlined above.

It is right that the Lisbon summit, which will take place at the end of this month, focuses on the analysis of the situation.Despite their complexity, these processes all have a common denominator: improve the quality of life of citizens of the European Union.In order to achieve this, we do not need new formulas, new working groups or new discussion offices.We know what the tools at our disposal are.Often the opinions of citizens and, sometimes, ideological opposition cause these tools to be used.Now it is extremely important to quickly break down all those obstacles that prevent the creation of a real European internal market;Only in this way will it be possible to avoid having to continue moving in fifteen different national markets, as still happens in many sectors.When, in the 80s, the idea of ​​the internal market began to be carried out, it was possible to maintain a similar pace, to use a metaphor, to that of a steam accelerated train.Today - with the rapid development of the electronic commerce and the speed of transmission and processing of data, the situation is completely different - it would take place at least the speed of Mika Häkkinen's fireball.Nonetheless, we must be sure that, on a decision -making level, the strength does not fail and that the engine does not start losing blows before reaching the finish line.How can we think of creating the most competitive economic area in the world if we don't have the courage to liberalize competition inside it?The already approved liberalization of the telecommunications and energy sector will help to create new jobs and reduce prices for both industry and consumers.In the same way, the demolition of obstacles for small and medium -sized enterprises - regardless of whether they are complex methods imposed by the authorities, access to risk capital or tax issues - is fundamental for the purpose of greater competitiveness and greater well -being.As part of the improvement of global competitiveness, adequate tax harmonization and modernization of our social security systems are also included in order to at least those members of the European Union which have a particularly high tax burden, can reduce the rates that brake the employment process.The foundations are however built through training and research.It is right to try to quickly create infrastructures of knowledge to be made available to businesses, schools and private individuals at reasonable prices or free of charge.In particular, it is important to engage in creating and maintaining sufficient resources to encourage the development of promising employment sectors.Among them, the technological sector, electronic commerce, tourism and, for example, assistance to the elderly, given the undeniable continuous aging of the population are naturally included.Parliament, Commission and Council must remember two important things: regardless of whether it is training and research, development of competitiveness or reduction of obstacles for entrepreneurship, these are tasks in any case of competence of the member countries.

-encompassing from collecting to delivery, which is not fragmented or only partially and as used as the postal service operator fits.However, as is well known, the Commission has commissioned studies to be informed of the Community of the Community of the Community of the Community of the Community, of which it did not inform the European Parliament, and that's why there is no know about the The priority objective of this reflection is to see the instruments that the international community can arrange to stabilize the international monetary and financial system.From this point of view, Mr. Bolkestein, the resolution proposal does not isolate the question of the Tobin Tax.If you read it carefully, this capital flow tax proposal is an instrument among others to try to force international investors to maintain responsible behaviors in financial markets.Secondly, it is not said in the resolution that we want an initiative on a only European basis.This is the reason why we explicitly refer to the autumn sessions of the International Monetary Fund for the European Union, that is, the Commission, but also the Council, take a position on how to defend the opportunity to stabilize the international financial and monetary system and introduce international taxation.I don't want there to be confusion in this debate.We do not want we, an environmentalists, a resolution that is only a alibi.It is not about adding a study to the tens that have already been done - that of the commission would undoubtedly be interesting - but to achieve the commission and the Council, that is, of each of the governments that make up the Union, a clear, positive or negative political attitude, to know if they are willing to defend in the competent public forums, the International Monetary Fund in the first place, the opportunity of such a tax of the other instruments necessary for the stability of the international monetary system.As for the argument according to which this initiative will increase uncertainty, which I know, very short -term capital movements have precisely as a function to play with uncertainty and bet on evolutions between currencies or between different short -term financial assets.This argument does not seem to me therefore relevant.I will not enter the background debate.I think everyone has their arguments.I attract your attention, however, not only on paragraph 9 of the resolution but on paragraph 10. It is clearly a political position what we expect, within a very clear period, the preparation of the autumn session of the International Monetary Fund, and we ask, if this resolution is voted tomorrow in the Plenary, that the commission and the council are presented before the Parliament to tell us what positions would defend on this occasion.Mrs. President, lordships, my group congratulates itself that takes place today a debate like this, even more so that we have not saved efforts with colleagues from different groups to achieve it.Naturally, we do not all have the same approach and I believe that our debate and the resolution proposals that we have presented at the beginning demonstrate it.That said, we are not, in what concerns us, indifferent to the step forward that constitutes the commitment resolution, which invites the commission to submit a report in six months.We think that the European Parliament can thus play its role by taking the initiative, even if it is timidly, on this issue, although of course -and I agree with the preceding speaker -if paragraph 9 will be questioned, this resolution would evidently lose its essence.Our debate touches, indeed, a vital issue that more and more citizens are pose legitimately: what place to attribute respectively to man and the financial sphere in today's economy?

In general we can say that the first is left and manifests social worries, in addition to examining economic problems, while this document, that colleague Katifortis did not consider it appropriate to support - and I think it has done well -, is a hybrid relationship in which, starting from a structure with social concerns, the main conclusions have been taken.What did Mr Katifortis propose and that was removed from the relationship?He offered us an ambitious relationship, in an optimistic Europe, which intended to quantify the objectives for the results they wanted to achieve.In fact, Europe has advanced thanks to programs with quantified objectives.For example, why did the proposal based on which the population active in Europe has to reach 75 percent of the population, while currently 60 percent is to reach in Europe?A rate of 60 percent is very low compared to that of Japan or the United States and with such a modest employment rate we certainly cannot produce as much as the aforementioned countries.We must therefore increase the employment rate with competitive jobs.As supported in view of the Lisbon summit, we must prepare manpower in possession of a scientific training to manage new technologies;In addition, investments must grow at a more tight rhythm.We know very well the idea advocated by colleague Von Wogau, according to which what is needed is the flexibility of the workforce.I wanted to contrast with this argument the Portuguese example, where the laws on work are not flexible and where the unemployment rate is less than 5 percent - and in recent years it has continued to decrease - because investments increase (obviously with community help) at a much higher pace than the average of the European Union.Therefore we want a Europe with economic growth, but attentive to social problems.Mr. President, like many other deputies, I would like to thank the honorable Katforis for the interesting relationship.Reading the text and focusing on the panorama of the European economy that emerges, I derive a very worrying impression of this.The investment rate is too low, unemployment remains at excessively high levels and growth remains insufficient.This is why, probably, it must not be surprised that the euro continues to lose ground compared to other currencies, despite the fact that the ECB is to do in great secret to the purchase of euros to support the course.The signer ascertained that stability does not represent an objective aim;I agree.There is too much talk of stability, convergence and coordination, and too little of the factors capable of inducing innovation and development.In my eyes, cooperation within the UEM is like a clumsy giant that struggles to keep up with such a mobile economy.However, the conclusions I draw are completely different from those of the speaker who preceded me.I believe that it is necessary to focus on human resources, in part through a macropolysis that generates demand and new job opportunities, in part - but perhaps above all - through field measures, in terms of training, democratization of businesses and improvement of social conditions.

If we continue to bother in the proposals that have so far given mediocre results, I do not see how we will advance, or what the Commission can do.The same remark applies to the enlargement which represents its own end without a much more effective reform of the European Union and its structures, and proposals that the Commission could also have made during the CIG.Mr. President, I would like to end with a positive note, perhaps contrary to the advice of certain colleagues, with regard to the telegram you have sent to the Austrian government.Your position has convinced us, you were right not to isolate this country even more.However, we will see in practice what will be the concrete gestures.I repeat, Mr. President, it is a vision in our opinion a little myopic.He especially lacks an impulse in the sectors I have cited, for example the Balkans.Can we continue to exclude the Balkans from enlargement, without thinking that Croatia, Macedonia and other countries also have the right to be part of our Europe?Madam President, Mr. Prodi, I applaud your proposal to make a radical decentralization of Union activities, but I ask you: Why do you then present a collection of centralizing laws?I remember the speech held five years ago by your predecessor.Mr. Santer had made the same promises as you - "less and better" but what we had in the end was "much more and much worse".I don't think you are able to keep your commitments.You talk about decentralization, but you act in centralizing.This collection of laws is only a monotonous list of questions about which citizens will lose all influence;It is yourself, Mr. Prodi, who remove this influence from citizens, even for social issues.You talk about increasing transparency, but you present proposals to hide documents that are today accessible.Your committee is made up of 20 people who are the only ones, within the EU, to be able to propose a reduction in the legislative volume.No local politician has this power from the moment a law was adopted in Brussels.This is why the collection of laws published by the Commission should at least be accompanied by an equally large collection of skills which are returned to the Member States and to the democratic power of citizens, failing which the volume of the legislation adopted in Brussels will not cease to grow.We have adopted 10,000 laws and as many legislative changes;The candidate countries have received 26,000 documents, which represent, for the Polish parliament, for example, 140,000 pages to examine.Already today, this figure is a lot, much too high.Brussels must make fewer decisions and grant more powers in this area to citizens, regions and member states;Only decisions concerning cross -border problems about which national parliaments can no longer legislate effectively must be the responsibility of Brussels.

In its presentation for the summit, the Commission has set quantitative objectives for development in employment, unemployment and female employment.The Commission has also set a goal for the reduction of poverty problems within Europe in the next ten years.It seems good to emphasize common objectives, since the policies of the countries in this field will be different -they must be.In some community countries - not mentioning any, I do not forget any - fight against great youth strike, in other countries such as my own country, Denmark, unemployment among young people is very low, yes, there is even a struggle between entrepreneurs and educational institutions to attract young people to themselves.There are differences between countries, as regards problems, systems, cultures and traditions and therefore there must be differences in the choice of the media with which to achieve the common objectives of greater employment and less social isolation.The design of the employment policy guarantees this through the exchange of experiences and ideas of the Luxembourg process and although there are enough common features in the problems that we will face in the coming years, both with respect to the employment policy and social policy, I must say that there are some common challenges and others that each one has to solve separatesocial problems, but collaborate and serve as mutual inspiration.I want to highlight both the importance that we pursue common objectives and that each country maintains its sovereignty and responsibilities when setting its social and employment policies and that we maintain a certain competence between the systems that ensure dynamism and development in the design of social and employment policies.Mr. President, as a representative of Flanders and in the name - of what I would call - the nationalist regions, represented in the European Free Alliance, his defense in favor of a strong European approach in which each of the fifteen Member States does not attempt does not attempt does not attempt does not try to gain power, but in which cooperation charges more strength.You pointed out the existence of fifteen different public opinions, but in practice there are many more since in the same Member States there are large internal differences.Is it necessary that I, that I am from Belgium, indicate the difference in existing opinions between Flanders and Valonia?Is it necessary to tell you that there is a difference between ancient Eastern Germany and Western Germany?In addition, there is a danger of a duality in our public opinion due to globalization.Instead of the differences of before between the "Havenots and The Haves", today we have differences between those who can follow the rhythm of this society and those who cannot follow it or directly abandon it.

adopted, at the second reading, this report which contains 8 amendments, including a restoration of the original budget of the Commission.The Commission accepted 5 of the proposed amendments, including the budgetary allowance, and I thank the Commission for its constant support for the budget during the conciliation procedure, since the council proposal was unacceptable.During the procedure, we reached an agreement on studies and actions to be carried out to design, implement, supplement and assess community measures.Compromise formulations have been agreed for 5 other amendments, including legislative and non -legislative measures, and the inclusion of local energy centers, and, very important, audit systems in terms of energy in examining the progress made in terms of energy efficiency.I hope you all agree that this is significant progress.Parliament firmly defended the question of the financial envelope in the face of the very thin opening offer made by I want to say that this budget is and has always been modest and that, therefore, the financing of this program is more symbolic than real.It is mainly Member States that finance energy savings.We I am satisfied with the rapporteur's approach to state aid and I congratulate it.There is too often tendency to castigate state aid as measures distorting competition.Certainly an effective competition policy is a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the internal market and the economic and monetary union.However, as the rapporteur points out, such aid is sometimes essential and can allow, beyond the survival of such or such a company, to contribute to sustainable development (article 6 of the treaty), services of general interest (article 16) and economic and social cohesion (article 158).However, it is obvious that they must be controlled, a mission that returns to the European Commission.Aid devoted each year by the Union's member states to the sectors considered reached a total of 95 billion euros during the period 1995-1997, 40 % of which are for the manufacturing sector.These aids decreased considerably compared to the previous period, 1993-1995 (drop by 13 % in the total amount and 3.8 % to 2.6 % of the amount of aid in the manufacturing sector).This decline in aid is mainly explained by the decrease in aid granted to the new German Länder.I deplore, like the rapporteur, that the figures presented in the report do not cover all state aid.The European Commission must compensate for these deficiencies as quickly as possible.It must also cooperate with the Member States to improve the quality of the data in good time, that is to say, for the ninth report.It would be good for the Commission to publish a register which makes the amount of state aid by Member State.I also regret that the European Parliament is completely excluded from the advisory committee on state aid.To compensate for this situation, the European Commission must make, to make us, regular reports.I will finish on one aspect of the use of state aid which seems particularly dangerous to me: these are aid that leads to the relocation of companies from one Member State to another, with the risk of a grant hunt that brings nothing to the common objectives of the EU.This is why I hope that the next report on state aid includes an assessment of the effect of these employment aids, as well as on the industry and craft sectors in beneficiary countries.Langen report (A5-0073/1999) In the important debate on competition, I expressed myself this morning on the text of Mr. Langen, relating to the application in 1998 of the 6th code of aid to the steel industry.As the Court of Justice recognized it in its order of May 3, 1996, the steel sector is particularly sensitive to competitive disturbances.This is why it was legitimate to establish an aid regime in this sector aimed at guaranteeing the survival of efficient companies, although article 4, point C, of ​​the CECA treaty for all state aid to the steel industry.This is, in fact, the object of the 6th code of aid to the steel industry.

I do not want to introduce changes in the text of the common position.The manufacturer is responsible, must be responsible and the last user must be able to deliver the car without costs.In my opinion there are many unjustified fears.The automobile industry pressure group has created confusion on many occasions.I want to reiterate once again to your lordships who, as the experience dictates, the treatment costs must have an impact.They are not such high costs.In my country they are calculated in about 150 florines per car.This begins from day one and at the same time you can carry out the treatment of old cars.Likewise, a great industry can be created now that it is occupied that car cemeteries, which were previously normal in our Member States, no longer exist.Therefore, I do not want to introduce changes in that regard in the commitment achieved.I think it is positive that we approve as soon as possible the legislation that has been presented to us.This is good because the nine million cars that are manufactured every year in Europe can also be properly recycled and this will result in the benefit of all.Mr. President, the current proposal is important in the commitment to prevent the production of hazardous waste from vehicles at the end of its useful life and is important in order to promote recycling and recovery of materials from targeting vehicles.Hence, it seems fundamental from the environmental point of view that the prohibition of the use of toxic heavy metals is fully implemented and that we do not weaken the responsibility of the manufacturers.To make the latter, we eliminate the incentives for manufacturers to build and manufacture cars that produce less residues.The common position achieved with great work in the Council, to which the Commission was added and was also ratified by the Parliament Environment Commission, fully meets the demands in environmental matters and therefore the amendments presented by members of the Environment Commission that have the object of the demands in environmental matters and fundamentally moderate the responsibility of the manufacturers of car are very strange and incomprehensible.If these amendments are approved, I really believe that we will have thrown out the credibility of the Parliament in environmental issues.Until now, this Parliament has acted positively as a catalyst in the defense of the environment, and if the amendments presented by Messrs. Florenz and Lange are approved, in this case we will now be a negative environmental factor.To this we must add that if we soften the responsibility of the manufacturers in this case, this will seriously have an impact on the future in other areas such as, for example, the next directive on electronic scrap and computer science.Therefore, I would like to recommend to the members of this Parliament that despite their political affiliation vote against the amendments presented to the common position that will weaken the environmental standard and soften the responsibility of the manufacturers.

C5-0104/1999 - 1999/2107 (COSS)).Mr. President, the Commissioner, dear colleagues, today, we are carrying out an important debate on the competition policy of the European Union.We debate a very controversial modernization project of European law in terms of understanding, namely the Von Wogau report, a subject much more controversial than the vote within the Economic Commission seems to show.From the outset, I mean that, for my part, and in this concrete case, I believe that the commission's proposal is wrong and that we still have to determine whether the concept of modernization is really justified with regard to the content of the white paper on articles 81 and 82 or if, in this case, a step back would not rather be the appropriate concept.However, today we are discussing the report on state aid and the general report on competition policy for 1998, my contribution to this common discussion affecting the last report.

The legal obligation to reach a situation characterized by zero emissions levels and the termination of discharges within 20 years would in fact mean a ban on the use of all the substances identified.These provisions risk putting enormous problems regarding transfrontier basins and candidate countries and, consequently, to complicate the expansion.I would like to talk about a sector in particular that I follow very closely, that of agriculture, the main consumer of water: it must, as has already started to do, take their part according to the principle according to which those who pollute pays, but must also take into account particularity and constraints, in particular in the arid regions.As for the amendments relating to radioactive substances, I am in favor of the controls, but the question of the legal base arises that falls within the sphere of the Euratom Treaty.Andersson Report (A5-0033/2000) The EDD group was unable to vote in favor of the Andersson report.It certainly contains valid observations;Among other things, it is admitted, on page 15, in the motivation that "the different level of development and the different traditions of the Member States in the social protection sector make uniform harmonization impossible".The concept of "uniform harmonization" is one of those raffazzonate expressions, which obscure the integration process we are talking about.It is also true, as stated in the motivation, that a harmonization would be harmful, in that "it would impose the weakest states of the weakest efforts and, like competition, would push the socially more developed states to proceed with cuts in social protection regimes. Such a harmonization would not benefit anyone".Still, things are like this: a social model is created, which actually involves harmonization, and moreover a uniform harmonization.At point D. It is underlined that "the union can bring a surplus value by defining truly binding and effective convergence criteria", and further on in the report it should be noted that the development of this process of convergence is promoted by discussions between the Ecofin Council and the Council of Social Affairs and employment ministers, and finally in point 7 it is underlined that "the process aimed at creating the social convergence must be accompanied by an effective convergenceambitious ".And here we approach the core of the issue: this social harmonization project does not concern social policy, but it is a continuation of the EUEM project of the European Union which has a very particular interest for the three countries that is outside, and that can be rescued by this Titanic, that is Great Britain, Sweden and Denmark, for this reason it is important for us to emphasize that we cannot support a proposal whose fundamental basis is to expand the UEM project.Mr. President, I voted in favor of the Commission's provision on the modernization of social protection because, in my opinion, it goes in the direction - while not coming completely - to finally offer European legislation in the social and pensioner fields.

Unfortunately, the European Commission has already advanced in its orientations and the position of the Parliament does not weigh heavily in the programs of the period 2000-2006.However, it is necessary to emphasize the need for these funds to aim for priority to the development of countries and regions that encounter the most difficulties and ultraperipheral regions, such as the regions of Azores and Madeira in Portugal, with a view to reaching economic and social cohesion.The truth is that the orientations of the Commission do not fully fulfill these objectives.Furthermore, it is important that there are specific indications and sufficient funds in the fields of quality job creation and with rights, as well as the effective promotion of equal rights and opportunities, in support for the social and solidarity economy, rural development, small and medium -sized enterprises, improving the quality of the life of the urban populations of disadvantaged areas, especially in the social housing sector,sustainable urban development.If the contents of article 158 of the treaty are intended to promote the harmonious development of all communities, it must be said that the total deletion of disparities is still distant.In some cases, as for the Italian regions entering the objective 1, these disparities even increase paradoxically, especially because of the still low approach to community procedures on the part of the structural apparatus and because of the persistent endangered of procedures.Despite normative interventions, the relaxation of community structures must still be carried out.If we do not first carry out an administrative simplification, it is difficult to achieve the community objectives of reforms characterized by efficiency and concentration.In this sense, the Commission's document is incomplete, devoid of any recommendation to the Member States in order to simplify national procedures and legislation in matters of presentation and instruction of projects on the part of the national authorities, as well as in matters of financing, application and control.SMEs, micro-enterprises and craftsmen in particular are still "weak subjects", because for them, the legislative and administrative constraints imposed by certain Member States, including Italy, constitute large obstacles to access to structural funds.A large handicap lies in the inability and impossibility of regions and other subjects to program in time.This is why, the Commission, which should have consulted in time the Parliament, under the decision on guidelines 97/99 (Howitt report), in fact found a sort of easy alibi in the constitution of the reduced programming phase within the Member States and published the guidelines in July 1999, long before the newly elected parliament ends its legislative activities, thus preventing it from acting on the current fansDirectors.The intermediate assessment of article 42 of regulation 1260/99 will therefore take on significant importance.Current guidelines generally do not have the merit of being clear and transparent.They only touch up an important question, however: the possibility of measuring the progress made according to verifiable objectives and in total harmony with the strategies of community policies, and do not properly attach to the implications of enlargement, especially since they do not contain specific provisions or clarification in the matter, nor for the regional and national authorities, or for candidate countries.

We all agree on the conviction of intolerance, but also in the fact that one has to look ahead, and the guilty ones do not have to be sought here, in this parliament or in many other parliaments: the culprits of the events in El Ejido are this minority who wanted to satisfy their vengeance against some immigrants.But one has to take into account that solutions never arise from revenge.The solutions must arise from a functional, social integration and respect for all working there between all authorities and from a determined fight against illegal immigration and a comprehensive respect for the rights of foreign workers who work legally in El Ejido and throughout Europe.President!The present resolution is about solidarity with democratic forces in Spain that fight for the respect of human rights.All Spanish Democrats who feel violated by the events in their country will find our full, unrestricted support.Not only the immigrants were victims of worse riots, but also the democratic system in Spain has been kicked with feet, despite the enormous ability to develop that it has demonstrated in the past 20 years.Immigrants are essential for employers.Their working conditions are so hard and so inhumane that they are not accepted by any Spaniard.Extremely low wages, housing shortages - some live in cardboard huts - lack of opportunities for access to the social institutions, an effective existing apartheid situation - all of this is shameful, unacceptable and incompatible with the necessary respect for every human being.The events in El Ejido are nothing more than racist and xenophobic practices that are no longer permitted in today's Europe.The hunt for immigrants took four days.Women and children were beaten.Hundreds of immigrants who had fled from everywhere have fled to a hill on the edge of the city.It is correct that we put Haider's Austria on the index, but we can not tolerate that small, local "Haiders" pursue a policy of racist exclusion and the merciless economic dominance.What has happened in Spain can occur in all of our Union countries if we are not vigilant.We all have the duty to sweep on our own doorstep.I support the present request for resolution, in particular the digits relating to Article 13 of the Amsterdam Treaty, as well as Section 11 of this resolution, in which a connection between the structural funds and the fight against exclusion is established.The European Parliament would be honored to judge these events and to support all proposals for respect for hiking workers in Spain and the entire Union.President, dear colleagues!In the heart of Europe, the flame of racist and xenophobic violence blows up today.This violence is fueled everywhere by extremist movements that gain in influence.We now have to take concrete measures in order to put an end to such violations of physical integrity.None of our societies in Europe can develop fully if it exists in the risk of hatred of hatred of a part of its population against the other part.

beyond the distribution - of the postal service, as well as the overall evaluation of the results of the studies.Mr. President, therefore, wonders - and, missing Commissioner Bolkestein, I ask the expert Commissioner Monti, who I believe will want to express his opinion -: why not examine, in these studies, the socio -economic impact of the various scenarios foresee for liberalization in each of the Member States?In fact, the postal services are very different in Greece, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands or Belgium.Following liberalization, how can you finance and make the universal postal service of a country like mine, Greece, which has a particular morphology of the territory, taking into account the numerous islands, often inhabited?How can the body in my country be able to survive the universal postal service once liberalized the transfrontier service, which in Greece corresponds to 25 percent and elsewhere less than 5 percent?How will the transfer of the national sector to a foreign country be managed, whose honorable McCartin also spoke?Since this is a very probable event since technological progress makes it increasingly simple and profitable, one should think of a further liberalization, gradual and controlled, with relative fixation of weight and value limits.But what will these limits be?Will it be granted to companies - always skilled in selective exploitation - the right to easily circumvent weight limits, since it is not possible to control the content of the letters?In any case, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, we ask the Commission to reveal their cards and present his proposals, analyzing foreseeable developments from every point of view and for all Member States.It goes without saying that liberalization is not an end in itself, but only a means of improving services.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, the proposed liberalization of classical national postal services inevitably leads to ask what the activities that the posts will consider their core business in the future.In other words: what services will the post office want to continue offering?Which activities can carry out internationally internationally?What areas do they intend to dispose?To respond, it must be taken into account that the old monopoly is no longer such de facto following the appearance of numerous couriers and the introduction of technological developments such as fax and e -mail.On the other hand, employment is of fundamental importance in the case of the liberalization of postal services.

There is no equivocal silence from the council on this subject, Mr. Wurtz.The Council assumes on this subject all the responsibility for the reading he makes of the situation in Cyprus.It was this situation and this reading that decided it, in Luxembourg at the end of 1997, to start the membership process of the Republic of Cyprus to the European Union.I would like you to understand that, regardless of decision -making of a more or less emotional nature on this type of question, the daily life of international negotiations normally obliges governments when I say governments I mean all governments to have a slightly more flexible reading.We indeed need positions of a more emotional nature to maintain the scenario in which all these questions projection on the human level.But we must also keep in mind that it is thanks to the rational character of political positions and the flexibility of negotiation that we can find solutions to overcome the big disputes, ultimately originally from certain great tragedies of history.Regardless of the culprits - we are not here to list the culprits, the relevant United Nations resolutions in this area are clear - I believe that we must enjoy, without emotions and with more rationality, opportunities offered by the new situation.The Helsinki European Council has had the courage to make certain decisions and I believe that different parts of these decisions already take up these opportunities duly in that they can, as I said at the start of my introductory intervention, constitute a window of ooportity.It is not by exploiting the tensions, in this negotiation phase, which is a delicate phase, a sensitive phase, that we can obtain concrete results.It is precisely through discreet work, support work of the mission of the special representative of the United Nations Secretary General that we must continue.The position of the European Union in the matter is unequivocal, ladies and gentlemen, and I believe that it is not worth engaging in second readings on possible sentences which could be in the discourse of the council or in another position.We do not play, within this parliament, in politically correct, we play for international level and for what the concrete positions are, defined by the Council, for a long time and consistently, and which the European Commission has also followed with prudence, attention and pragmatism.When we are currently talking about the need to involve the community of the northern part of Cyprus in an exchange of information, in particular on the way to a future membership of the Republic of Cyprus to the European Union, we must know that we are trying to find formulas of a practical nature allowing us to overcome obstacles on the path of a political solution.We are not looking for subterfuges and we do not seek to create, through practical solutions, any models presenting recognition of a political nature.
