which currently only have the status of annual recommendations to the council to the Member States - would have to be reformed in order to expand their scope and, above all, I quote: "To form their character as a framework even more".The word "frame" should obviously be understood in its double meaning, namely as a summary and obligation.Are we not with these total documents to reinvent the GOSPLAN?This question is justified, especially if you read the French contribution, which goes a little further towards Dirigism, by proposing to coordinate a whole series of national policies, for example in the areas of employment, social security and SME, in Brussels and to present a wealth of quantified indicators, which then be monitored.Such a central control would lead to renewed violations of the principle of subsidiarity, to re -standardization of details, to other coordination, which, despite their different situations, ultimately lead to new rigid rules that would still be added to those in the area of ​​uniform currency.

Italy, for example, in recent years, has encountered difficulties in the use of structural funds, especially due to excessive bureaucracy, a lack of information and the almost absent involvement of economic and social operators at the local level.There are therefore two points to which I would like to attract the attention of the Commission: first of all, it is necessary to use the consultation as best as an instrument of coordination and participation in the decisions of local and regional operators, precisely in order to avoid imbalances and inequalities.Second, it is really necessary to simplify and make administrative processes more transparent, which too often present an unnecessary length and complexity to the point of prejudice access to funds, something of which small and medium -sized European enterprises complain.I conclude, Mr. President, claiming that it is quite serious that the Commission, in his communication, has only paid little attention to territorial pacts and especially to the methods of combating unemployment among women and young people.Mr. President, like my colleague, Mr. Evans, I am delighted that the first speech that I come to pronounce before this assembly relates to such an important subject, in particular because I represent part of the United Kingdom, the West Midlands, which has so far benefited from the funds of lens 2. But the report presented this evening in the Parliament is an excellent example of what, if we do not see,Lack of the substance necessary to be relevant for people by benefiting directly.The report itself starts from a good intention, but, as often happens when we deal with these subjects, lacks clarity as to its objective and a solid base for its operation.This is why my group and I offer three key amendments and additions to the text.It is not a question of removing anything from the proposal but of making it more relevant for those which it intends to guide.I would like to explain our thought.First, we care about the proper use of structural funds and the cohesion fund.The experience of the past shows that we should and we must, as elected deputies of European taxpayers, demand financial probity and transparency in the payment and control of the sums allocated.Our amendments and adds therefore aim to establish indicators of what we know under the expression "to have it for your money" in the process of granting credits.Then, we see far too often that we spend huge sums in projects whose outcome is inevitably uncertain at the start of the program period.But halfway through or at the end of this period, there is no effective way to put an end to the project if it has not been fruitful.Our additions therefore require that practical and applicable exit strategies are provided, so that not only can we have the necessary insurance against continuous costs that taxpayers must often bear, but also that we can avoid the syndrome which consists in a bad deal.Finally, we ask for a change in balance and the method of payment of funds.

I would also like to praise the reasonable and flexible attitude of the council.Save according to the agenda is followed by Ms. Ahern (A5-0010/2000) on behalf of the delegation of the parliament in the mediation committee about the joint draft for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on a multi -year program for the promotion of energy efficiency - Save (C5-0334/1997/0371 (COD)).Ms. President, I would like to thank the Council and the Commission for the successful and thorough implementation of the mediation procedure, in which there was a good atmosphere all the time, which is not always the case.I am pleased to be able to say that I consider the end result to be very satisfactory for the parliament, since all of its amendments have been included in the common text in full or in revised form.The funds ultimately estimated for the program represent a significant improvement compared to the council's proposal in the second reading, which we considered completely unacceptable;We made some progress there.I therefore propose to this house to agree to the suggestions for Save and the conclusion from the mediation in the third reading.I would like to remind the house that we had accepted this report with eight amendments to the second reading, including the reinstatement of the amount originally mentioned by the Commission.The Commission had accepted five of the proposed amendments, including the middle equipment, and I would like to thank the Commission for their continued support in the budget during the mediation procedure, since the council's proposal was unacceptable.In the course of the placement, an agreement on the studies and actions for elaboration, implementation, supplement and evaluation of the measures of the community could be achieved.Furthermore, compromise formulations were found for five further change applications, including the legislative and non -legislative measures, the inclusion of local energy centers and - very important - from energy balance systems in monitoring progress in the area of ​​energy efficiency.I hope you all agree that this is enormous progress.In the question of financial resources, the Parliament steadfastly defended its position in view of the extremely lean initial offer of the Council.To do this, we had to hold several sessions until the Council finally increased the funds on a noteworthy amount.We enforced an increase by two million compared to the initial amount, which is equivalent to a significant increase in the middle equipment.I can recommend this central equipment and the Commission has promised to follow the program afterwards.This played an important role in our considerations.However, I would like to make it clear that this is a very modest financial framework and has always been and that the financing is more symbolic than corresponds to the real requirements.The financing of the energy savings still comes from the Member States for the most part.We have to keep that in mind when we say goodbye to this program.If what we can achieve at community level is more symbolic than real, it is unfortunate because there is a lot of enthusiasm for measures, including community measures, for energy saving at the local level.However, the community can do one thing, namely to bring the local actors into contact with each other so that the wheel is not reinvented in every region.

Taking into account that the contribution of the European Social Fund for the 2000-2006 period will amount to 2,487 million euros and that the Equal initiative is joint financing with the Member States, what will be the contribution rate of Greece?- (El) The equal initiative is not limited to certain groups of people.It is proposed to deal with discrimination in the workplace.The decision to launch this initiative was taken in Berlin and there it was decided to take into consideration and include in their actions the professional groups of asylum seekers.I mention it as an important aspect of this initiative.The community initiative program of each of the Member States has to comply with the regulations, which are the same as the regulation of the European Social Fund, that is, the Equal initiative is addressed to the European Social Fund Regulations.It has been presented to Parliament and we wait next month the opinion of Parliament.I must emphasize that the Equal initiative responds to national needs and national plans, which are defined according to the agreed European strategy.Responsible in the first instance of the constitution of common agencies, for the presentation of the proposals, for the election of the persons who will materialize the programs - and also of the control in the first instance - are the national governments.In the European Commission, the General Directorate of Employment has powers on the application, while the financial control will be exercised, of course, by the General Directorate of Financial Control, as well as by the European Office to Fight Fraud and by the Court of Auditors.The last question refers to the amount granted.Greece has been granted 98 million ECUS and the obligation of participation is 80%, while for the island regions, and especially for the most remote Greek islands, the participation of the initiative reaches 85%with its own corresponding participation of 15%.Mr. President, I am of the opinion that the guidelines on the Equal community initiative, and especially the four actions described therein, lead to a very complex bureaucratic scheme and, paradoxically, little transparent.For example, one wonders in what way an association for development may demonstrate that it has a spirit of collaboration or ability to represent as action 2 in paragraph 33 of the guidelines.On the other hand, the obligatory nature of interstatal collaboration and the complex demands for planning and the expression of an association for development fatally refer to large formations, which are the only ones that can respond to such demands.This, however, comes into contradiction with the proclaimed will of the general objectives, which contemplate decentralized action plans, and, precisely in the field of local administration and rural world.And in addition, at the same time, it makes the participation of the really more disadvantaged - as asylum seekers, emigrants and others - impossible or merely symbolic.Finally, if the global amount is considered, which is rather small -2,800 million euros for 15 countries and objectives so ambitious -I fear that the only thing we will finally achieve will be to demonstrate that unemployment is a very bad thing.- (El) In the first place, I would say that since we are in the elaboration phase by Parliament, it will really help us to make us concrete proposals, which will be taken by us in consideration.Secondly, I have to say that the objective of the Equal initiative is not the reduction of unemployment.This initiative cannot consider the issue of unemployment reduction, nor support for job creation.

Due to the size, unpredictability and irrationality of the global foreign exchange markets, it is becoming increasingly difficult to master the economy at national and regional level.Computer -controlled sales programs were sufficient to turn a random flashing into an avalanche on the screen, under which jobs, life and entire industry were buried in all parts of the world.The only arguments that speak against them are: First, the efficiency of the foreign exchange markets would be affected - one can hardly imagine in view of the enormous pace with which capital is moved back and forth and the annihilation of jobs all over the world, in East Asia, Europe and Latin America.Mr. Chirac has once referred to those who are involved in this business as the AIDS virus of the global economy.We have to sprinkle a little sand in the gearbox of currency speculators, stock exchange brokers and option dealers.Of course, this cannot achieve a single country nor the currency union, but it is possible at an international level and through worldwide cooperation.In my view, Europe, Japan and the United States, the euro, the Yen and the dollar would be such a block.I am disappointed with the PPE.I thought the members would at least read the applications for the resolution they want to vote on.Yes, I support such a tax, but we won't vote on that tomorrow.Tomorrow we will only decide whether the Commission should be commissioned to examine this area and check which steps and requirements would be necessary for the introduction of such a tax.As far as I heard, the commission member also rejects such a tax.However, I cannot understand why he does not welcome a study of this topic, because after all, the result could underpin his position.There is nothing worse than a prefabricated opinion.According to a survey by "War on Want", 47 % of all citizens in the United Kingdom support this tax.In France, this proposal has come across an overwhelming response, especially in connection with the claim to use the income to reduce debts and to relieve poverty in the Third World.This topic can no longer be ignored by Parliament, Council and the Commission.A large part of the public now requires a better answer than: "There has never been such a tax." In the new millennium with its new problems, which require global solutions, the citizens demand good arguments, which is why such a tax cannot be introduced, and they do not want to hear what reasons so far.Ms. President, Commissioner, Varier colleagues, a political compromise from the benefits of taxation of international financial transactions would be a first step towards the indispensable redesign of numerous international regulations.One of the most important demands of the demonstrators in Seattle was exactly the introduction of this type of tax, and this is no coincidence.Proposing them now would be a strong signal of the rich European countries that show that they want to give up their selfish attitude, Mr. Commissioner.According to everyone, such a solidarity tax represents a commendable measure that does not hinder trade, but primarily aims at speculation transactions and their bad effects, revered colleagues from the right -wing parties.

Is the commission proposed an action plan to increase the active participation of women in environmental decisions?The Commission has, since 1988, an action plan for equal opportunities for women and men.With the current program, which includes from 1997 to 2000, it is tried to develop a culture in which male and female values ​​are integrated and in which the specific needs of each sex are taken into account.One of the objectives of the program is to prepare and control methods, strategies and measures that promote the equitable distribution of the sexes in the decision processes, including, in the high positions.Within the framework of this program, each General Directorate prepares a specific action plan.One of the objectives of the Action Plan is to increase the number of women in management positions.The new commission has as a goal to double the number of women in headquarters during their legislature.The General Directorate of Environment, in which currently 60 percent of directors and 20 percent of department leaders are women, is especially active in this area.Our policy is to favor the incorporation of women into administrative positions, to create a reserve of ideal candidates for future management positions.Currently, 24.5 percent of our category A employees are women.We hope this proportion continually grows.In addition, we make efforts to attract qualified women to participate in our discussion forums.With regard to our external partners, we can only give them good examples and urge them to make efforts to democratize their decision processes.Regarding more general issues about the integration of the perspective of equal opportunities between men and women, they surely know that this principle is established in the Amsterdam treaty.Article 3 of the treaty stipulates that the community, in everything that concerns that article, must aim to eliminate deficiencies and promote equal opportunities for men and women.The Commission gives its support to the efforts made in this area and is studying what specific measures can be adopted in environmental matters.Obviously, I want to take advantage to say that I value the role of the Women's Rights Commission of the European Parliament and, especially, its president.Allow me only to remember that when the current commission was approved, the Women's Rights Commission asked each commissioner how they would deal with equal opportunities between men and women in their work area.We are going to carefully control each of the commissioners;In this way I want to warn others too.Thanks for the answer.I interpret it as a yes, as it is an action plan that is necessary;An action plan to incorporate more women in specific environmental fields.Also allow me to say that Beijing's statement underlines the importance of having an institutional capacity to include the perspective of equal opportunities in all environmental programs.

The assembly had exceptionally accepted last year to place the credits intended for these expenses in section 4 so that Cyprus and Malta are not treated as an equal with the candidates from Central and Eastern Europe when they should be in accordance with the declarations made at the Helsinki summit.Resources must therefore be assigned to section 7 for which financial prospects must be revised.This is the salient point.It is essential that the credits allocated as a help of pre -pricing for Cyprus and Malta come from section 7 and that financial prospects are the subject of a revision, because if the council refuses this principle, it will act in contradiction with its own decisions taken in Helsinki in December.As for the amount which appears in the Brok report - 130 million euros - I would like to declare, on behalf of the Liberal group, that we must first negotiate the volume of this amount.The main thing, in this regard, is to guarantee a multi -year program, which is part of the adequate section in order to start the preparations for membership of Cyprus and Malta.Mr. President, the Greens of Greens/European Free Alliance supports the decision adopted by the European Council of Helsinki according to which the resolution of the conflict cannot constitute a preliminary condition for the membership of Cyprus.It is necessary to maintain a strong pressure on the Cypriot government, but the will of the majority of the population cannot be the subject of a blackmail of another part of it, even if we emit great doubts about the representativeness of the government of this part of the island.It is obvious that the opportunity window - the "Janela de Oportunidades", of which the presidency spoke - must be exploited to the maximum.However, we are also convinced that, although Greco-Turkish relationships have improved, this cannot be sufficient.

Berger report (A5-0007/2000) This proposal for a directive aims to establish the conditions for the detachment of salaried workers nationals of a third state as part of a delivery of cross-border services.Indeed, nationals of third countries legally staying in a Member State do not enjoy the right to free movement within the European Union.Until now, extracommunications workers have been seriously faced with obstacles to their free movement within the European Union.It is therefore positive that we facilitate the circulation of workers in the European Union, even if they are nationals of third countries.However, the proposal for a directive targets only their displacement in another Member State if they are in detachment regime on behalf of an employer established in a country where he has his usual residence, so that the possibility of circulating is limited to the detachment period, and only in the Member State where it was detached.This means that the fundamental concern for this proposal is not to solve the problem of circulation of these workers but only to create better conditions for companies providing services.On the other hand, the Berger report introduces, in the name of the simplification of procedures, questionable profound changes, in particular the creation of a common information system giving access to the cards issued by the authorities of all the Member States Berger Report (A5-0007/2000) and Berger (A5-0012/2000).It is with the greatest satisfaction that I welcome the two proposals for directives which aim to facilitate the free movement of working -class workers from third countries while facilitating the free movement of services.Essentially, these proposals introduce the service service/which will allow, in the future, nearly 5 million third -party nationals legally residing in a Member State of the European Union, to provide services in other Member States, something to which problems are today, such as obtaining visas and work permit.The first proposal for a directive will authorize companies established in a Member State who employ third -party working -class workers to temporarily detach these employees in another Member State to provide services.Under the provisions provided, the employer would simply be required to apply for a service provision for each worker concerned.Logically, to be able to hold such a card, the worker must reside legally in a member state and be covered by a social security scheme.The second proposal gives the same rights to the self -employed workers from third countries.If, on the merits, I adhere to the proposals of the European Commission, it is true that certain provisions could be confusing.This is why, I vote in favor of the amendments deposited by the rapporteur.This will clarify the provisions and thus prevent any abuse!Other amendments aim to simplify administrative procedures, for example by authorizing the Member States to appoint a single authority responsible for the issuance of cards.Such a modification seemed essential to me to avoid administrative heaviness which too often slow down the right application of new provisions.

Wijkman).Mr. President, since the 1987 Brundtland report we know that a policy aimed only at economic growth is not and cannot be sustainable in the long term.The challenge that awaits all of us, therefore, consists in the integration of social sensitivity and ecological sensitivity.This implies, among other things, the impossibility of considering ecological sensitivity as a sectoral problem, and the need for any negative consequences of industrial production, transport and construction to be addressed already in the design phase, reducing their impact to minimal through various types of measures.The Rio conference has led to the development of an action program in which, sector by sector, the main problems are listed in this context and in which solutions are expected to guarantee the protection of the environment and natural resources.Although it is a document of various hundreds of pages, it still remains a generic program.

Modernization of social protection in accordance with the agenda, the report of the report is proceeded (A5-0033/2000), by Mr. Andersson, in the name of the Employment and Social Affairs Commission, on the communication of the Commission: a concerted strategy to modernize social protection (com (1999) 347 - C5-0253/1999 - 1999/2182 (COS)..(SV) Mr. President, social protection is an important issue.This is an obvious consequence of cooperation in the community.The base is monetary cooperation, which has later been followed by macroeconomic cooperation and in matters related to employment policy.Now it is obvious to continue with the social protection system.These sectors are interdependent.Economic stability serves as a basis for growth and can give rise to an increase in employment.It also makes it possible to develop the welfare state.However, the opposite situation can also occur: a well -developed social protection policy can contribute to increasing employment and growth.Social security is, in other words, a productive factor.There are differences in the community in social protection.Many of them have historical history.However, today we face a series of common challenges.For example, demographic development, in which not only increases the number of elders but also reduces birth.The labor market also changes.Women are increasingly incorporated into the labor market.Another challenge is technological development.We have to deal with these challenges jointly.The communication of the Commission proposes an increase in the exchange of experiences, the formation of a high -level group and the realization of the benchmarking.In addition, the Social Protection Report is published annually and examined together with the Employment Report.This is helpful, but it is not enough.We propose a procedure such as the Luxembourg process.Clear guidelines and indicators are needed, at the same time that Member States must create methods in national action plans.We create a common model, but we maintain the principle of subsidiarity.Social convergence is a process that will be developed for a long time.Therefore, we must involve Parliament in this work, not making it part of the high -level group, but allowing representatives of Parliament to follow the work of the high -level group and present proposals related to the development of the process.The commission's proposal, like the cooperation in employment matters, is based on four pillars.These are: make systems favor employment, make the sustainable long -term pension system, promote social integration and guarantee high quality and sustainable health.All this is important.In our report we have especially highlighted the importance of the fight against poverty in the EU field and finding indicators, as soon as possible, so that we advance in this matter.Equal opportunities between men and women do not have a pillar.Here the mainstreamer is applied.For this reason, aspects related to equal opportunities must be found in the four pillars.We have done so.We propose many things, for example, to move on to an individualized social protection system, that birth permits allow parents to achieve benefits in the social system, better possibilities to coordinate family and work life and that retirement pensions guarantee decent living standards.

Do you consider, Mr. Commissioner, that the data we have about infant mortality in Kosovo - the highest in Europe - and in general the image of misfortune and human disaster in Kosovo is not seriously damaging our credibility and that does not question our ability to carry out what we have promised?And, Mr. Commissioner, the so -called humanitarian military intervention, is justified by the current image of Kosovo's humanitarian disaster?Do not you think so much inertia cannot be justified when this same right to life is at risk?I do not believe that our reconstruction agency or the operational units before it, which have made huge efforts in Kosovo, consider as a successful description of their work the suggestion that their intervention has consisted of remaining crossed with arms.I am sure that your honor did not mean that.It goes without saying that his honor is right in stating that the credibility of the union will depend on what happens, not only in Kosovo, but in the entire region of the Balkans.I am very concerned that the help we provide arrives as soon as possible and so that it enhances our assistance to the maximum.I would only like to make two observations about the situation in Kosovo, which we deal with all the enthusiasm we can together with WHO.In the first place, I am sure that their honor recognizes that during the period of the 1990s, the Belgrade Government cut the funds for Kosovo health service, and many Albanians discovered that they were not receiving any type of health care.As a result, a parallel health system was created through the sure that their honor will also recognize this, some of the tragic stories from Kosovo during the last weeks did not deal with infant mortality during childbirth, but of child mortality after the thank him for his answer to the first question of my colleague and also to the additional question.However, the contacts that I keep in Kosovo tell me that the food packages that are distributed, obligations with the environment and economic imperatives.The common position of the Council has been to say that car manufacturers should take care of the totality or a significant part of the cost of recovery and recycling.But as Mr. Lange has said very well, this solution is not equitable with European manufacturers.Because I am from a country where there are many automobile manufacturers, I can tell their lordships that it is not possible to impose them, retroactively, the total financial burden of the vehicle set that is currently in use, that is, the load of the costs imposed by 80% of competitive.For this reason, I ask their lordships to support the amendments presented by Bernd Lange, who will have the support of the European Socialist Party Group because, in effect, they reconcile the set of the present interests -economic interests and environmental obligations -while leaving the free member states regarding the modalities of application of these obligations, because these amendments anticipate that the systems currently applied in the Member StatesYou have to work very well- continue to work.Mr. President, Mrs. curator, the directive proposal on vehicles at the end of their useful life today seeks to guarantee, on the one hand, a high level of environmental protection in the European Union and, on the other, wants to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market in that sector.A word about historical and period vehicles: they must be excluded from the field of application of this directive because I think we will all agree on it.Cars also integrate our cultural heritage.That said, one of the obstacles refers to article 12, that is, to the date of application of the Directive.

And so far the restrictions that affect the free movement of extra -community workers in the European Union have been severe.Thus, it is positive that the circulation of workers in the European Union account of an entrepreneur established in the country where they have their habitual residence, so that the possibility of circulation is limited to the period of displacement, and only to the Member State to which they are highlighted.That means that this proposal does not have as a fundamental concern to solve the problem of the circulation of these workers, but only to create better conditions for service providers.On the other hand, in the Berger report, in the name of the simplification of procedures, deeply debatable amendments are introduced, one of whose examples is the creation of a common information system for access to the cards issued by an entity of any Member State.Berger report (A5-0007/2000) and Berger (A5-0012/2000).(FR) with the greatest satisfaction of the two proposals for directives aimed at facilitating the free movement of workers from third countries and also the free circulation of services.Essentially, these proposals introduce the CE services provision card that, in the future, will allow about 5 million from natives of third countries that legally reside in a Member State of the European Union provide services to other Member States, In truth, a hierarchy of oppression was created.Until the same individuals are recognized to all individuals before the law, this inequality will be the cause of discrimination and human rights will be eroded.In the process of expansion of the Union we rightly placed the emphasis on human rights and the protection of minorities.We must not give up this commitment.But we must also look in the mirror and recognize our inadequacies.Yes, the conventions have been signed, but action is required.I would like to propose continuous checks of the observance of human rights, an eternal supervision, not only outside our borders, but also inside.This is the reason why I am in favor of the presentation of an annual report by each Member State, which reports any possible accusation against it and the measures adopted.Because what happens in each Member State happens to each of us.What happens in another part of the world concerns all of us.Pinochet in Chile is as important as Haider in Austria.Human rights and civil freedoms are inextricably connected.Human rights are not isolated, they are connected to our development policies, our economic policies, our internal affairs policies, in reality they are at the center of our democratic functions.I would like to reiterate how much commissioner Patten said: we must commit ourselves, we must inform, instruct and thus make a real and durable change.Mr. President, "Europe means ideals, values ​​and principles. It is necessary to give space to the spiritual history of Europe. We must jointly restore the values ​​that combine Europe. The spiritual values ​​have spread from Europe to the rest of the world. We must live with our consciences".This is what he said in this classroom, three hours ago, the President of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel.In a particularly edifying speech, pervaded of knowledge of the human soul, wisdom, knowledge of history and acumen towards the European spiritual and Christian heritage, he has been able to indicate the sources of inspiration for our work in the matter of dignity of man and human rights.We must be grateful if, in our Europe, there are heads of state like Václav Havel.I wish to dwell on two aspects.First, civil society.Havel recalled that in Eastern Europe the communist regimes systematically made civil society to pieces: popular movements, churches, independent unions.This is also what happens in China with the Falun Gong movement and with the Catholic and Protestant churches.This is what happens with Lamaism in Tibet.We must never forget the defense of civil society.I would also like to talk about the death penalty.The European Union, exactly like Sweden from which I come, has built its vision of the human being on the basis of equality, uniqueness and inviolability of human dignity.Based on this principle, the human being must always have the opportunity to repent.It is said to the government of the United States, the government of Russia and the government of China!Mr. President, Mr. President in office for the Council, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that the line that the Member States of the European Union should follow in Geneva is to grant the priority to situations in Kosovo, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone and China.

The first aspect concerns the fight against poverty, which seems to me to start to transform into a very embarrassing story for the union and for the Member States.Although both in the Treaty and in the UN conferences of Rio and Copenhagen we have made the commitment to eradicate poverty worldwide, in reality the balance of development cooperation is reduced, in contrast with the intentions declared.It is a trend that must be broken.First of all, it is necessary to proceed with the cancellation of the debt.It is necessary to move from words to deeds.I hope that we will be able to take on a guide role in this task.The second aspect concerns the fact that, in numerous situations, we say that ACP countries must learn the foundations of democracy.At paragraphs 2 and 3 of the resolution, in the framework of the new agreement, the working methods are developed and optimized, and that the ACP countries are encouraged to contribute to the debate with a plurality of political opinions.It is fine, I can only sign it.At the same time, however, we must ask ourselves how we ourselves manage democracy.How do things work within the delegation of the European Parliament at the ACP-EU Joint Assembly?In contrast to the way in which things go within parliament and his commissions, in which after all, the speakers are designated and therefore appointed, in the delegation at the joint assembly there are no rules.The two large groups spart up all the relationships, the general relationships etc.Just to change this non -democratic operating mode, the Verts/Ale group presented amendment no.6. In this amendment we ask that the appointment of speakers for all relationships, including work groups and general relations, is carried out on the basis of clear and democratic rules.In this regard, small groups must be taken into account and the appearance of representativeness.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, first of all, I would like to congratulate me in turn with the honorable Corrie for the quality of his relationship, which reflects with relevance the tenor of the discussions of the joint assembly whose covers he ensured very effectively.The elimination of poverty was at the center of our works and, to achieve this ambitious objective, many of the intervenes had drawn attention to the need to preserve an essential tool, i.e. the preferential agreements between the European Union and the ACP countries, within the framework of the conventions of Lomé.The challenge was arduous.The globalization, the liberalization of trade, as well as the pre -eminence of the WOP and the world philosophy of which it constitutes the vehicle, endangered the very essence of dialogue between the north and south.It is therefore only possible to welcome the conclusion of the new partnership agreement for development and my part I am convinced that the works of the last joint assembly have exercised a decisive influence on the unlocking of the negotiations, such as the new climate created by Seattle's events.However, while rejoicing me with the renewal of the agreements, what attracts above all my attention is the new wind that blows now in our relationships and which manifests itself with the balanced character of the negotiation that turns to the end.

as the Portuguese Prime Minister recently did - that the persecutions of Serbian populations, of those of zigana ethnic groups and other ethnic groups are totally unacceptable.They will not be tolerated and will have to cease immediately.It has been communicated and reiterated explicitly to the managers of Kosovo that international support will largely depend on the treatment that will be reserved for non -Albanian minorities.This point seems to me of the utmost importance;The European Union will maintain the sense of conditionality inherent in this position and the same applies to the Council.We fully supported the efforts of the United Nations mission and the international security force in Kosovo aimed at avoiding new manifestations of violence against minorities and protecting threatened populations.The KFOR and the UNMIK police consider the suppression of all forms of mistreatment due to the ethnic origin as one of their primary tasks.In this context, the Council has congratulated its conclusions in December for the substantial contributions announced by the European Commission which, together with others of a similar nature offered by the Member States, will indirectly contribute to normalization of the situation.However, honorable parliamentary, the Council is also aware of the fact that the set of the means made available to the international structures responsible in Kosovo do not correspond, in terms of mobilization of the various Member States, as it would be desirable and this has limited the actual capacity for intervention on the field of the structures themselves.We will not stop, however, to focus all our attention on this problem, as the entire credibility of the Albanian authorities and structures in the area also depends on the ability of these same structures to prove that they are able to apply measures that guarantee multi -ethnicity within said territory.Thanks, Mr. President in office for the Council.

The objective of this regulation proposal is to create the first program of application of the preadite strategy for Cyprus and Malta, as of the year 2000 and for a period of five years (2000-2004).Therefore, the proposal aims to facilitate the legislative approach to the community "collection" and the correct application of said "collection."It is a new registered step within the framework of the Helsinki European Council last December.Thus, in this Council, in view of the progress made by Malta, it was decided to open bilateral conferences as of February 2000, that is, before the end of the month, in order to initiate negotiations on the conditions of adhesion to the European Union and about the necessary adaptations that must be carried out.Regarding Cyprus, although the Council confirmed "that a political solution will facilitate the adhesion of Cyprus to the European Union", "this does not constitute, however, a previous condition regarding its decision on adhesion", so I congratulate myself.Indeed, I have always considered the approach consisting of conditioning the beginning of negotiations with Cypring to the search for a solution of the situation that affects the third part of the territory of this Republic, occupied by Turkey.In general, it is true that the socioeconomic situation of these two countries is much more favorable than that of other candidate countries.However, these have been able to benefit from a technical and financial aid of the European Union for the transposition of the community "collection.This technical and financial aid has been provided until the end of 1999, within the framework of the four financial protocols (B7-4011).Both countries are also beneficiaries of financial aid of the Meda program (B7-4012).In its first and second reading of the 2000 Budget, the European Parliament emphasizes that the new title "Preadhesion" (B7-0) proposed by the Commission in the budget of budget should not be limited to the associated countries of the central and eastern Europe, since it should also encompass Malta and Cyprus.However, given the advice of the Council to negotiate the necessary review of the maximum limit of rubric 7 (preadsion) of the financial perspectives, the European Parliament accepted, exceptionally - I emphasize this fact -, finance the corresponding expenses with charge to rubric 4 (external measures) of the financial perspectives for the year 2000. Simultaneously, the European parliament created a new chapter created a new chapter.to the "preadhesion strategy in favor of Mediterranean countries" (B7-04).Within this chapter, two new articles on the preadhesion strategy were created in favor of Malta and Cyprus, waiting for the present commission, in accordance with the European Council of Helsinki, the legal foundations and the review of the maximum limit of rubric 7 of the financial perspectives.This regulation proposal should constitute one of these legal foundations!.(In) I greet the report of Mr. Brok that reinforces with amendments the proposals of the commission aimed at preparing Cyprus and Malta for adherence to the European Union.The package will allocate about 15 million euros in total to both countries in this year.It should be regretted, however, that the Commission has avoided multinational financing and has decided in return to assign funds on an annual basis.

The melody that will be played will be a melody listened to by the citizens of Europe and they will want to hear the right one.As it was described this afternoon, it will contribute to a large extent to forget the unpleasant melodies that we had heard at the time of the European elections and in the past few months.The Treaty of Amsterdam and the Tampere Council develop the project of space of freedom, security and justice.There is one aspect, however, which is very important and in which this parliament must participate, I mean control.The legislation is so abundant - and I take this opportunity to congratulate the Portuguese presidency for its program which was presented to us last week - that we must have absolute certainty that it is closely followed, that deputies in the European Parliament, deputies of national parliaments and European citizens are aware of everything it implies.In addition, we must ensure that it is, in all its details, applicable, appropriate and useful to each of the different countries.I would like to draw attention to certain aspects of the resolutions that are submitted to us this afternoon, one or two of which have already been mentioned before.I congratulate myself on evolution towards the recognition of judicial systems between different countries and towards cropration in criminal matters.European citizens will not remain indifferent to it and they will rejoice.However, the Commission and the Council must know that many deputies in this assembly have reservations to be made, against the Eurodac system for example.We admit the predominant role of the council in this matter, but reservations exist and I am sure that the council will have CUR to listen to what the elected deputies present here have to say when the subject is deepened.Mr. Schulz said he was not sure of the definition to give to the word scoreboard.Any English or British, or whoever follows a cricket match, knows what a scoreboard is.The scoreboard, or display board, gives spectators the score of the match;He must follow the developments, he must be clear and clearly visible.I have no doubt that Commissioner Vitorino will make sure that it is so.I hope that at the end of the six months, music will always play and that citizens will always be attentive.Mr. President, allow me to welcome the President in office and his colleague from the Ministry of Justice, Mr. Costa.I would like to thank them for the welcome they reserved for my committee last week in Lisbon, and for the constructive meetings we had.Amsterdam and Tampere have given us a lot of work to do together, as shown in the excellent resolution project of Ms. Terrón today.I would like to raise three fairly short points.The first is that it is time that we have a thoughtful dialogue between the Council and the European Parliament.It has been just six months since the Amsterdam Treaty requires our two organizations to work hand in hand: we gauged ourselves, we Since the adoption of Directive 86/611, the investment funds sector has continued to evolve, so the regulations in force need to be modernized.The new proposals pretend to guarantee the maximum level of investor protection, which is a sine qua non condition for the integration of markets following the introduction of the euro.Given that an average European family allocates its savings to investment funds, the proposals contain provisions regarding prudent management - I want to insist on it - a prudent management in terms of investment policy and risk diversification refers.Both proposals constitute a unitary whole.The first of them expands the number of instruments in which a "collective investment agency in transferable values" -OICVM- can invest.As already indicated in this session, the IACVs are one of the most important protagonists of the modern capital markets.Thanks to their presence, the number of non -professional investors who can participate in these markets has been increasing, without prejudice to the principle of distribution of risks and adequate supervision.Since the possibility of opting for diversified investment modalities is contemplated, private investors can benefit from all the advantages offered by new investment techniques.The second proposal expands the role that these important mediating agencies can perform in the capital markets of the European Union, as far as the development of the investment funds is concerned.From the moment there is the possibility of creating bouquets and performing certain cross -border services, these agencies can finally use the freedoms contemplated in the Treaty of Rome that have been denied during all these years.The Commission applauds many of the clarifications proposed by the Commission for Economic and Monetary Affairs and will adopt much of its ideas.More specifically, the Commission will adopt - and now I use the most recent numbering - the amendments 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 13, 19 and 21 as far as the first proposal is concerned and the amendments 23, 28 and 32 as far as the second proposal is concerned, since it is clearly a clear clarifications and improvements.In addition, I value the ideas expressed in amendments 1, 10, 11, 14, 18 and 20, although they will be formulated in another way.I also agree with the underlying idea of ​​limiting the risk of counterpart to a maximum percentage that appears in the amendments 17, 36 and 45. In the same way I can accept the content of the second paragraph of the amendment 47. All the amendments that I just mentioned refer to the first proposal.As for the second proposal we can adopt the ideas expressed in the amendments 24, 25, 29, 30, 41 and parts of the amendment 27, since they include sensible suggestions, as long as their writing adapts.In other words, the Commission is willing to adopt their content, but proposes that its formulation be modified.In addition to this, I take notice from the request of the Commission for Economic and Monetary Affairs to prepare a full text coding once it is approved.This request is reflected in amendments 7 and 22 of the first and second proposal respectively.

Second, we must see what are the capacities of each country, so that this overall force of 60,000 soldiers can be distributed in an orderly and effective manner between the fifteen countries.Tertio, we must see what are the differences between the Headline Goal and what each country can bring.It is possible, ladies and gentlemen, that we do not have enough capacities in the fifteen countries and that the latter must all make an additional effort to deal with the needs that we have offered.How are we going to do?We want to do so by summoning a conference of the fifteen countries to see the differences between the objectives set and the means we have to achieve them and see how what we are missing is distributed between the fifteen countries that form the European Union.Ladies and Gentlemen, Madam President, we want to fix the calendar so that, during the French Presidency, in December 2000, we can close this process by a large conference generating forces of all countries so that needs and capacities are equivalent and that we can therefore sincerely say that we already have the plan of what we have to do from the end of 2000 to 2003decided that the capacities will be underway.Ladies and gentlemen, that is what we do, to which we are committed to.I believe that we have worked well in recent months, in recent weeks and I think that we will be able to work during what remains of the year 2000 during the Portuguese presidency - which really does extraordinary, magnificent work - and continue during the French presidency which, without any doubt, will continue to work with the same promptitude and the same capacity as that which it has shown on other occasions.I wanted to tell you that in the meantime, there will be at least four European advice, that of Lisbon, that of Feria and two European councils during the French presidency.During these councils, the heads of state and government are also ready to pursue the examination of these questions so that we do not reject the train and that we are able, by 2003, to deploy what we have agreed, if necessary.Consequently, Ladies and Gentlemen, Madam President, I think that in this area, we work with determination, energy and with the broad support of all governments and all heads of state and government.Ladies and gentlemen, I would still like to add two things.The European Union has the obligation to carry out all this operation by keeping contact with the third countries to which I have referred, countries which, although members of Europe from a geographic point of view, are not yet part of the European Union.These are countries with which we must work, which we must integrate because, if a crisis occurs, God keeps us, all the forces and all the countries will be more than welcome.Then we must be able to establish a fluid and transparent relationship with NATO.The operations that we will have to carry out in the future will be of three types: the first takes up the operations in which European forces participate in the context of NATO;The second takes up the operations in which European forces participate and which they direct, but using NATO's means and infrastructure;The third takes up the operations where Europeans will act alone.

Strongly concerned about the continuation of human rights violations in Tibet and in order to support the proposal of the Dalai Lama aimed at establishing a dialogue with the Chinese government in order to resolve the Tibetan situation, the inter-group working group "Tibet" therefore asks the commission to appoint a delegate for Tibetan affairs, who will take care of the European Union,will strive to bring the Tibetan, Chinese authorities or their representatives to start a dialogue.When does the commission intend to name this Tibetan affairs delegate?The floor is to Mr. Patten, on behalf of the Commission.The concerns expressed by the European Parliament about Tibet are widely shared.I have long believed in the need to clearly and sincerely expose our points of view on human rights, including in Tibet, to the Chinese authorities.This is what the European Union did last month, at the European Union-China summit in Beijing, during which we have exerted pressures with the Chinese on a series of questions relating to human rights, including in Tibet.Once again, we invited the Chinese to start a dialogue with the Dalai Lama.Once again, I invite the Chinese to do so.We will continue to raise the question of Tibet with the Chinese authorities.We also undertake other actions: during the dialogue between the European Union and China on Human rights, we focused on a series of practical measures, including the sending of mission experts to Tibet, planning development assistance programs and activities relating to health, education and training for Tibetans.It is to the council that the appointment of an EU special envoy would mainly return to Tibet and the European Parliament could tackle the issue directly with him.As far as I'm concerned, I am not sure that our efforts would gain a lot from a practical point of view.It is unlikely that it will have a great impact on the Chinese authorities and we already have effective communication channels with the Tibetan community in exile.I would also like to avoid an exponential growth in the number of special envoys, whatever commendable.Mr. President, Mr. Patten, of course you benefit from an excellent experience of China because of your journey and you most certainly know how the Tibetans are trying to obtain the implementation of dialogues, which have all been avoided so far.If your answer is limited to telling us to send us to Mr. PESC, to Mr. Solana, I fear that it is a unilateral orientation in terms of foreign policy.Your approach, which I gladly recommend for its consistency, is inspired by the theme of human rights.I totally agree: we must take care of the theme of human rights.Detention, torture, mutilation of young women and other similar practices are all themes of discussion quite endless.If we reduce all this to say that the Council is competent in these matters, I fear that the questions relating to human rights do not come enough in the foreground.The possibility of insisting on the one hand on the economy and trade while including the issue of human rights would be a measure for which we would actually be able to tell the partnership of the European Commission and would not say that this is the case of the Council.

Therefore, I support Mr. Swoboda's well -founded report - we are not used to anything else - and therefore also my appreciative words about the respectable Republic of Macedonia.Mr. President, revered colleagues, allow me to pronounce my personal recognition for the quality of his work, the rapporteur, Mr. Swoboda.Today we make an advisable statement on the initiation of negotiations on a stabilization and association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Macedonia.We do this in the consciousness that this decision, the first ever that refers to this region, is specified in a completely new phase of our relationships with the Balkans.He himself is a factor of this new phase or a policy that sees the only way to solve your conflicts in the future integration of this region into the European Union.Our approval of the negotiations, as proposed in the justification of the rapporteur, is based on our conviction that it is correct to combine both a regional dimension in the Union politics and the specific appreciation of the efforts and results of the individual member states in the alignment with each other.In my opinion, this double objective must be pursued.Therefore, on the one hand, the programs related to the infrastructures, for example, must be prepared for the creation of a free trade zone - for which it is still too early - and forms of economic and commercial cooperation between the Balkan countries, and on the other hand, it is time to create a model for a narrower integration policy with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.For various reasons, we cannot avoid a positive statement.As we found in the framework of our missions in Skopje, in the former Republic of Yugoslavia, the progress in the economic sector, on the way to democracy and on the - in the Balkans region - quite difficult and conflicting - area of ​​living together between different ethnic groups are remarkable;On the other hand, a high price was paid for the war in neighboring Kosovo, both by providing logistics for the NATO forces and the falling exports to Northern Europe.In conclusion, I would like to emphasize that these developments are undoubtedly difficult, inconsistent and insecure and that we demand constant vigilance in relation to the various stages that must be expressed through regular and targeted checks.President, Mr. Commissioner, revered colleagues!At this point I would like to express that negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are welcomed by the faction of the liberals, the Democrats and the reformers of Europe.I have the strong hope that this agreement may serve as an example in its basic features in his rapporteur, Mr. Swoboda, and as soon as possible to other countries, especially in Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Montenegro, Kosovo, and as soon as possible is also extended to Serbia.According to our conviction, a rapid introduction to these negotiations and their rapid conclusion are the only way to create peace in the region - those peace that has not automatically occurred since the end of the war in Kosovo - and thus prevent conditions for further decay again and that chaos and violence will be used again, which leads to instability in Europe, if not in the world.

That the public accepts such prices without abandoning financial operations in panic can be explained by the too optimistic expectation of future profits.Speculative activities develop beyond any measure and in turn feed profits which, one day, will prove to be fictitious.Excessive optimism will succeed disenchantment and fear, with the consequence of a stock market crisis and, possibly, an economic crisis.The risk is too large for you to ignore it.We have to face it, even if it seems difficult.Modern economic science has given us a remarkable tool with the proposal of Tobin and others that we could use if we had the political will to start acting.This is what we miss, Mr. Commissioner, the political will to start attacking speculation.But the blissful admiration or resignation in the face of market forces, the professions of faith of the Liberals - and I regret that Mr. Gasòliba I Böhm no longer sits among us - cannot continue indefinitely to characterize democracy, because they lead us straight for the disaster!Madam President, Mr. Bolkestein, it is quite incredible to see how ignorance permeates this discussion.It was necessary for a Greek colleague to tell us what this Tobin tax meant.You refuse it without any other form of trial because you do not understand anything.It is perfectly clear that the right is opposed to taxes;Otherwise, it would never have dared to transfer these millions, even these billions, to Switzerland.It has become clear.Now, I am calling you - with full knowledge of the facts - to help stop speculative financial capital, to finally support long -term projects by long -term capital.This has never been done in Southeast Asia, it has never been done in Europe and, to consider their financial management, I can understand that our Austrian Karas colleague is no longer there.It's the same mess.We need a Tobin tax to be able to intervene via a tax instrument.Madam President, I am revolted with the political ignorance of this commission, that is to say Commissioner Bolkestein.Given his position on the Tobin tax, he should really wonder why he is here.Madam President, I too had the impression of a ghostly debate somewhat.It is undoubtedly no coincidence that no preservatives be present because the idea of ​​market freedom they defended has nothing to do with the august principles of the social market economy which have brought so much prosperity to Western Europe in recent decades.If we continue to assert the sacrosanct nature of the markets - such is the ideology - and even to maintain that any intervention in the functioning of these markets is opposed to the progress and the growth of the economy, we most certainly be wrong and this can take very dangerous proportions.Currently, capital holders still have colossal fortunes that are asking to be reinvested.

I condemn the false arguments that, since both sides, it has been tried to deceive the deputies and public opinion in the context of this difficult and partly technical theme.That is why I especially appreciate the intervention of the colleagues in my group that contributed to make some commitments possible.Above all, I want to especially thank the enormous work that our rapporteur has done, Mrs. Lienemann, and her cooperative attitude, even when discrepancies still subsist in relation to some points.I also want to express, on the other hand, my thanks to the representatives of the European Commission, who have always been available to advise us and offer us technical help.If the representatives of the Council of Ministers adopt the same constructive attitude, I have no doubt that in the conciliation procedure we will achieve an even more appropriate solution for the protection of the aquatic environment in Europe.Mr. President, first of all I want to congratulate Mrs. Lienemann for the excellent work she has presented and for the effort she has made when approaching the differences that separate us in the issue of water.The Water Framework Directive is a necessary initiative.However, and based on the fact that the idea of ​​solidarity is intrinsic to the European construction process, this directive must be taken into account that water resources must be understood as a social cohesion factor.Water -Nadie doubts- is a good of general interest.However, in the case of Spain and other southern countries, which present an irregular weather, the management of water resources requires political approaches to rationalize its use and other solidarity measures.Therefore, we consider that this Framework Directive must advocate a use of water that allows to overcome territorial imbalances and, for this purpose, I request its support for the amendment 95, which our group has presented.We want to ensure that in article 1 of the Directive a sustainable, efficient, fair and solidarity of water is promoted.I will now make a brief review of the main issues in which the Spanish socialist delegation maintains some divergence with respect to certain positions that are defended here.This is the case of the transfers.It would seem better than the future Framework Directive, it would not be subject to community supervision the possibility of carrying them out.We consider that, given the hydrographic characteristics of the Spanish State, where transves of structural nature are carried out, it must be the authorities of the country that decide on the resources of their own territory, a decision that, of course, should always be taken from the criteria of the search for cohesion and the rational use of water.With regard to one of the most controversial points of our debate, that of the tarification, the Spanish socialists have been defending that, since respecting the principle of "who pollutes pays", the directive advocates accessible price policies for all levels of consumption.It is evident that in Spain a full recovery policy of water costs would not have the same impact as in the countries of the center and northern Europe.The Spaniards would see the price of water increased for their various uses due, precisely, to the shortage of water resources and the internalization of environmental costs that will be necessary to carry out within the framework of the provisions of the Directive.

I spoke of the extraordinary European Council and the intention to make it expressed by Portugal;I talked about it with a future perspective, as there are two complementary ways of dealing with the question of social exclusion: one of them is represented by the set of measures to be adopted in the immediate time in order to combat its concrete effects, the second is represented by the creation of conditions of competitiveness internationally that allow us to improve the economic fabric within the Union with positive consequences on the problems of social exclusion.However, the Portuguese presidency does not have miraculous recipes to answer in six months to issues that have always lasted.There is the willingness to operate in these areas, on the proposal of the Commission, in all areas of community competence and of course it is possible - and it is our interest - to encourage together the initiatives that will be presented, in particular, by non -governmental organizations, but also thanks to the traditional intergovernmental coordination in these sectors.However, it must be kept in mind, honorable parliamentary, that it is not possible to operate in an area of ​​such great impact, from a financial point of view, only and only through measures proposed by a presidency in charge for only six months.For this reason, we believe that only the measures envisaged in the context of long -term strategies - although knowing, is true, that in the long run some homeless people may be dead - they will allow us to launch sustainable policies at the European Union level.And it is to these strategies that we will try to contribute in the best possible way during our semester.Question n.12, of the Honorable (H-0801/99): subject: the Portuguese Presidency and Development Policy intends to the President in office to make a declaration on the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency as regards the development policy, the Lomé Convention and the way to face the situations of famine?I would like to thank the presidency for the comprehensive answer provided to my question, and in particular the minister who spoke at the commission for development last week in Brussels illustrating the matter.However, there are still some problems to solve.No accent has been placed in the program on the fight against AIDS.The situation of AIDS in Africa has now become serious to the point that more people die due to this disease than in conflicts.I hope the minister dedicate some time to this particular issue.In the United States, drugs are available, but the price applied does not make them accessible to African peoples.I would like to ask the minister what he is doing exactly about the situation that is developing in Ethiopia where there is drought, the crops have not been successful and where in six months we will inevitably return to the situation that existed a few years ago, characterized by the famine and the death of thousands of people.At the same time, a war between Eritrea and Ethiopia is underway and the European armaments industry sends its weapons, after which we will send the bread.Mr Parliamentary, first of all I would like it to be clear that I disagree with the interpretation you have given to the intervention of my colleague during the meeting of the Commission for Development and Cooperation.
