It is in this spirit, almost provocatively, that we have presented an amendment intended to suggest the transfer of skills for southern Europe from foreign affairs to expansion.The fastest and most direct involvement of south-east Europe to the life of European institutions has led us to suggest that a limited number of observers are accepted, sent by national parliaments to the European Parliament, and that staff of those countries can work at the Court of Justice and the Commission.However, to encourage the evolution of the Region towards a more democratic society and more based on market economics, we are above all convinced that immediate and concrete steps must be taken to intensify the fight against corruption and to make international aid for reconstruction and development more efficient.For this reason we have presented some amendments, which I hope the Parliament will want to accept: first, to offer the former Republic of Macedonia a customs tariff equal to zero for its exports to the European Union and a compensation of the progressive reduction of customs rights applied by Macedonia on European products, provided that the principle of a combination of joint customs control is accepted;second, that the former Republic of Macedonia is encouraged, with adequate financial support, to gradually hook its coin to the euro as the first step towards a Europeanization of the entire Macedonian economy, and this with the further purpose of eliminating every possible corruption to the banking system;Third, that the help and assistance that the world must give to the Region, and therefore also to Macedonia, has the marked character of multilaterality, without conditioning the beneficiary country to obligations directed towards the donor country.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, we hope that the agreement can reach all the purposes that aims but we cannot delude ourselves that peace, stability and prosperity in the south -east of Europe can be achieved without dealing with themes on much wider problems, which we try to remove: I refer to the future constitutional state of Kosovo, to the need to involve Serbia in the process of reconciliation of the region andNo?- to the re -discussion of the relations between the European Union, NATO and the UN, in the light of the new balance to be found between humanitarian interference and state sovereignty, which I believe will have to change the same card as the UN.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the war in Kosovo has created a climate of great instability.This instability above all characterizes the relationships between the European Union and the Western Balkans.Since then expectations have been particularly high, both in that region and in our countries.In that region why, whether we like it or not, in addition to the request for direct aid, the question that arises is: what does Europe intend to do with us?Is there the possibility of adhesion?These are very felt questions in all the countries in question.The expectations are also strong here by us, in the European Union.If we act correctly, this could be the first test of the existence of a true foreign policy and common security.

That is why the institutions of the European Union have developed a comprehensive negotiating and consultation activity in the Amsterdam contract after taking the declaration No. 31, which ultimately culminated in the new decision of the Council, with which the old system is largely changed, but not satisfactorily changed for us.In particular, a check right of the parliament, i.e.h.The possibility introduced to "ring the alarm bell" if a measure to carry out a legal act issued according to the co -decision procedure violates the authorization authority transferred to the Commission.In the course of the lengthy interinstitutional negotiations, in which the parliament was actively involved thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Adelaide Aglietta, the goal was to conclude an interinstitutional agreement on the modalities of the application of certain aspects of the new decision.On the one hand, in order to clarify certain points that the Council was not willing to include in the decision, and on the other hand to regulate the information and control system with regard to the implementation measures more precisely.As part of the trilogue of October 6, 1999 in Strasbourg, the President of the European Parliament and the President of the Commission approved the proposal to conclude this agreement quickly.We believe that we have complied with this obligation, which, however, was relatively easy for us, since there was a climate of trust and mutual respect during the entire negotiation with the Commission.In the agreement, two points are essentially dealt with: On the one hand, this is the inform of the European Parliament as a conditio sine qua non for the actual exercise of his right of intervention in accordance with Article 8 of the decision.This information has so far been carried out on paper and unsystematically and was often unusable for our services, partly also by the guilt of the parliament itself.From now on, this information is ensured by an electronic system with the name Circa, to which the European Parliament has access and not only for us, but also - I am sure - is a real innovation for the commission.On the other hand, in Article 8 of the Council decision neither the procedure nor the deadline are mentioned, within which the European Parliament "ring" alarm bells, i.h.must exercise its limited control authority.In point 6 and 7 of the agreement it is stated that the European Parliament generally accepts its resolution in the plenum and has a period of one month to make use of its right to intervention before the commission's draft.However, we are all aware that it is not always possible to wait a month before a implementation measure is issued.Therefore, an urgency procedure is expressly provided for in the agreement, in the context of which the responsible committee can work.Finally, I would like to emphasize that we have to wait and see how the agreement works in practice before we can assess whether it is a good agreement or not.The European Parliament will have to equip itself with it not yet available in order to ensure an effective course of the implementing methods and effective control, and the commission will have to accept a reorganization of some of its procedures in order to ensure effective control and an actual information of parliament.

In the group of the People's Party there is no clear agreement on the question of supporting the mandatory quota regulation.Some members even speak against it.Personally, I don't want to feel a quota, I don't want to think that I am only on a certain position because I was born as a woman.This is a feeling that the men will never have, and an essential difference.I would also like to thank the minister and the commission member for their contributions, and I agree with the latter that it is time that beautiful words are converted into action.We all know how small the proportion of women in decision -making is at all levels, because we know the statistics, and they speak volumes.I agree that precise statistics are also necessary, because we will only learn from the fact that we slowly overcome the problems when we see how the numbers change.We will be able to recognize this with systematic monitoring.Mainstreaming is a long -term obligation.In the meantime we need positive measures, which means that we use odds and similar measures.We can learn from the mentioned successes, and not only by looking at the actual number of female MPs, but also on the effects they had on the government composition to clarify that everyone benefits from a really representative system.I am pleased that the proportion of women in the National Assembly in Wales, which I represent, is 40 %.That is the result of positive measures by the political parties;On the other hand, only four women from Wales are represented in the lower house, which is just 10 % of all MPs.Therefore, fundamental statements and basic support are not enough because they do not work.If we trust in the principle of equal representation of women and men in the decision structures, we have to participate in the measures that are necessary for its implementation.President!At the second international socialist women's conference in Copenhagen in 1910, it was decided to combine the main claim to combine voting rights for women with the entire question of women.In addition, as noted in the resolution, the women's day should be preserved and well prepared.It is also noteworthy that Women's Day was later banned in all countries in which fascism and racism came to power and between the wars.In 1910 the right to vote for women was on the agenda.Nowadays we focus on participating more women in the decision -making processes.Women are not a homogeneous group.They belong to different social classes, have different individual needs and interests.In general and continuously, however, regardless of where we are, regardless of class, breed or religion, whether at home or at work, we are subordinate to men in all areas of society - with a few individual exceptions, you should probably add.In my home country, Sweden, several political parties have voluntarily introduced a quota regulation for the election to political committees and the occupation of political offices in recent years.This has led to an increasing number of women in political decision -making, which in turn opened new opportunities for research.

In September we promised to carry out a reform with the presentation of the White Paper and today we fulfill the acquired commitment, in the terms we have assumed before you.The Commission wants to be judged by the facts, only for the facts, on the basis of what we are going to do.However, I remind you - it is my last reflection - that the Commission is not the only community institution.Parliament and Council are also called to fully accept the challenge of these reforms.The commission has opened the road resolutely: I hope that all institutions travel until the end, at the service of European citizens, for an increasingly strong and increasingly transparent Europe.I am glad to be here with President Prodi and my colleague Michele Schreyer to present the White Paper "Reform of the Commission" approved by the commission this morning.As your lordships will see in the document, which will be available to you today, the unprecedented consultation to the commission staff, this Parliament and the Council, which has been made since the approval of the document on the consultation in January has been very productive and, as a result of it, useful improvements have been achieved.Together with Romano Prodi, I express my gratitude to this assembly and the large number of people who have dedicated time and efforts to give us their constructive responses.The White Paper places the reform in its appropriate political framework.In the Commission, systems and structures have been created for forty years in which there have been extensions achieved.The treaties have been reviewed, this Parliament and the Council have attributed new management tasks to the Commission and in our union, in our continent and in the world there have been many other changes of great importance.These realities, together with the approach of new extensions, strongly advise the modernization of the commission so that this essential institution can perform its primary tasks of conception and formulation of policies, application of the treaties and management of public resources and do so with the maximum efficiency, responsibility and democratic account of accounts.Naturally, the permanent independence and strength of the commission are fundamental for that mission, as this assembly has repeatedly recognized.Reform and renewal are also essential for that purpose.The commission is not and will be a secretariat of any kind and that is clear for all institutions ... That is something that is perfectly understood everywhere.But the Commission exists to be at the service of the Union and its peoples with high levels of performance.That is what citizens have the right to expect and what the people who work for the commission want to offer and offer.As the Assembly must know, the Commission cannot achieve those objectives alone.All European Union institutions will have to face the issues raised by the reform and do so with honesty and responsibility.I know that my colleagues and I can count on the support of many deputies to this assembly of all trends.

And, above all, and with that I conclude, Mrs. President, Ladies, we have to be able to express this in flat language, clearly, changing in some ways the jargon that we handle, because we cannot ask Europeans, who are living times of profound changes, that they adhere and get excited about us if we continue to maintain an absolutely closed and back language to them.This is the fundamental means of increasing and reinforcing the confidence that, in any case, I hope it can be measured in the next European elections.Mr. President of the Commission, allow me to tell you, on behalf of my group, that we firmly support the starting point, the core of the analysis and the strategy that today presents to the Assembly;namely that the bet is now undeniably political.And it is political, because we are moving forward.Although we have not yet finished building all the basic pieces, we are advancing from that type of functional construction of Europe to a political perspective that is a greater challenge.The challenge of expansion is political.The challenge of the creation of a space for justice and internal issues, to address the issue of asylum and immigration and crime is very political.The challenge of a common external defense and security policy is very political.And because it is political, it is more complex.Because it is political is more susceptible to sovereignty.Because it is more susceptible to sovereignty, it is more susceptible to voters and citizens.Therefore, we must find a way to advance until we reach those goals and political objectives, to overcome not only skepticism, but also the greatest enemy of all, which is the apathy to which it has referred.The means to achieve this are not easy, but they are real.I applaud your opinion that we need more synergy between our institutions, not only between the commission and the Parliament, but also between these two and the Council to highlight the scope of the political challenge.We need more dialogue, not only among us, but also with civil society.More explanations are needed to know what Europe is about.We must overcome fears and anxieties, because in many cases, the greatest fears is fear.Perhaps with more dialogue and explanations we can overcome some of these fears.My group feels especially attracted to the creative possibilities that you have pointed out regarding the perspective of presenting a white paper in next spring, which addresses the issue of the Government.When we contemplate the Europe of the networks that you describe, it is very important that Europe focuses on its main themes, that we have the value of focusing the areas in which Europe could be behind.In this way, the population could be convinced that Europe, in its governorate, is not something that is directed exclusively from Brussels, in an attempt to concentrate and absorb more competencies, more decisions and more authority.Here is the political core of the challenge, and I think you have exposed it today to this assembly perfectly.For my group, the extension is the first priority with which all other possible reforms must be measured, whether the Government, whether the intergovernmental conference or the reform of the institutions.

after the white book, there is certainly plenty of time until a guideline appears.This makes it clear that the procedure is very slow and to explain why so much time is needed, a report is required in my opinion.Second: If a legislative proposal is announced in the legislative program, but its implementation is not carried out in the current year, the reasons for this must be presented.In addition an example.Today, a proposal for a guideline on electrical and electronic scrap is announced.This proposal has already been mentioned several times, but it has never been adopted.We know that this was based on the pressure of the US government that threatens with a lawsuit in front of the WTO, but it would make sense, fair, fair, democratic and transparent if the commission explained what is happening behind the scenes and why the submission of this guideline is long.Allow me to express my fears and fears with regard to the approach of your program for the year of 2000 you described as a year of the turn - and not just because it does not contain any really innovative suggestions.What worries us is rather the programmatic, semi -ideological approach of this work plan, its submissive and the second principle is equal opportunities, especially between women and men, as well as the European employment strategy and the economic and currency union.Ms. rapporteur, ladies and men, I would like to say about the concerns expressed in the pronunciation that the guidelines indicate the importance and determination of integrated development or conversion strategies, so that the priorities mentioned enable the greatest possible synergy effects of the measures and effective decentralized partnerships.They are worried because this partnership apparently has not been discussed.However, it is clearly mentioned on page 5 of these guidelines, and I would like to refer to it - because they have asked me - that this partnership for me - and I have looked after a region for long enough to be able to assess - is a very effective instrument for mobilizing intellectual resources at local level - both those in the public sector - the city and municipalities, the school and social areas, the associations and associations - as well asthose of the private sector.And the territorial pacts are one of the forms of this decentralized partnership to respond to a remark from Ms. Angelilli.The guidelines are ordered according to topic -related priorities so that they can be taken into account to different degrees within the framework of the individual goals depending on the specific situation of each Member State or its regions.Well, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to briefly respond to some of your comments;First to the procedure.It is true that your house was only dealt with late.However, I would like to remind you that after the guidelines in the form of a draft in February 1999 according to a new procedure in which the submission of statements on the text had been passed, you were immediately forwarded to Parliament by my predecessor, Ms. Monika Wulf-Mathies.However, due to the upcoming European elections at the time, their house was only able to begin examining the guidelines after the text was finally adopted in July 1999.Today I can assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that we are only at the beginning during the negotiations on the programs - the committee chairman Mr. Hatzidakis has already asked me about this - and that your comments from most Member States can therefore actually be taken into account.I can also tell you that the Commission will take into account the opinion of your house, which is expressed in this report, when passing the guidelines for the prescribed so -called half -time valuation.Now on the content of the guidelines.Ms. rapporteur, you underlined that this is about making specifications for a number of often very precisely defined European goals.I cannot now call everyone: Introduction of cross -sector measures, more efficient use of public funds, support of the different partners in the joint development of regional or national programs, etc. The Commission takes note of this, but these specifications or questions do not belong here, for example, but, for example, in the Vademecum or the methodological document.

We therefore propose to change the legislation as follows.Firstly, it should only be reserved for public structures what is built thanks to Life Fondi, also at the cost of entrusting, with a tender, the management of the sites in question to associations recognized for the protection of nature.The continuity of the projects started, since private law associations can disappear or resell.It is aberrant from a philosophical point of view, as well as contestable from a legal point of view, that 100 percent of public money serves to build a private land assets, even if with the claim to protect the environment.Secondly, the selection and attribution criteria of the Life funds should be defined, in order to avoid any suspicion of clientelism or ostracism.Thirdly, a preventive consultation of users and interested bodies should be requested.For example, in France, the Life-Nature project for Grand -lu, developed without any concertation, has proved to be a real ecological catastrophe: the operations intended to free the watercourse at the valley from the melma, Acheneau, and conducted in violation of the French law on the waters, have caused its interraction, destroying braking, invading wetlands and causing other consequences.In reality, all that was achieved was a 3 -kilometer movement of the melma with a cost of 6 million francs: a remedy that proved worse than evil, a predictable consequence and announced by all the operators of the site.Result?A cause and a cost of restoration higher than the sum allocated by the program.This is what we want to avoid.Fourth, in the committee in charge of the follow-up representatives of Parliament and, at least, a deputy for each political group should be included in the committee in charge of the follow-up.Deputies must control the use of funds for which they voted: it seems more than legitimate.In fifth place, a scientific, technical and financial report of the Life operations carried out should be published annually.In sixth place, a serious and regular evaluation of the programs should be carried out.In seventh place, the use of these funds should be allowed in cases of environmental emergency, for example, reforestation after a storm, restoring natural spaces after a black tide, etc.Here, Mr. President, honorable speaker, the concrete, sensible proposal, simple to implement, aimed at limiting conflicts at the local level and justifying the correct use of public funds, which we advance before any increase?of 40 percent at least!?of the funds allocated for Life.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, I would like to congratulate the Honorable Lienemann in the first place for the elaborate relationship, but also with the commission because this relationship, this position, improves the texts currently in force.In addition, it has a more acceptable, clearer and transparent structure.I would also like to congratulate the commission services, as the evaluation, control and sequel to the Life program reasonably guarantee the selection and execution of the projects.However, I would like to dwell on some aspects.First of all, on its continuity in which, in principle, I believe.

From community institutions, we are obliged to work to overcome these border scars, which involve a contradiction with the spirit of European unity.The economic and social cohesion that we advocate is concretized, through the Interreg initiative, in territorial cohesion and in the integration of border spaces and the peripheries of our continent.Interreg is since its origin in the germ of an authentic community policy of territory management and a truly polycentric conception of the European territory.The European Parliament, according to this initiative, only regrets that we have to approve a resolution on it when we still do not know the evaluation of Interreg II, but we are aware that it is not convenient to delay the application of this third edition, since we would endanger the success of several projects and the continuity of projects that are already underway, because the success of Interreg is evident and this is expressed by local, regional and national authorities that have participated in projectsco -financed.Learn together, innovate, share projects and share good practices, understand and tolerate each other, are some of the lessons that allows you to learn from this initiative to those who participate in it.There are a whole series of interesting issues around it, the observatory, the principle of concentration ... I would like to stop in the management bodies.It is necessary to seek common, interregional and transnational management bodies, in which all local and regional authorities actively participate, as well as economic and social agents.No cases of parallel projects should be repeated on either side of the border.We need to create a cross -border culture, and for this it is necessary to innovate in administrative cooperation, overcoming with imagination the existing barriers, overcoming the difficulties of the different degrees of competencies of each Member State, of each region and of each municipality.It cannot be that a project cannot be carried out due to interlocution difficulties.During commission debates, we have also found the difficulty of coordinating Interreg with other annual or biannual financial instruments, such as Meda, Tacis or Phare.The proposal for resolving this Parliament has been very attentive to these difficulties, formulating the commission proposals capable of solving them and putting reasonable deadlines to make the necessary modifications.Mr. President, I want to intervene in this debate because the Urban initiative has been very successful, especially in Ireland, and satisfies me that the European Union continues to contribute in that area.It is very sad that hundreds of communities, if not thousands, suffer poverty and disadvantages so deep.Even in the richest member states and cities there are a large number of people who live in ghettos, in situations in which there are inappropriate facilities, where education is quite bad, where physical infrastructure are underdeveloped and where drugs and other problems are widespread.It seems to me that, for the European Union to demonstrate that it really helps the citizens of the EC, it must collaborate with the Member States to make it clear that the EU works for citizens and their families.

It is very useful.It is an excellent contribution from Mr. Swoboda and his colleagues.We are very grateful to him to have been in the foreground in this area, as well as some of his colleagues, some of whom are present this evening within the Assembly - Ms. Pack, Mr. Lagendijk and others.I am very satisfied with what our general relations with ARYM are as good.Perhaps Mr. Dupuis, as well as his interpreter, will forgive me to use this expression in the spirit of the cordial agreement.The excellent representative of the European Union in this country has contributed to it.He was a great friend of the European Parliament and an excellent servant of the Commission.The best example illustrating the quality of our relationships is the imminent start of negotiations on the stabilization and association agreement.As is also the cooperation of ARYM with regard to the reconstruction of Kosovo.I thank the Macedonian authorities for helping their help in recent weeks, in order to cope with the considerable difficulties in electricity supply to Kosovo.Like certain deputies, I recognize the stabilizing role that this country played during the tragedy which took place in the Balkans, in particular with regard to the integration of the Albanian minority in the political and social life of the country.A few weeks ago, I saw the new president Georgievski, recently elected, and I was extremely impressed, like others, by his commitment to multi -thnicity and pluralism.Let me present to you the state of these negotiations than other countries in the region - as Mr. Lagendijk said - observe with immense interest.The Council adopted, on January 24 of this year, its negotiation directives for a stabilization and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.This represents the most important step in the process of stabilization and association of the western part of the Balkans initiated by the Commission in May 1999. Allow me to clarify the main elements of these directive projects.They cover inclusion in the arrangement agreement establishing a political dialogue with ARYM.They cover provisions with a view to improving regional cooperation, including the prospect of establishing free trade areas between the countries of the region, although I would clearly say that there is no question of an attempt to recreate the state of Yugoslavia.They cover the prospect of the establishment of a free trade area between the European Union and these countries during the ten years which will follow the entry into force of the agreement.They cover provisions concerning the circulation of workers, freedom of establishment, the provision of services, current payments and capital movements.They cover an ARYM commitment to bring its legislation closer to that of the European Community, especially in key fields on the domestic market;And they cover provisions concerning cooperation with ARYM in a wide range of fields, including justice and domestic affairs.We now carry out the necessary preparations in the Commission so that negotiations can start in March.I have to go to Arym in the second week of March.

After two elections of the European Parliament and an important new reform of the Union Treaties, our relations with the Czech Republic developed in an extremely dynamic way.A association agreement is in force and a mixed parliamentary commission has been established with delegates of the European Parliament and the Czech one.In 1996 his country submitted the official application to enter the Union.Finally, in 1998 the adhesion negotiations were officially started.The European integration and expansion process have undergone an impressive acceleration after the fall of the iron curtain.The end of Europe's artificial separation marks the beginning of a new era.A historical challenge awaits us that presents various perspectives for all Europeans.Mr. President, she who was also founder and signatory of paper 77 - the defense movement of human rights that represented and claimed the fundamental values ​​in a dark period of the history of its people - represents an incisive symbol of these evolutions.For defending the freedom and dignity of the person she was sentenced to almost five years in prison by a communist regime.But he never lost hope and history has given her right.Ten years have passed since the "velvet revolution" claimed Havel Na Hrad.For ten years she represented, as president, first the Democratic Czechoslovakia and then the Czech Republic.Reconciliation with her neighbors has always constituted an essential objective for her, defended with firmness and perseverance.We consider it a first -rate European.Today the Czech Republic is preparing to become a member of our union.Experience has taught us, and you Mr. President will converge that the process of expanding the Union is not always without pitfalls, for both sides.The Czech Republic will therefore have to undergo significant efforts to satisfy all membership conditions.The European Union, for its part, will have to adapt its institutions and its policy in view of the expansion.It has already taken a large step forward in the agenda 2000. The next stage, which consists of the institutional reform, will start this year on the occasion of the new intergovernmental conference, of which the European Parliament is an active part.Our responsibility as deputies consists in guaranteeing maximum opening and transparency so that, at the right time, the citizens of the European Union and those of the Czech Republic approves, through their representatives, the adhesion of the Czech Republic to the European Union.Mr. President, I leave her word with immense pleasure.(Applause) Mr. President, on behalf of the European Parliament, I want to thank you highly for the strong message that he addressed us and, moreover, the applause of the colleagues testify to what we appreciated his words.I would like to thank you for reminding us that the different nationalities are perfectly compatible with European belonging.Starting from his personal experience, he illustrated that European belonging cannot be imposed, as it constitutes a spontaneous and natural path.His words struck me: they express what we all feel deeply.

of the new millennium, I hope you agree that this parliament will be appropriate for this day by firmly committing to tackling the issue of cardiovascular disease, which are the main cause of mortality in Europe.I am urging the member states to align themselves with the commitment made today during the Winning Hearts Conference, namely that any child born in the new millennium has the The values ​​must pass before power.We therefore deplore what is happening in Austria.Even more, we are shaken.We are deeply disappointed.We ask the ÖVP to further examine other solutions.We continue to insist on article 6 of the treaty.We continue to fight the trivialization of the far right.If the coalition still came to train, we call on our ÖVP colleagues to guarantee themselves in their programs, as well as in their words and in their gestures, of respect for the principles and values ​​which constitute the foundations of European integration.Madam President, my dear colleagues, Austria must face a heavy responsibility.Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is obvious that within this Parliament, we are very widely agreed in our rejection of Haider and its policy, but it is just as clear that the opinions diverge as to the question of how to best fight this policy.Have you only asked yourself about the repercussions in Austria of this debate and the declaration made last weekend by the presidency of the council?Did you ask yourself the question of knowing our share of responsibility in the future development of the political situation in Austria if we decide to make a judgment on this file?You only asked yourself what would happen if the view of one of our colleagues was granted and that elections took place in Austria in the coming days.In the unanimous opinion of the observers, Haider would come out even stronger.Who may want such a thing?Do we not have the responsibility of carefully thinking about how to fight such a policy?Europe is a community of law.Among the principles that we must defend, there is democracy, respect for human law and the rule of law.The democratic requirement implies that we can deplore electoral results but that we must respect them and that is why we must respect the decision taken by the Austrians for reasons inherent in their policy.The rule of law requires that the presidency of the council will not be expressed as it did, in a way that contradicts the treaties.Politic intelligence commands not to isolate the ÖVP but to support it, as an undoubtedly democratic party, respectful of the rule of law and having demonstrated its European commitment, so that Austria remains in a just as undoubtedly undoubtedly a member of this European community.This is why we must support our ÖVP colleagues in this difficult situation and isolation is a completely wrong path.(Applause) Madam President, we say where I come from that a Welshman always takes it three times.It is actually three times - as you will notice during this debate - that I mean my desire to respond very briefly to what was an excellent, and sometimes disturbing, debate.First of all, I would like to thank, on behalf of the President Prodi and my colleagues from the Commission, several deputies of this assembly for their support and their understanding vis-à-vis the position taken by the Commission in the declaration that we made yesterday.

Likewise, I support a movement towards a linear career system, since the current system of career groups no longer meets the needs of our institutions.It certainly blocks the progress and mobility of people with demonstrably high performance potential.Those MEPs who have duly praised the commission staff in the course of this debate, whose vast majority are normally characterized by hard work, high integrity and performance, are absolutely right with their statements.The white book on the reform strategy will contain a detailed presentation of our concepts on this and other topics;Accuracy in detail is of course the top priority here.There will therefore be some messages for this in the coming months, and each individual will be advised and discussed here in this plenary.In the meantime, there is absolute clarity that we have to work closely with the parliament as an institution in central questions of common interest, in particular on the service and care payments as well as the civil servant statute.In connection with this last point, we are considering whether it would be useful to assume a framework regulation that contains general provisions on important questions such as salary, employment conditions, personnel representative rights, etc., but authorizes the individual institutions to introduce implementation provisions on other facts.Initial thoughts from the plenum about this consultative concept would be particularly welcome.In conclusion, I would like to go into paragraph 15 of the draft deflection in which the middle requirements of our reform strategies are addressed.This is a very important point.We are certain that we will have a significant "reform dividend" as soon as the modernization measures have been reflected in increased efficiency and better management of the use of funds.However, there is absolute clarity that parts of the commission service are already fully utilized.This has already been addressed by Parliament several times.Second, it is also clear that due to the reform, some new investments for qualification measures and technology are required.Third, there is completely no doubt that the preparations for the expansion must be intensified.Already now they have an impact on the availability of funds.It is also clear that with the assumption of new tasks - which is certainly brought to us by the council and parliament - we will have to name and sort so -called "negative priorities" in order to create additional capacities.Central feature of our reform will therefore be more determined in order to combine the determination of priorities with the funds on the basis of the measures -related budgeting.However, I would like to emphasize that the internal discipline is introduced by the Commission when setting the priority, but it can only be effective if the parliament and the council also take into account it and show a similarly determined attitude in relation to the claims of the Commission.For this reason, the Commission welcomes paragraph 15 of the report van Hulten.Mr President, I would like to come to the end and thank the Hohen house for his attention during an inevitable speech.At the same time, I would like to thank the rapporteur, the committee for household control and the other committees who have submitted their statements.We look forward to close cooperation with the plenary in the final formulation of the reform strategy package and, which is much more important, to constantly good cooperation in all the years that are necessary for the solution of such difficult tasks.

It is simply recognizing their inferiority.But that I know, we never felt lower than men, and all the more in politics.So I believe that we all lead this fight to help our compatriots to access decision-making power, to access positions of responsibility in the political environment, but I believe that this will only be done with a real revolution of mentalities.We must be strong enough together to force our political leaders to impose the participation of women in political decision-making powers..(SV) Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, "half of the sky is supported by women," said an enlightened man one day.But when it comes to important decisions and priority subjects, women are lacking.Women, which constitute more than half of the population, are largely underrepresented in the fields of politics, economics and social action.It is an unacceptable fact in a democracy.Regarding equality between men and women, the gap between law and facts is nowhere more marked than in decision -making bodies.So that we can reach a balance, a concrete action plan with a fixed calendar is necessary.An important part of this plan would consist in a benchmarking system that can ensure the full participation of women in power structures and decision -making processes.I therefore be delighted that the commissioner is favorable to such a system.I propose that the European objectives concerning the participation of women in decision -making processes are based on the average obtained in the three most advanced member states in this area, with an annual report provided by all the Member States.These reports would then be the subject of an evaluation.Women are the first victims of human rights violations - in particular with rapes and sexual abuses, the ill -treatment suffered in the domestic framework and the trade of women - but they are underrepresented in the judicial and legislative institutions responsible for judging these criminal acts.As a result, these are not considered priority, and that very often, their authors are not the subject of prosecution.Women are also the most numerous victims of armed conflicts, but nevertheless remain absent from actions in favor of preserving peace, conflict resolution and reconstruction work.This is why we urge the Member States, in the text of the resolution, to increase the number of women who take part in all these activities in the service of peace.Equality between female and male participation in decision -making processes is not solely of social justice and democracy;It is also a necessity, to be able to fully exploit the experiences lived by women and their knowledge.The fact of not calling on the capacities of women in the decision -making process represents an unacceptable waste.Women must not only "support half of the sky", but also have the right to take their share of responsibility in decisions concerning the whole earth.Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the presidency of the council and the commissioner for their excellent interventions.We expect a lot from your action.We start a millennium and a century which we hope will be decisive for women and for their possibility of occupying places of decision.

If in a general direction it is considered that this is a pertinent and effective way to increase financial control, the ex -sudden system can be used.Naturally, there are different requirements throughout the commission according to the number and nature of the financial transactions that the general directorates must carry out.In the White Paper, that is also taken into account, but in cases where there is desire and the demonstrated need to use that system, it can be done without a doubt.Finally, with respect to the transition, I share the reserves of Mrs. Theato on the so -called "flexible standards."That is something that we have already discussed and their honor knows that I make a distinction between the various forms of codes that can have a positive effect and at the time they can become - we could say, I suppose - "imperative norms."But in that regard I see any possibility of flexible norms, which is why in the transition period there will be a total compliance with the current financial regulation until the legislation is modified through a duly democratic process in this assembly and in the Board.In the White Paper include absolute guarantees and provisions in this regard.Now, in addition -and it is something very important, because it is a period of transition -there will be training, advice, support, guarantees: the new head of the audit unit will occupy his position on May 1 and with that and with a cluster of other guarantees I think we can be safe, to the extent of the humanly possible, that there will be a totally safe system even during the transition period.I must formulate two other observations, because it is an essential issue for reform.The first is that there are those who have the sensation - for reasons that I understand perfectly - that in that transition there is a danger of irresponsibility or inertia.Irresponsibility, because there is a sensation in some means that there will be not enough control and discipline.I completely reject it and for this I simply rely on the criteria of the commission officials, the responsibility of the general directors and the guarantees that we have introduced into the system.Inertia would be exclusively consequence of anxiety and we are doing everything we can in terms of support and training to reduce the possibility of it.Finally, the system we currently have - as the Committee of Independent Experts said very firmly - is already unsustainable.In fact, the Court of Accounts has considered it a fiction.In any case, there will have to be a change, which would entail a transition period, because there is no possibility of inventing any system that could allow us to move from one system to another from one Friday to the following Monday.To the extent that it is possible with all the information we have and all the capacity for conception we have, I am sure we have installed - or we will install - from our proposals a system that will provide the Union, its taxpayers and this assembly a complete security.

Greater control at national level, by national governments on national banks, but also greater international control through, for example, the International Monetary Fund.I therefore believe that the causes of the problem can be tackled at the best if, from a song, in the countries concerned, good government practices will be kept due to respect and, by the other song, if greater control at national and international level will be guaranteed to avoid these uncontrolled phenomena.Mrs. President, several members of Parliament have said that larger funds should be allocated for large projects.Honorable Kreissl-Dörfler, for example, spoke, in English, of "Long Term Financing for Long Terg Term Projects".It is an absolutely obvious request.My response to this request is that first of all the countries should maintain their promise to allocate 0.7 percent of their gross national product in favor of help and development cooperation, so that, compared to today, a much greater volume of funding can be used for long -term projects according to the methods specifically provided for for this purpose, that is, through contributions to development cooperation, and not through the Tabin tax, which would be a form of artificial financing,And probably harmful.Lady president, I wish to conclude my intervention here.As for the resolution, of which I saw a proposal, the Commission awaits that it knows the result of Parliament's vote to define its position.Thank you for offering me the opportunity to participate in tonight's discussion.I communicate that I have received four resolution proposals pursuant to article 40, paragraph 5, of the regulation.Lady president, unfortunately I do not have his mastery of French.However, I would rejoice if the commissioner Bolkestein listened for a moment, which I don't think possible since he is talking to the honorable Randzio-Plath.Could you remind him that I still have something to say?Monsieur Bolkestein, je veux vous say that chose!Unfortunately I don't speak Dutch as well as her.However, I would like to express some consideration for his address.The fact that we are in favor of the Tobin Tax does not represent an initiative of Parliament against the Commission.We want to evaluate the possibilities of introducing this tax as one of the many possible tools and in this we hope it will be on our side.From a political point of view I always have some doubts when it is stated that an initiative is not necessary, we do not want it, we cannot apply it.Adopting a decision about it is not his task, but ours.This demonstrates to a certain extent the new awareness that has awakened at the level of Parliament.I would like to discuss it with her, nothing more, nothing less.However, we can leave any other path immediately;I consider it a serious commissioner who intends to carry out his work with commitment and as such respects it.Please in turn respect us deputies who intend to face our tasks with the same seriousness, including the Tobin Tax!Lady president, it seems that there is a forgetfulness and that, in the list of the resolved resolutions, that she has just mentioned, does not appear the proposal to resolve the common compromise presented by the PSE, the liberals, the Gue group, the green and the honorable Kuntz and Coûteaux.

This coordination does not exist at the moment, and the commission has not yet submitted concrete proposals to improve coordination.Here, in Parliament, we are waiting for the Commission to give our parliamentary commission as soon as possible a more detailed report on this matter.It is of decisive importance to ensure that companies, organizations and other local agents participate in the practical execution of the programs.Experience shows that cooperation projects must be better planned, that the monitoring of them must be more precise and that they need to behave greater performance.Many projects have been halfway and have lost efficacy in the network of administration and bureaucracy.The parties must also be required to commit to the projects and that fulfill their obligations.Our group returns to several amendments that were rejected by the parliamentary commission during preparations.I want to submit the report on Urban to consideration, in whose argument the rapporteur has addressed in a plausible way the guidelines of the commission regarding the establishment of a minimum sum of 500 euros per inhabitant.This does not proceed to carry it out as a mechanical objective, but must be adapted to the specific conditions of the destination region.This point of view is so important that it must be included in the conclusions, and not stay in mere argument.Mr. President, dear colleagues, Interreg is one of the structural funds.In it, not only projects will be financed in a region, in a country, but in neighboring regions, in two or more countries.Unfortunately, this is true only for a part of the resources, that is, only for the interior borders of the EU.However, precisely the regions located next to the borders with third countries need an instrument that works for cross -border cooperation.The regulation induces, as if this were also so.However, it is not so.It happens that the commission has not modified the regulation for years, although Parliament has been demanding it for a long time.Looking ahead this means for these regions that will be produced again in degradation in the form of transnochado promotion of marginal areas.Since 1996, Parliament asks for cooperation with third states to constitute a fund to eliminate difficulties.Nothing has happened.Difficulties are still dragging to the detriment of the affected regions.Parliament again demands here an improvement and cross -border cooperation, and we hope that a common fund is constituted and that the regulation will be modified once again in collaboration with the other commissioners.We want a Europe for citizens and not a Europe of bureaucrats.Mr. President, a third of the European Union money is spent on funds for all kinds of development objectives.It seems great to my group if this is able to overcome the differences with regions, cities and population groups more disadvantaged or if health conditions and the vital environment are improved.It is a matter of solidarity and progress.But the distribution of more and more money is no guarantee that it is spent better and better.

It would have been better if we had tried to reach a compromise by formulating a common position.I am of the opinion that, in this way, the European Parliament is excluded from the debate precisely when a particularly interesting development is underway in the European Union which sees the much clearer processing of a large socio -economic program.The Portuguese presidency presented a large programmatic document in view of the extraordinary summit of Lisbon.The Commission has adopted the same approach within the framework of its five -year program, also mentioning one of the four priorities.Also the document that the Commission has produced for the Lisbon summit refers to a wide setting that embraces numerous areas.I am convinced that this is the right path: the development within the European Union of a large socio -economic approach, also because it is starting from this economic entity that politics arises.I believe that, in this regard, the European Parliament will be able to play a limited role both in Lisbon and in the context of the meeting in which we are invited to participate in June.But what positions will we have to take in those locations?Will we just have to recognize that we are still nailed to the old existing political oppositions?Mr. President, honorable deputies, I would like to thank the Assembly for the seriousness and acrybia with which he worked in the first place.The auditions of experts and the debates in the Commission provided us with additional information of considerable quality.Furthermore, during the debate this afternoon, important differences were identified as regards possible policies.However, I believe that I can see some elements of consent.We are all agreed on the fact that the current economic situation is positive and that one must try to progress and exploit the opportunity of the moment in order to improve circumstances and achieve a marked improvement in the field of employment.I would like to focus only briefly on these issues and instead deepen the last point that seems to me a priority in today's debate.Yesterday, as some of you observed, the commission for economic problems illustrated the improvement of the situation of the economy in Europe.We can believe that this positive trend, already highlighted in the perspectives in November, can even prove better than the initially expected.The growth of employment continues at a good rhythm.It is true that inflation, despite yesterday's figures, must be controlled - we have reached about 2 percent according to the latest December data -, but it is equally true that the subject inflation highlights that inflationary tensions are due to very precise elements, such as the rise in the price of oil and, of course, the trend of the exchange rate.At the time of the presentation of the report, we have already referred to any risks of growth.We have highlighted the possibility of finding difficulties in American growth and therefore in other areas of the world, as well as the possibility of a certain recovery of inflation.This recovery of inflation can be significant especially if it ends up generating an inflation of costs.For this reason, we reiterate the need for a wage policy compatible with the inflation definitions that we intend to establish.

Let me be allowed to thank Mr. Andersson for the rest he gives to his main question and to answer them as follows.First, Finland and Denmark have exceptions to the principle of free movement of goods until 2003. These countries are busy taking preparatory measures in order to be ready for the free access of alcoholic products by 2003. In the case of Sweden, the situation is somewhat different.In 1995, it was decided to set up a five -year derogatory period, a period which is now expiring.I have yet heard any argument on the basis of which the Commission should consider an extension of this period.Second, we have a permanent consultation process with the Swedish government.I can point out to Mr. Andersson that I will go to Stockholm on March 6 to chat with the Minister Ringholm, with members of the Swedish Parliament and, on request, with the Prime Minister or other ministers, with a view to continuing the debate on this file which - I understand it perfectly - is the subject of lively political passions in Sweden.Third, I naturally understand the importance of the health aspect of this dossier very well.I repeat once again that Professor Lindgren of the University of Lund said that regardless of the evolution of events in importing restrictions, alcohol consumption in Sweden will remain unchanged.The question is then of course to know where the amount of alcohol is not introduced by travelers arriving in the country comes from.The answer is that it is made in fraud or that alcohol is produced by the Swedes themselves and, as Mr. Andersson knows, it is a particularly dangerous and harmful process.That said, Mr. Andersson seems to think that the health situation is improving as soon as the import of alcohol is limited.In this case, however, not only Sweden but all countries of the European Union should start from the principle of the prohibition of any alcohol sale.We were able to observe a similar example in the United States.Mr. Andersson is certainly aware of what has been named prohibition.He also knows what resulted in the Maffia activities in the United States, where we ended up putting an end to prohibition.This simply means that you should of course protect health but not by prohibiting alcohol, as it is useless.Mr. President, it is all the same, in reality, Swedish monopoly revenues on alcohol and, if the Swedish government says that it must thus cover the costs in the health sector, this proves that it is a distortion of competition, since other countries must finance their costs in the sector themselves without having a monopoly on alcohol.What I would like to know is if you also know studies according to which moderate consumption of quality alcohol, for example Franconia wine or Bavarian beer, is good for health and would therefore reduce the Swedish budget.I understand that Mr. Posselt began to raise the tax aspects of this file.I also believe that I know that the high taxation of alcoholic products in Sweden dates back to the year 1638 and that, since that time, the State has perceived a significant part of its tax revenues from the sale of alcoholic products.

But my criticism, indeed, to say it openly, my anger is addressed exclusively against those who have caused and still cause similar reactions, the Schüssel and Haider lords and their parties ... ... as well as against their representatives in the European Parliament.Honorable Poettering, I find it interesting that she is in a difficult situation today as much as the one in which I find myself, This would force all the main industries of the European Union countries to pay billions of pounds or euros, and this cost would affect the price and therefore on the buyers of new cars.Since the European motor vehicles manufacturers began to produce many tens of years earlier than Japanese manufacturers, Koreans, etc., they would be burdened by a greater weight, to the advantage of their competitors in other countries.I congratulate the Honorable Florenz, the honorable Lange and the other deputies who have tried to overcome the fracture within the party and to reach a compromise based on the division of costs, and I ask you to support the amendment presented in my name and of the colleagues of Germany, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Sweden and Great Britain aimed at removing the retroactive aspect of the provision.Retroactive laws are bad laws, unjust laws and often even unasslatable.The majority of the democratic parliaments of the free world rejects them in principle, unless they are of enormous public interest, which cannot be said in this case.That's why I asked for a nominal appeal vote.We want to see who is willing to vote in favor of a retroactive law, of dubious legality, which would constitute a heavy economic burden for all future car buyers and would have a devastating effect on the European car industry.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to remember once again briefly the economic stake of this directive and renew my support for the amendments presented by my colleague, honorable Bernd Lange.In fact, these amendments present the advantage - and I would like to insist on this point - to reconcile environmental requirements and economic imperatives.The Council, in the common position, said that the car manufacturers had to bear, totally or in a consistent percentage, the costs of retreat and recycling.But as was correctly said by the honorable Lange, this solution is absolutely unjust for European manufacturers.Coming from a country in which there are actually car manufacturers, and I can assure you that it is not possible to impose, retroactively, the total intake of the costs of all the vehicles of their brand currently in circulation, that is, in fact of taking costs imposed by the 80 percent of the European car park.This solution is unacceptable because these manufacturers have not been able to integrate the environmental requirements that we impose on them in their production processes and cost prices.The common position puts European manufacturers in an unfavorable position compared to the manufacturers who recently appeared on the European market.Of course we are not here to defend this or that national interest, this or the industrial lobby, but to build a competitive Europe on the world market and defend jobs in the economic sectors in which we are actually competitive.For this reason, honorable colleagues, I ask you to support the amendments presented by the honorable Bernd Lange, which will be supported by the European Socialism Party group since in fact all the interests involved - economic interests and environmental requirements - while leaving the Member States for the methods of applying these requirements;In fact, the amendments in question provide that the systems in force in the Member States, and there are that they work very well, they can continue to work.

after the age of the ships or after the risk history of the flags.Unfortunately, the 25 % are sometimes covered by flags, of which you know that they will meet all the requirements: the inspections go faster and the work is easier to do.Therefore, it will be less about making changes than taking measures to control what is already done, apart from some complementary claims in relation to revisions, especially depending on the age of the different ships.In addition, there are Solas (international convention to protect human life at sea) and marble (international convention to prevent marine pollution by ships), two Convention of the International Sea Consumption Organization, which must be made mandatory in all countries of the Union and their application must be checked.With regard to the question of the inspectors of the Union, I believe that the principle of subsidiarity justifies that these inspections are carried out by the Member States, which should not mean that the Commission does not have to control whether the states correctly perform their task correctly.

coasters who monitor the coasts of the United States.In the first place, I would like to thank the colleagues of my group that deal with the environment and who have addressed this problem together with the transport team.This disaster is as environmental as transportation and is not limited to a sector.Once again we are in this Parliament debating on another maritime disaster.I could recite the list of disasters that have affected that industry in the 10 years that I have been in this Parliament, but I only have three minutes.There is no doubt that it is time for not only member states, but also that tiger tooth called International Maritime Organization and the oil companies and the owners of the ships - to those who fit no less responsibilities - assume their responsibilities adopting measures to end those ecological and human tragedies that are repeated year after year.How many Erika more will we have to endure before those who have the power give us a control of the status of the contamination than any disaster of the type of Erika?While I recognize that some advances have been achieved in sectors such as control by the state of the port and norms on minimal crew, we continue to face what our deceased colleague Ken Stewart called "ships of shame that enter our waters of the European Union and leave them: rusty cubos and with poor crew."It is necessary for Member States to act quickly and decisively.It is necessary that our governments contribute the financial resources necessary to provide us with effective control and also stop giving the matter of maritime security long.Erika has not gained human lives, but it may have ruined the livelihoods of many people.Just like it is business, just like the braer.There is no doubt that the three left us an ecological disaster.My group expresses its condolence to the population of Brittany that has seen its area looted by that disaster, as it was also expressed on previous occasions to the population of Western Wales and that of the Shetland Islands.Isn't it time for us to stop expressing condolences and start communicating requirements to get rid of those ships of shame for the safety of the seas?Otherwise,
