Expressing our solidarity, as a European Parliament, first means acting to obtain immediate unlocking of emergency aid to families affected by black tide and, at the same time, demand a qualitative, European and international scale strengthening, of the rules and safety standards of maritime transport to establish much more frequent controls and clearly more dissuasive penalties for the offenders.Our proposals refer in particular to the age of the oil tankers.Among those who were controlled and considered offenders last year, 15 were twenty years or more, some more than thirty and even more.That is no longer tolerable.In addition, convenience pavilions.According to the International Federation of Transport Workers, more than 40 percent of ships shipwrecked in 1998 carried a convenience pavilion, a symbol of the benefit and exploitation of men to the detriment of security.That is no longer tolerable.Finally, the lack of transparency.Everything possible to make the most opaque as possible the concatenation of the responsibilities and identity of the owners and those who really decide.That is no longer tolerable.In all these planes, we must obtain real and significant changes, including the fixation of a limit date for the observance of new norms, including double helmet, under penalty of prohibition of anchoring in the ports of the Member States or crossing its territorial waters.We must also achieve greater rigor both in the issuance of navigability certificates and in the verification of age and the maintenance of ships.Finally, we must ensure that all those responsible for a catastrophe contribute to repairs.In the present case I think, in particular, in the total-flin group.The European Union can, Mr. President, to do the same management before the International Maritime Organization.This will demonstrate its usefulness before a public opinion that this time awaits clear and concrete acts.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, as a representative of the French Atlantic coast, representative of Vendée, I would like to express first of all the feeling of rebellion of the victims of the Erika black tide before the disasters caused not by a natural catastrophe like the hurricane who has just hit us, but for a crime.With the urgency, given adversity, a magnificent impulse of solidarity has been manifested: local solidarity, national solidarity, intergovernmental solidarity.What the sinister populations now expect, who have lost everything, in particular among the professionals of the sea and tourism, those whose activity is committed to several years, is not only that pollINATORS repair the damage they have caused, but also that everything necessary so that their current misfortune serves in the future to others to prevent the repetition of such crimes.We are paying - it is more than obvious - the price of our left.Because our states, with the blessing of the community, have not considered it appropriate to continue having their own merchant fleet and have let a rigorous expertise in the field of naval construction disappear, we no longer have a clear traceability of the ships and see authentic ships-base Surcar our waters with a pavilion of convenience, at the mercy of the short-term interests of the multinational companies.

When the contracts come into force and what final form they will have depends on the implementation also depends on the implementation by the contracting parties.In the United States, the WIPO contract has already achieved legal force in the form of the digital Millenium Corporate Act, whereby this legislative measure has managed to maintain the delicate balance in the sense of the WIPO.The EU must also make progress in accordance with the agreements made in the WIPO.It is also questionable that the statements adopted by the previous parliament do not support the balanced WIPO system.The statement in the first reading of the copyright guideline had a inclination and the balance was shifted in a manner that was disadvantageous for Europe.The proposed recommendations do not promote the position of culture in Europe, on the contrary.Rather, the changes brought in by Parliament improve the possibilities of the media groups established on the existing market to put their old market shares of over 80 % by rigid and oversized copyright regulations in a new framework.So I am not talking about the recommendation of Charlotte Cederschiöld, which I think is an excellent document, but of the treatment of the topic copyrights by the last parliament.In particular, I would also like to thank Ms. Cederschiöld to clearly define the concept of so -called intermediate storage in her report.In the WIPO contract, this type of reproduction has not been given a conscious position.If these technical copies are subject to protection, the data transmissions - as is rightly stated in the recommendation - are more expensive and complicated.This is as if a postman would have to pay a license fee if he has a book to read the consumer.The actual advantage of culture is to be able to bring art and knowledge safely and easily from the artist directly to the user, the consumer.The new activity environment is above all a huge opportunity to create and spread culture in a different way than ever before.It is essential to take into account the interests of all parties.The parliament tried to meet this aspect in its recommendation.President!First of all my compliment to the rapporteur for the work she did.According to the Commission, she worked quickly and precisely.That is not unimportant.The Commission would like to express its recognition to the rapporteur.Right from the start, I would like to say that the Commission agrees with the conclusions in the draft of a recommendation and therefore agrees to ratification by the parliament.I would like to highlight the importance of both contracts.With the Wipo consulting law contract and the WIPO contract for performances and recordings, we make progress in the international protection of copyrights and the related rights and thus a significant improvement in the Bern agreement and the Roman contracts.Both contracts contribute to better protection of works and other things, but enable the public to access the content offered in the networks.The two contracts expressly allow the community to become a contracting party and to have a say in the control in this area.The consent of the community to the contracts is of crucial importance because it shows how much it is due to intellectual property rights.

The third incoherence is related to human rights.It is said to want to protect them.Developing countries are encouraged to respect them.They even vote multiple resolutions to condemn each violation of these.We also echo the protests, of international campaigns.However, at the same time, the trade of weapons is allowed to develop, without worrying at least to limit the trade of the most atrocious weapons: antipersonnel mines, for example.Nor is much done to really prevent human rights violations.The fourth incoherence of the European Union cooperation policy is as follows: How do you want to help development by looting the natural resources of the countries they help?It is necessary that the European Union leave its fish to local fishermen to nurture local populations, instead of systematically destroying seabed with their intensive fishing.It is necessary to leave the raw materials to local producers so that they transform them.Let's not talk about oil, since unfortunately we know the policy of groups such as ELF or total in Africa.To go further, and that will be perhaps the fifth incoherence, we ask that biodiversity be respected, among other reasons to allow everyone to produce with their own seeds and preserve natural wealth.However, at the same time, and we still saw it during the last negotiations, ACP countries are obliged to sign the Trips agreements, when they run the risk of being expanded to living organisms.This extension would therefore mean the death of biodiversity and return to de facto slavery for the small farmers from the south to the mercy of multinationals.On the other hand, and this is a sixth incoherence, the application of existing treaties is not defended.Thus, on the one hand, a budgetary endowment is voted for the fight against AIDS and, on the other, nothing is done by imposing that mandatory licenses be met within the framework, precisely, of the aforementioned Trips, which would therefore allow developing countries to produce their own medications and curb the hecatombe caused by AIDS.In the same sense, during the WTO negotiations, and when the Schwaiger report observed, from the second section, that broad sectors of the population of developing countries, especially the poorest, barely benefit from the current process of liberalization of exchanges, the European Union continuesnecessary to reinforce it, especially for the poorest countries.The eighth incoherence is political and practical.It is always said: to think globally and act locally.However, local development agents are neglected, preferring to argue with national governments, subsidize North NGOs at the expense of local South NGO programs.Agriculture, environment, are other problems, other inconsistencies that could also have been mentioned, not forgetting research, emigration or health.In summary, it is intended to want to help developing countries and, at the same time, market liberalization is stimulated, recognizing that it is against that objective.

What should be done with this money?Human rights deserve special mention.West has fought for human rights in Kosovo.What currently happens in the area?The massive expulsions orchestrated by the Serbs have been ended, but despite this there are virtually every day unacceptable situations in which people are killed or lived where and how they want.Every day aggressions against Serbs, Rome and Bosnians are recorded, while attacks against Albanians continue to occur.Actually, the news has frightened me, if it is true, that an Albanian doctor, who has undoubtedly worked in very difficult conditions in the hospital of the Serbian part of Mitrovica, has been forced to stop attending to his people in that hospital because he received continuous death threats.They are incidents and situations that we cannot tolerate.The news has come to me - I don't know if it is true or not - that the Serbs continue to exploit a mine in Kosovo, in the Serbian part.Rumor runs that Serbian militias remain active.I do not care if it is a Serbian, a Rome, a Bosnium or an Albanian who receives threats or is killed in Kosovo.I don't care who tries to divide and separate Kosovo.What matters to me is that the organs that we finance get what we want to achieve, namely a multiethnic Kosovo, a Kosovo of coexistence.We need more police officers, since the current forces are insufficient.We need independent justice -fed hard -we also need means for the High Commissioner for Human Rights.All this should be done and the sooner it becomes better.If we take for help, the situation will make it worse, with the risk of new conflicts and crisis situations.For this reason, it seems correct that we have acted quickly, that we have recognized the urgent character of the operation and that we free the funds.Now, we want to see facts and we also want to see results in Kosovo.Therefore, I ask the commission to ensure that money is destined for effective purposes, especially to the organization of the Police and the Organization of Justice..Mr. President, thank you, in the first place, the deputies, and especially the rapporteur, for the speed with which they have dealt with this issue.It will undoubtedly allow us to free Kosovo's funds quickly and face the concerns that both Mr. Swoboda and Mrs. Pack have raised us.In tonight, I think I perceive three fundamental types of concern.In the first place, although much progress has been made, and we could refer to the administration of Customs, to the Banking Administration, to the Tax Administration, it is true that we have to move forward.Go ahead to finance what?There we have a first point of a certain disagreement.You raise us in any of your amendments that are established more limitedly the type of entities referred to in the contribution of the financing of the Union.For example, in amendments 3 and 5.

This is certainly the best boost we can give to democracy in Europe.If, in this way, we abandon the culture of the fifties to engage in the new century, we can say that we have experienced a very beautiful moment.Mr. President, I first address my congratulations to Michiel Van Hulten for his first report.It was a famous hazing but, as popular wisdom says, the best way to learn to swim is to throw yourself immediately.Dear colleague, after such an event, I think you can qualify for the Olympic Games!In my opinion, two points deserve the particular attention of my group.First, there is the individual responsibility of the commissioners.This point must be set at the intergovernmental conference.We certainly do not want this important question to be left to the entire discretion of the council.Consequently, we have filed an amendment in which we ask if it would not be possible to conclude an agreement between the Commission and the Parliament so that we have a kind of retirement position rather than leaving our fate in the hands of the Council.The second point that my colleague, Mr. Mulder, has already mentioned, is that, according to the European Party of Liberals Democrats and Reformers, the Parliament should also be examined by independent experts.This would contribute enormously to the restoration of the confidence of European citizens in our institution.We can only be both an opponent and a credible partner of the reformed commission that if we recognize our wrongs and if we put on order inside the European Parliament.It is only by reforming all of the European institutions that we will obtain from democratic, dynamic and transparent Europe that our fellow citizens deserve.Mr. President, I would also like to congratulate my colleague Van Hulten at the first work he presents in the Assembly.I am convinced that it will serve him, among other things, so that his second report gains flexibility and for him to seek to reach a greater consensus between the different groups.Now, the Commission reform process claimed by citizens cannot be postponed.This parliament has heard many occasions, including on the part of the Presidents of the Commission, the wish that it is reformed.It now seems that it becomes more serious.After the resignation of a commission and the demonstration of an almost unlimited number of inadequacies by an expert committee, the promise made by Mr. Prodi on September 14 to present before this assembly a complete reform project for the month of February is logical.Parliament anxiously awaits this complete reform program.The report that we are now debating is trying to give a political force to a good part of the recommendations of the Expert Committee charged by this Parliament.Mr. Prodi said that in any case he would act, that he would of course prefer to succeed, but that the fear of not reaching his goal would not prevent him from acting.Therefore, we ask that his program be courageous, because, if this is the case, I can assure him that Parliament will be on the side of the Commission in this reform process.

Mr. President, I would also like to start by thanking Corrie for his excellent report that, in my opinion, he describes and properly summarize the work done in the AU-EU Joint Assembly in 1999. My intervention time is short and I want to take care of two issues.The first of these refers to the fight against poverty that, in my opinion, begins to be an embarrassing story for both the EU and the Member States.Although both in the treaty and in the UN meetings in Rio and in Copenhagen we have committed ourselves to work to end poverty, in reality cuts are made in the budgets for development aid, contrary to what has been said to be done.You have to stop this trend.We have to start by condemning debts.You have to start putting action behind the words.I would like us to have an important role in this work.The other thing is that, on many occasions, we say that ACP countries have to learn democratic foundations.In points 2 and 3 of the resolution, in the framework of the new convention, work methods are developed and better.ACP countries will be urged to express their opinions to many political currents.In my opinion, this is very good, and it is something that I give my full support.However, we must also ask how we understand democracy.How works in the Delegation of the European Parliament before the ACP-EU Joint Assembly?Contrary to how things work here in the European Parliament and in the parliamentary commissions, in which speakers are proposed and designated for the reports, in this delegation before the Joint Assembly there are no rules.The two large groups distribute all the reports with each other.To change this anti -democratic situation, the Verts/Ale has presented the amendment 6. In it we ask that the speakers of the general reports and memories, in addition to the members of the working groups, are designated according to clear and democratic norms.In this context, small groups and their representativeness must be taken into account.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I want to congratulate our partner Mr. Corrie for the quality of his report that relevantly reflects the content of the debates of the Joint Assembly whose co -presidency assumed very effectively.The eradication of poverty has been the central theme of our works, and to achieve that ambitious objective, many auditors caught attention to the need to preserve a fundamental tool: I refer to preferential agreements between the European Union and the ACP countries, within the framework of the Lomé Agreements.It was a considerable challenge.The globalization, the liberalization of exchanges, as well as the preeminence of the WTO and the World Cup philosophy that she vehicle threatened the very essence of the North-South dialogue.

We must end at all costs to the irresponsibility waterfall, irresponsible charterers, unenforceable shipowners, complacent certification societies.Now, today we are immersed in the greatest confusion.These issues should be discussed - it is more than evident - in the worldwide, but the current international standards are very insufficient and much more laxist and neither our countries nor the community have tried with a determination to make them more rigorous, despite recent catastrophes.It is true that the International Fund against Hydrocarbons Contamination (FIPOL) exists, but dilutes the responsibilities and its level of prescriptions is totally insufficient, and should be checked.The question of the convenience pavilions within the framework of the IMO must be imperatively reviewed.It corresponds to the Member States and the community to adopt the necessary initiatives for that purpose.I have to remember that Erika carried a pavilion of convenience of a candidate state to enter the union.On the other hand, there are community directives, but they do not apply or apply little due to lack of a sufficient number of national controllers.You have to urgently remedy that lack.For many years, a directive on maritime security has been in preparation, but progresses very slowly.From that point of view, there is an inadmissible inertia and unacceptable lack by the commission.The date of presentation of the communication of the Commission dedicated to that essential issue, perpetually postponed and now planned for July must be advanced imperatively.As for the substantive provisions that must be established, they must be particularly clear and strict.I will mention three that our group considers priority.First, the responsibility of the owners of the oil cargoes must be clearly established and the victims of the pollution must be able to establish judicial actions without ambiguity against those responsible.The best prevention for the future is the certainty of charterers that, if they are not extraordinarily vigilant on the safety of ships they choose, severe civil, criminal and financial convictions will receive.Secondly, the condition of a double helmet for oil tankers to which community waters is allowed and should not be left for Greek calenders should be imposed as quickly as possible.Thirdly, a strict limitation of the age of ships to which community waters is allowed to be set up.It could be fifteen at most.If a sufficiently clear, strict and rigorous community regulatory framework is not achieved, the Member States that wish, on the other hand, to establish it to protect its population and their territory, in the same way that the United States have known, on the other hand, to take advantage of the teachings of the catastrophe of Exxon Valdez, demanding the double hull and seeing its waters to all the ships of more than twenty years.Thus, the United States denied Erika access to its waters.If the community had done the same, an immense catastrophe would have been avoided.

According to the Commission, the convent responsible for the development of the fundamental rights chart must take into account the task that is given to him by the European Council of Cologne.However, this does not mean that the convention would have to limit itself to a codifying function existing in different sources.As I already had the opportunity to carry out this parliament, the Commission is convinced that the convent may have to be able to adapt and develop these rights taking into account current circumstances, in particular technical and social development.In view of the mandate and the final purpose of the text to be presented by the head of state and government, however, this option must be used with caution and only in case.The rights awarded with this charter apply to at least two groups of people.Part of everyone in the area of ​​the Union benefits from the Union in the area of ​​the Union, only the Union citizens.It is also conceivable that certain economic and social rights are granted only Union citizens and, under certain conditions, nationals are granted by third countries.At the present time, since the process of developing the Charter is still at the very beginning, it is still premature to want to go into more detail on the content of the charter.However, it is clear that the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women will certainly be one of the rights guaranteed by the future fundamental rights chart of the Union, since it is already included in the EU contract and the derived law and is undoubtedly one of the joint constitutional traditions of the Member States.As I have already presented before this parliament, the Commission is to include this charter in the contract.However, it is aware that the final decision is the responsibility of the state and heads of government.The not easy task of the convention is therefore to develop an ambitious and politically significant text, which can easily be included in the contracts.In its statement on the convening of a government conference to change the contracts, the Commission points out that the European Council must decide on the admission of certain topics in the agenda of the government conference in the course of 2000, including the fundamental rights chart of the European Union.Mr. Commissioner, it is extremely important that the citizens of Europe, men and women, are called up at the beginning of this new century to re -determine their rights and duties.We hope that the significant decision of the Cologne Council will really be fulfilled with life.The globalization on the one hand and the expansion on the other hand make the fixing of these rights only appear more urgent.Seattle has given the reason to seriously think about many related problems, and hopefully the European Council of Nice will not come together for nothing.However, in order to ensure the participation of the citizens in this new project, we would like to know which plan the European organs, specifically the European Commission, proposes for the social and democratic model of the Europe of the 21st century.I have heard something about her general line and now I would like to ask which space is intended for the children as an independent individuals in this project of the European Commission for a new social model of the 21st century.Mr President, Mrs. MP, I have to tell you very clearly that in my opinion and according to the statements of the President President President President from this morning, the development of the Charter is a politically very important process because he shows that the Union places the fundamental rights of its citizens on all other political concerns for the future of our joint project.

At that time, the interpreter of the general emotion in the face of the disastrous consequences of this disaster, the Council expressed its concern about the security of the oil tankers and the protection of the environment which must be associated with it.The council was not insensitive to this type of question and the need to take additional measures in this area.The importance for the Council to take new measures on the community level, and as part of its own work with international organizations, was highlighted at the time.As you know, in the current state, community legislation obliges the port authorities to perform inspections on board all foreign ships, including those who beat complacency, and immobilize them in the event that they do not meet international standards.There is a 1995 directive in this area.With regard to the future, the Council noted that the current reflection process at the level of the Commission will soon lead to communication on the security of oil tankers and to new proposals aimed at strengthening controls, as well as qualifications for inspection organizations.It is also planned to strengthen the structures of oil tankers who frequent community ports.These files are followed by the Council of Ministers of Transport and I can assure you, on behalf of the Council, that we will grant the greatest priority to the proposals that the Commission will present in this area, in all likelihood.This seems essential to us in terms of environmental protection.Of course Parliament will be called upon to also decide on these proposals, since these are materials subject to codecision.I am delighted that the council reflect on this question.The chairman of the council is from a country, Portugal, which is directly threatened by a situation of this kind.If we think too much, by next summer, an oil tanker subject to such conditions could very well sink off the coasts of the Algarve, destroy the Portuguese tourism industry of the summer and, with a little luck, the sea currents could take this pollution to the island of Madeira - because they follow this direction - and, in addition, also destroyingCanaries.Does the president of the council not believe that we must stop thinking and start to take draconian measures in this area, taking into account that today we already have the means necessary to control this type of oil trees on the high seas?In any case, the history of Erika is a story that seems comical.A French boat, beating Maltese pavilion, with an Indian crew, with a navigation certificate issued by Italy, Sicily, and the last inspection of which was, I think, carried out in Bulgaria.The boat was flowing, the captain saw him well and knew that he would not even come to the nearest port.I think it should not be allowed.The damage can be catastrophic for your country, Mr. President, and for mine too, Spain.

and above all of a citizen-consumer, I express my satisfaction for the proposal of the European Commission which marks a further step forward in the direction of an improvement in food safety in the European Union.The proposal is twofold: on the one hand, it is a matter of modifying the 1991 council directive relating to the conditions of health policy by eliminating the provisions concerning the disease of the sheep's trot, or scrapia, and, on the other, to define a new regulation that establishes provisions for prevention and fight against some transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (east) or eSb types that affect the sheep andOther animal species.The positive aspect of the new legislation consists in the fact that a specific legal base is created for the fight against the Scrapia.My satisfaction is even greater as it was one of the main requests contained in the control and evaluation report following the crazy cow crisis.Moreover, it seems to me indispensable, in an intent of consistency, to merge the existing legislation relating to the disease disease, limited to the commercial exchanges of sheep and caprini, in a single mechanism complete with new provisions governing the East that affect all animals in the European Union as a whole, in order to prevent the consumption of food or food products.This regulation is also appropriate because doubts continue to remain on the disease of the sheep's trot.According to some scientific hypotheses, this disease may have evolved to change into ESB in cattle and therefore be at the origin of ESB epizootia.At the time, of the clarifications and the strengthening that are necessary, in particular as regards the identification and fight against the Scratpie, the proposal of regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council containing provisions for the prevention and control of some est represents a considerable improvement.It is a guarantee for European citizens who have repeatedly expressed their concerns against European food policy, concerns that, taken from the European Parliament, have been heard.The discussions relating to the precautionary principle, to traceability, responsibility, transparency led the European Commission to present a white paper on food safety, which offers different food for thought and in particular has proposed the creation of an independent European food authority.All this is part of a European strategy aimed at regaining consumer trust.It is up to us European managers to demonstrate that single market and free movement of goods can be combined with food safety!Report Cederschiöld (A5-0008/2000) Mr. President, I voted in favor of this provision on the reorganization of the legislation concerning copyright because I believe it is one of the most important sectors in which the activity of the European Parliament is expressed.They are of the opinion that the product of the ingenuity is much more important than the constructions, tangible products, which we can precisely see to touch, while as ingenuity and science, which also cannot be touched by hand, arise of great importance that we, as we European community, should support much more actively, not only through the protection of patents but granting facilitations and support for scientists, to those who - by taking advantage of the teachings received -They use to give future generations something much more important than we have had in the past.

Therefore, we support the amendments 78 and 79 that prefigure a minimum of safe standards regarding telephone listening and videoconferences.On the one hand, we await with great attention the result of this vote in order to avoid emptying all this agreement - that, I repeat, already establishes minimal standards - and, on the other, we are in favor of waiting for any proposals that arrive from the Commission so that this minimum community right is finally prepared.Mr. President, no doubt that, given the growing phenomena of organized crime at international level, the Member States should cooperate as much as possible, or better, the institutional conditions should be established to implement a concrete and effective process of cooperation in the judicial field: a process that, however, must face all the necessary stages to avoid that there are inappropriate forces to the detriment of the legitimate indications of the legitimate.regarding which Member States are sovereign, and especially to avoid forcing that end up belittling the fundamental rights of citizens.Consequently, it is necessary to act with caution before a text such as the Council, in which, as the rapporteur has also stressed, after years of debate, it is now intended to solve everything in a few months.In addition - I share the valuations of Mr. Di Pietro - the text of the Council seems even too rich in contradictions, incoherent formulations and lagoons.Obviously, justice, more than any other sector, cannot be treated incoherent and contradictory.In our group, the report as a whole seems very debatable, despite the introduction of some corrective amendments, sensitive to the protection of personal freedoms and respect for national sovereignty.In the report, too heterogeneous materials are addressed, there is no gradation and proceed by approximation.In conclusion, we will vote against this report reiterating that the Europe we want must be a Europe of rights and guarantees: rights and guarantees that require gradual and responsible reflections, as well as very serious deepenings.In the first place, the general rules must be established, institutional certainties, and only after the establishment of practical agreements may be proceeded.Mr. President, on behalf of the deputies of the Bonino list, I want to confirm the position we had in the Commission of Freedoms and Rights of Citizens, Justice and Internal Affairs and, consequently, also announced the vote on behalf of our deputies: a vote against this report, or better, a vote against the agreement on which the report is based.However, I want to thank and praise the work of the speaker who has heard very carefully what we held in the Commission, in particular about the issue of the rights to defense both at the national level and in the field of cooperation in criminal matters of European legal assistance.The commission and the rapporteur have accepted nine of the eleven amendments that we have presented and that are based precisely on the rights to defense.

I also propose that the withdrawal of salmon that present clinical signs of the disease should be immediate.To introduce the withdrawal plans, the procedures already existing in Community legislation will be used for the introduction of additional control measures;These plans will be based on the actual health conditions of the salmon in order to reduce the possible environmental impact to the maximum.In this regard, I accept the amendments nos.7 and 8, the latter with a slight change.I am also in favor of amendment no.9, but I believe that it must be formulated better in order to also include environmental issues and strategies of eradication and control of the disease.I do not believe I can accommodate the amendments nos.12 and 13 as it seems to me that they are aimed at zeroing the risk.I believe that this goal is very difficult to achieve without causing the closing of the sector farms.I would like to know Parliament's opinion on these amendments and know if he thinks that this approach represents the best way to act.I can also partially accommodate amendment no.11. Finally, I want to emphasize that we will continue to fight to maintain a high standard of protection of public health in accordance with the obligations provided for by the Treaty.I believe that measures in line with this goal must be proposed to go on.We will continue to commit ourselves to eradicate the disease, to the advantage of both the environment and the salmon industry.I will be extremely grateful to the Parliament if, in accepting the proposal, it will recognize our commitment.Thank you, Commissioner Byrne.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, at 11.00.The protection of novels The agenda bears the discussion on the A5-0035/2000 report, presented by the honorable Gallagher on behalf of the Commission for Fishing Commission on the proposal of the Council Regulations containing fourth modification of the Regulation (EC) n.1624/94 which establishes technical measures for the conservation of fishing resources in the Mediterranean and fourth modification of regulation (EC) no.850/98 for the conservation of fishing resources through technical measures for the protection of novel (com (1999) 552 - C5-0040/2000 - 1999/0222 (CNS)).The proposal under consideration, broadly described in the introduction, is very important.My colleagues from the Commission for Fishing and Parliament know that our work on technical conservation measures is based on concrete technical indications.The institution in charge of providing these indications, based on certain scientific tests, is the Commission for the conservation of tonnids in the Atlantic (ICCOT).This intergovernmental organization on fishing, which also includes the European Union, is responsible for the conservation of tons and similar species in the Atlantic and the adjacent marries, including the Mediterranean.It was established in March 1969 and, although formally required to meet every two years, meets every year.It makes its decisions on the basis of scientific indications and therefore formula recommendations for the conservation of fish resources.The ICCT operates through four permanent committees, consisting of national experts, who deal with research and statistics, finances and administration, compliance with the rules, as well as conservation and management measures.There are also four working groups that deal, respectively, of the tons of the tropical area, of those of the northern temperate area, those of the southern tempered area and other species.

While taking into account the new rules introduced by the Treaty of Amsterdam, which provide for its entry into force after at least half of the Member States have adopted the agreement, I would like to invite Member States to do everything possible to rap this convention quickly.Unfortunately, the experience made on the occasion of rates of the conventions of the European Union in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters is disappointing.This agreement will not create a new or different system of judicial assistance;Its purpose is to be based on consolidated and tested mechanisms, which has already been operating for a long time, such as those provided for by the judicial assistance agreement of the Council of Europe, from 1959, and by the Bennelux Treaty.The project developed by the Council contains provisions on various issues that have been discussed by many Parliament deputies.An important conquest of the Convention is that, where possible, the Member States to which all the formalities and procedures indicated by the requesting Member State is made.This is particularly important for the possibility of using the tests obtained in court.In addition, requests can be submitted directly between the competent authorities without having to pass through the central authorities.In general terms, there are two types of provisions: those that impose the obligation to offer assistance - such as the provisions concerning the phone and videoconferences, supervised deliveries and the interception of telecommunications - and those in which no obligation is imposed, but a simple legal framework is established for the Member States that want to collaborate in the prescribed manner - for example, the provisions concerning the common investigative teams,infiltration operations and sending and offering procedural documents.The Commission welcomes with particular favor the inclusion of provisions that deal with new or modern investigative techniques, given their effectiveness in the fight against organized crime, which thanks to its own location can take advantage of the opening of the borders.It is all too easy to be dragged by the obvious need to improve the effectiveness of criminal investigations.However, we must not forget an essential aspect of any action on criminal procedures: defense rights.I really appreciate that the report of the honorable of Peter, to whom I pay homage to the excellent work done in such a short time, includes the rights of defense between the fundamental points.Currently it is currently only due to the Member States to guarantee respect for these rights under the control of the European Court of Human Rights of Strasbourg.It remains to be seen if this will change with the new card of fundamental rights of the European Union, whose preparation has just begun.We must recognize that article 18 concerns a clearly controversial decision.The article was carefully formulated, during prolonged debates within the Council, to guarantee the effectiveness of intelligence activities and the inclusion of criminal investigations.As regards the criminal investigations, of which I am responsible, I take note of the invitation addressed to the Commission and the Council, by various deputies of the European Parliament, to consider the matter and address it on a common legal basis, given the importance that the interception of telecommunications can have as proof before the Court.The Commission is fully aware of the fact that the project in front of us is neither perfect nor ideal, but it must be realistic.

Additional recommendations as to this way of proceeding are also in the second report of the Committee of Wise Men.Likewise, the commission, through the voice of MM.Barnier and Vitorino, as well as certain Member States are resolutely favorable.I beg you, dear colleagues, to vote for this report adopted by a large majority by the Budget Control Commission.We can once again show that this Parliament is active to prevent mismanagement and, in particular, fraud and pronounce a conviction where it is necessary.Mr. President, I am happy to be able to express myself on this report and I congratulate Ms. Theato.I believe that this is a report where cooperation between the commissions has worked very well and the result, which reaches us today, is a sober and serene relationship on an extremely delicate material.Sobriety and serenity which are particularly necessary for the development of article 280.4.Because if we had to award a price for the most difficult article to understand, the least clear, the most confused whatever the name you want to give it, the competition would be, in doubt, very harsh when the treaty is a sampling of complex items, but it goes without saying that this article is a serious candidate at this price.This is also a particularly delicate question because it is, as Ms. Theato said, the protection of the financial interests of the community which is the game. We are all aware and this parliament is the first to have cared for the need to protect the financial interests of the community.But let's be careful and, as the French say: "Let's not throw the baby with bath water".In other words, it is necessary to respect, within the framework of the protection of the financial interests of the community, not only and Ms. Theato underlined, the powers of the national states, but also other points which concern citizens, which concern essential guarantees.The conclusions of the Theato report save them perfectly.Starting, as the president of the legal committee and the internal market and, of course, from the deputy, I hope that, tomorrow, this report will benefit from the support of the Parliament, to a large majority, and that it will be well implemented by the Commission.Mr. President, as Ms. Theato said, it is a critical relationship.It was proposed by the Budget Control Commission and it is an initiative report.One of the reasons why we ardently wanted to highlight this aspect was that the European Union, whether we like it or not, drags behind it a reputation for fraud and mismanagement, an exaggerated reputation, but it exists.We have to do something to remedy this situation.Some of the measures we have implemented in the past have not been respected by certain Member States - let's not forget that the Member States are responsible for the execution of some 80 % of the EU budget.

I don't quite understand what the commissioner said.At this point, the vase leash in Stregrennan, added to the special protection zone at the commission's request, was completely destroyed.It is clear that the activities that took place at this location are in blatant offense with European directives.You say that there will be no subsequent funding.I would like to know if you hear, at this stage, to stop funding completely until a real investigation takes place.If not, why?If so, when will you do it exactly?Is it correct and indicated that the department which has the company is also the authority which issues the license as well as that which, at the base, perceives the funds from the EU and the reverse them to a company it has 100 %?Is it fair and well indicated?What is your opinion about it?It is necessary to put an end to any community funding of the project because it is in the blatant offense of the EU directives.Even the area designated by the commissioners as a special protection zone has been destroyed.Compensation afterwards will not repair the damage caused.The first legal challenge followed the start of the development of the port of the port, at the beginning of fall 1999, without having been implemented compensatory improvements in terms of housing.This resulted that the Irish authorities agreed to restore the elimination of the Spartina Anglica, but this time by mechanical means.The use of mechanical resources has brought an additional legal challenge - this is what I referred to in my first answer - based on the argument that mechanical abduction would damage the vase leashes and would cause proliferation in the estuary of the Spartina Anglica, harmful on the environmental level.Currently, this legal challenge has not identified any conclusive result.The adoption of the necessary compensatory measures is the responsibility of the national authorities and does not require any prior approval of the Commission.The role of the commission is to ensure full compliance with the standards required by the bird directive and it is clear that damaging compensatory measures as such would be a problem.In this case, the Commission proposes to request additional clarifications with the Irish authorities with regard to the most recent situation in terms of compensatory measures and the potential problems of the mechanical elimination of the Anglica Spartina.For the time being it is, we are not ready to offer the interruption of financing for structural funds.Mr. President, the specific case raised by Ms. McKenna is unfortunately not an isolated case.There are other examples of damage caused to the conservation of special scientific zones following EU funding.Will the Commission plan to transmit instructions to all member states stipulating that if, in the future, it discovers that European environmental directives have been infringed or that adequate environmental assessments have not been carried out, not only will interrupt any future funding but it will also withdraw the funds already allocated;In other words, it will claim the reimbursement of the sums paid to the Member States?Only such a measure will discourage this practice in the future.

A fair approach to the problem of speculation consists, in my opinion, in eliminating the true causes of financial disorders, not in an attempt to suppress only the symptoms by introducing obstacles to the functioning of the markets.Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, I would like to reconstruct the procedure and the ideological tactic that led to this oral question in short, also because I know how many social democrats to Parliament, and not only experts on economic and financial policy, share our criticism.We know the problem.It is the instability on markets caused by speculations.However, it should be remembered to those who presented the oral question that - as the commissioner explained incisively - not any form of instability is a consequence of speculation.The Tobin Tax could not have avoided the crises at the SEE level in 1992 and 1993 nor the monetary crisis in the 1997 Southeast Asian. The authors of the oral question do not hypothesize any solution, but ask for a new tribute, more bureaucracy and a measure contrary to market mechanisms.They propose an intergroup evaluation in the classroom excluding the competent parliamentary commission, in contrast with different decisions of Parliament.This question, I say it in no uncertain terms, is motivated in my opinion by ideological reasons and does not aim to find solutions.I believe it is the wrong road.Why do we reject the Tobin Tax and consider it with so much suspicion?First, as the commissioner has already affirmed, because it represents a strong burden for the capital markets.Even a minimum taxation would entail heavy repercussions on the capital markets, since such a tax on speculation would reduce the profitability of investments to considerable extent.Furthermore, such a measure would strongly compromise the development of financial markets, contrasting the principle of free movement of capital which represents one in the central nuclei of the internal market.Second, capital invested for speculation purposes is difficult to identify.Third, tax measures can be easily circumvented, if they are not introduced with the same system in all countries, because too many escapade remain open.Fourth, this measure is difficult to apply from a technical point of view and involves a high degree of bureaucracy and administrative charges with the impossibility of effective control.The measure we should adopt is a part of the resolution today.It is a matter of strengthening banking supervision, of clarifying the responsibility for transactions, of creating an international regulatory framework, of evaluating national laws in order to verify if they comply with the rules of the Basel Committee and to understand how the latter can be more widespread.Regarding this resolution, I have a strong doubt about a fundamental point that we cannot accept in this form.I refer to paragraph 9. From the intervention of the Commissioner we deduce that the examination of the Commission will end with a refusal of the Tobin Tax.If this assessment, the current debate and the arguments proposed are of the tenor that has emerged and that I share, also the fact that the commission is dealt with for another six months with the consequent insecurity that will affect the financial and capital markets represents a lack of responsibility.

Indonesia.We are obviously very happy that Indonesia now has a new government and that Mr. Wahid and Mrs Soukarnopoutri occupy the presidency and the vice-president respectively.We also welcome what the situation in Timor evolves slowly in the right direction.However, I point out to you that in the Moluccas, an archipelago located just north of Timor, violence has not yet been mastered.Thousands
